column1: I bought a Sony ICD-MX20 Digital Voice Recorder a week ago.  I was surprised that Sony does not provide downloads of the associated software named "Digital Voice Editor".  Sony Customer Service staff told me that if you lost the CD that came with the box
column2: you had to buy a new one.  Only patches of the software are available to download.    The Customer Service personnel told me that it was corporate policy despite the fact that the software is bound to the digital device.  This immoral policy violating the norm of digital appliance industries and should not be encouraged.  Sony is demoting its brand name by offering poor post-sales services.  Think twice before making your buying decision.

column1: I agree with all the negative reviews on this list about this disc and Lang Lang in general.  I was deeply disappointed with his performances of the Tchaikovsky/Mendelssohn and Rachmaninov concertos.  Then
column2: my friend asked me to listen to his Islamey
column3: exclaiming that it was one of the most remarkable performances he'd ever heard.  I remember clearly thinking how boring it was and had to have my friend listen to the incredible performance by Ogdon and
column4: even more brazen account (remember this piece ismeant to be a showpiece
column5: and not the pseudo-intellectual piece Lang Lang thinks it is) by Barere.  Although I'm no fan of Islamey
column6: I find it very easy to discern the difference between mediocrity (Lang Lang) and brilliance.  I got a chance to listen to some of this disc couple of months ago
column7: and boy
column8: he continues to disappoint.  Regarding all those who say he's the next Horowitz or Richter blah blah
column9: I suspect that these people don't know history.  Another fundamental mistake they make is that they form conclusions without comparing to other performances.  Just compare his interpretations of the abegg variations and the Wanderer fantasy to those by Kissin or Richter.  You'll quickly notice how pedantic and uninspiring Lang Lang's accounts are.  Boring as I don't know what!  Likewise
column10: try comparing his Tchaikovsky's 1st or Rach 2nd to those by Horowitz
column11: Argerich
column12: and Freire
column13: and Richter
column14: Kissin
column15: Cliburn
column16: Ashkenazy
column17: Jando and countless others.  Lang Lang sounds absolutely amateurish in comparison.  Memory can be very fleeting and the only reliable thing is to compare side by side.  His mediocrity just jumps out and grabs you.  I'm willing to admit that my main objections to Lang Lang's musicality is subjective in nature.  Afterall
column18: taste is taste.  While I find Lang Lang's tone terribly uneven and dull
column19: with his interpretations without life
column20: with his general stance of "let's not mess things up here" attitude
column21: others may indeed find him exciting.  However
column22: I will not concede that his technique is somehow "one of the greatest."  To this day
column23: I cannot figure out how one can consider his technique to be great.  Just sit in a dark room
column24: close your eyes and dissect his articulation
column25: finger work
column26: phrasing
column27: octaves
column28: and you'll notice that no way in hell does his technique measure up to those by Michelangeli
column29: Hamelin
column30: Barere
column31: Berman
column32: and Horowitz
column33: or even to those by Leslie Howard
column34: Kissin
column35: Zayas
column36: Argerich
column37: Gould
column38: Gavrilov
column39: Cziffra
column40: Kocsis
column41: and Pollini.  To me Lang Lang's technique is dead average
column42: nothing special
column43: and for those who think his technique is one of the greatest in history or at least one of the greatest around
column44: perhaps more listening and studying is required.  Sure
column45: Clint Eastwood is a solid film maker
column46: but to say to me that he is in the league with Orson Welles
column47: Jean Renoir
column48: Stanley Kubrick
column49: Martin Scorsese
column50: Alfred Hitchcock would lead me believe that more film study of the classics is in order.  In conclusion
column51: Lang Lang (and this disc set) is a joke.  People tend to think that because an artist is heavily promoted by a large record company like DG
column52: then he must be good.  This effect can be very powerful and
column53: now in this era
column54: often very wrong.  If classical music continues down this path of promoting dead average pianists
column55: then we are all going to suffer

column1: I could attack this book for its lack of political merit

column4: which is one of the cover issues of the book
column5: is bizarre on its own because it takes the late-18th century definition of liberal and stacks it up against the 20th century definition of conservative
column6: but again
column7: neither here nor there).  Every sentence is very simple
column8: there are no words that are too big
column9: so as not to confuse every South Park conservative who gets lost between the Dan Browns
column10: the Steve Kings
column11: and the 2-for-$11 DVD sections at the bookstores. The book is brimming with needless erreta and digressions

column14: ironic (or appropo?) given the book's harsh condemnation of the American intellectual; in a book where every professor is a communist and every college graduate is a tree-hugger

column16: subject-object confusion
column17: confused pronouns
column18: and uncited "data."  Certainly a fine bookshelf filler for every budding

column20: "and this is presented as a HISTORY book?" you may wish to look elsewhere

column1: I quote from GLIMPSES OF THE DEVIL
column2: p. 215: "...after spending a half hour with that book
column3: GODS' MAN. I called [a nun
column4: six years my senior
column5: who has been my spiritual director for more than twenty-five years] sobbing with a complex of emotions
column6: including hatred for the author
column7: disgust at the book
column8: rage at its destructiveness
column9: sorrow for all the other young boys and girls who had been the book's victims
column10: and a feeling of deep contamination that I had received just from looking at it. After we spoke
column11: I sent her my newly purchased copy and she called me back to agree that it was the single most destructive thing she had ever seen in her fifty-plus years." Undoubtedly
column12: Dr. Peck's strong emotional reaction was due to the destruction the book wrought in the life of one of Peck's patients. But now you are forewarned

column1: I purchased this book hoping that it would help me loosen up my watercolor painting.  I was disappointed enough to return it

column5: but I recommend you look over this book thoroughly before committing to purchasing it.  There is basically no instruction that will teach you to do a watercolor painting in anything but vague
column6: fuzzy
column7: garishly colored (she really
column8: really likes bright pink) paintings that call to my mind the tie-died T-shirts of the 60's.  I was also put off by the self-portrayal of the author as a kind of artistico-spiritual guru.  In her experience
column9: she says
column10: all watercolor students fall into one of two categories:  those who never finish a picture because they are too hung up on doing things just so
column11: and those who would like to play but don't know how--left brain types and right brain types.  She assures us she has had an epiphany and is now beyond such limitations.  If you buy her books
column12: she'll share her higher wisdom.  Well
column13: good for her
column14: she's got her audience.  There are Taoist quotes at the beginning of the chapters
column15: but if you want to explore that philosophy
column16: you'd be better off with a source that truly addresses it.  If you want to learm how to do watercolors
column17: this is not the place to do it

column18: blah blah
column19: yadda yadda yadda".Then he went out to blah blah blah.       - They said "Blah
column20: blah blah
column21: yadda yadda yadda".Then they went out to blah blah blah.         Because of this distracting form of typing

column1: The only reason I'm reviewing this movie now is because I just watched it on TV today. And the only reason I watched it was because nothing else was on. So...  No
column2: let's be fair. I did enjoy Analyze This
column3: I really did
column4: though it wasn't a masterpiece that would remain with me for the rest of my life
column5: or even for the rest of the day. And I do love both Billy Crystal and Robert De Niro; they made a fantastic comedic duo in the first movie. I didn't have very high expectations
column6: though
column7: because I rarely expect too much of sequels. Once again
column8: I was proven right.  Analyze That illustrates perfectly why `sequel' sounds like such a dirty word. The original film had a spark of originality; the sequel merely takes the same idea and the same jokes and tries to make them funny again. But of course
column9: that could never work. It's the same problem with almost every comedic sequel: those who haven't seen the original wouldn't understand the jokes
column10: and those who have already heard them before. And that is why they fail time after time.  So what does this movie have? A great comedic duo
column11: a couple of really funny guys. Yeah
column12: and? Fathers' Day had an even better pair
column13: look what happened to that. A couple of good mafia jokes? Sure
column14: sure. I even cracked a smile on several occasions. But that isn't enough. There are thousands of comedy films out there; not many of them have that special something that makes them memorable
column15: and producers think they'll improve their odds by recycling the ones that work instead of trying to get new ideas. Newsflash: think again. Nobody watches these movies. There's no reason to when you can just watch the original again

column1: Well
column2: I just received Gavin Lambert's book on Natalie Wood
column3: and after trudging through this monotonous
column4: overblown biography
column5: the conclusion is as follows: it's boring as hell!  (I can't say I haven't been warned). This is the "wonderful" biography of Natalie that is supposed to set the record straight?  It boasts 78 photos
column6: but instead of being included in a glossy pictures section
column7: they are widespread on various pages in the book so that they appear grainy.  It seems to me that it was written as a rebuttal
column8: and to paint Lana Wood as a greedy
column9: vicious person (she was obviously not interviewed)
column10: and to make childish slaps at her
column11: when she was not given the opportunity to tell her side of it.   Robert Wagner seems threatened by anyone who knew Natalie before he
column12: Lambert and Mart Crowley did - dismissing all of the people Natalie befriended before who offered their insights in "Natasha: The Biography Of Natalie Wood" as vultures who barely made her aquaintance and who are weaving fantasies about her.  Basically
column13: Wagner is uncomfortable with the aspects of Natalie's life that he was not involved in.  It doesn't really attempt to get behind Natalie's persona any
column14: like "Natasha" did
column15: and of course
column16: it doesn't acknowledge Natalie's love for Jimmy Williams
column17: her first boyfriend
column18: the rape by a famous actor
column19: or what happened on the night of her death
column20: hastily tying up loose ends and making her death sound so simple.  Lambert wrote this book for Wagner
column21: there's no question
column22: and Natasha and Courtney are hardly mentioned at all.  Did Lambert actually do any in-depth research?  As well
column23: there are allegations that Nick Gurdin may not have been Natalie's or Lana's father
column24: and then there's Natasha Lofft
column25: who has not proven with DNA that she is actually Natalie's half sister
column26: but Wagner and the girls have no problem believing that she is
column27: but they dismiss Suzanne Finstad's book as speculation and trash? I'll believe this claimant's story when I see proof! At least Finstad was able to remain somewhat objective and unbiased
column28: since she did not know Natalie (and she did try to get Wagner's input
column29: but he refused) which is obviously not the case with this pathetic attempt at a so-called "definitive" biography. Much of the book appears to be written quickly
column30: but at least it does name the film Natalie turned down
column31: which was reputed to have the actor who raped her in the cast.  And of course
column32: it has to dispel all the allegations of Wagner's sexual orientation
column33: and what played the role in the demise of his first marriage to Natalie.  As much of a disappointment as this book is
column34: I'm glad I purchased it so I can compare it to "Natasha" and Lana's book to try to decipher what is closer to the truth.  At least I didn't have to spend too much money on it!  Whatever the truth
column35: I hope that Natalie is at peace.

column3: never seems to have a consistent theme and finally

column8: it'll be another 20 years before 'ol Shirley picks up her pen again.

column1: Never in my life have I been so outraged by what I have read as by the drivel spouted by Dr. West in this book (in his Translator's Note)
column2: and by the use of `unponderingly' and "the Thinkery" (among other things) in his translation of The Clouds. I also read his translation of Plato's Apology of Socrates
column3: and found it grossly inferior to Jowett.  Four Texts on Socrates is not a book to be tossed aside lightly: it should be hurled with great force. (Apologies to Dorothy Parker.)  Not only are the translations themselves inexcusably inept
column4: almost everything that he writes in his Translator's Note is wrong.  The Clouds is a play
column5: not a scientific or mathematical treatise. As such
column6: it has characters and dialogue. A `modern' translation of a play must be something that could be presented on a stage and make sense to a `modern' audience. If a character is supposed to be bizarre or out of the ordinary
column7: one does not make him spout drivel such as 'unponderingly'; one gives him a `shtick'
column8: which is a theatrical term. It's more or less a running gag associated with a particular character. You create
column9: through clever ways of speaking or odd ways of stringing his words together
column10: a characterization. He could be made to speak like a parody of William F. Buckley or the Star Wars character Yoda. As it stands
column11: West's text cannot be presented as a play.  It is neither necessary nor useful to coin such nonsense as 'unponderingly'; indeed
column12: it is inexcusable. It conveys neither humor nor cleverness. It comes off simply as stupid. The translator of a play must know something about theatre and drawing characters
column13: which Dr. West obviously does not. To state it bluntly: The translation of plays should be left to people who understand theatre and characterization
column14: and who are creative. Dr. West doesn't have a creative bone in his body.  In regard to his translation of Plato's The Apology of Socrates
column15: the translation by Dr. West is both original and good
column16: but the parts that are good are not original
column17: and the parts that are original are not good. After all
column18: when one has the work of such a brilliant predecessor as Benjamin Jowett to follow
column19: the temptation to do something entirely different is strong. But it must be resisted. If Dr. West had merely lightly revised Jowett's great work
column20: he would have made a contribution to learning. Alas
column21: he did neither.   The version by Jowett is clearly superior. Here is a short excerpt:  "And I must beg of you to grant me a favor: If I defend myself in my accustomed manner
column22: and you hear me using the words which I have been in the habit of using in the agora
column23: at the tables of the money-changers
column24: or anywhere else
column25: I would ask you not to be surprised
column26: and not to interrupt me on this account. For I am more than seventy years of age
column27: and appearing now for the first time in a court of law
column28: I am quite a stranger to the language of the place; and therefore I would have you regard me as if I were really a stranger
column29: whom you would accuse if he spoke in his native tongue
column30: and after the fashion of his country: Am I making an unfair request of you? Never mind the manner
column31: which may or may not be good; but think only of the truth of my words
column32: and give heed to that: let the speaker speak truly and the judge decide justly."  Compare West's inept version:  "...I do very much beg and beseech this of you: if you hear me speaking in my defense with the same speeches I am accustomed to speak both in the marketplace at the money-tables
column33: where many of you have heard me
column34: and elsewhere
column35: do not wonder or make a disturbance because of this. For this is how it is: now is the first time I have come before a law court
column36: at the age of seventy; hence I am simply foreign to the manner of speech here. So just as
column37: if I really did happen to be a foreigner
column38: you would surely sympathize with me if I spoke in the dialect and way in which I was raised
column39: so also I do beg of you now (and it is just
column40: at least
column41: as it seems to me): leave aside the manner of my speech--for perhaps it may be worse
column42: but perhaps better--and instead consider this very thing and apply your mind to this: whether the things I say are just or not. For this is the virtue of a judge
column43: while that of an orator is to speak the truth."  "Speaking...with the same speeches I am accustomed to speak"? How utterly inept and repetitive! Didn't he even proof-read? One doesn't speak with 'speeches'
column44: one speaks with words!  It is obvious that Dr. West never read his version aloud as a test of its appropriateness
column45: which is surprising
column46: because this work is supposed to be a speech. Dr. West's version is clearly not suited to speaking aloud
column47: whereas Jowett's is. In West's translation
column48: Socrates is a clumsy
column49: repetitive
column50: and inept speaker. Needlessly so. If you want to read a good translation
column51: see Jowett's 3rd edition (1892).  Why does Dr. West believe himself qualified to make translations? Nothing in his work suggests that he is competent in any way to do so. This is not the work of a scholar
column52: but that of a bungling hack. These translations are travesties. How does work this nauseatingly bad get published?  NOT RECOMMENDE

column1: This is a film about two soldiers captured during the Chechen war.  Normally the Chechen rebels don't take prisoners but one of the men is hoping to trade the soldiers for his son who is being held by the Russians.  As time passes the younger of the two soldiers
column2: Ivan
column3: begins to feel for the rebels and to wish he could live among them.  The soldiers are told to write to their families and have them ask the commander to trade them for the rebel's son.  Ivan's mother tries but ultimately fails in her attempt.  Eventually the rebels get tired to waiting and kill the older soldier.  Ivan gets free and runs for the hills ending the movie with his escape

column1: The mere act of arguing that comic art qualifies as "fine art" somehow legitimizes such nonproductive and ultimately meaningless distinctions. Yet this catalogue's obvious purpose is to somehow elevate
column2: by force of such argument
column3: the reputations of comic strip and comic book artists. As the early twentieth century cultural critic
column4: Gilbert Seldes
column5: stated in his review of George Herriman's Krazy Kat:  	Krazy Kat
column6: the daily comic strip of George Herriman is
column7: to me
column8: the most amusing and fantastic and satisfactory 	work of art produced in America today.  With those who 	hold that a comic strip cannot be a work of art
column9: I shall 	not traffic.   Not only is it unlikely that this book of self-promoting essays
column10: largely written by comic artists
column11: will advance the position of comic art within the insular and rarified world of contemporary art criticism
column12: the book does not even go far enough to promote the appreciation of the genre among those readers/viewers with a genuine interest in the art form.   The presentation of comic strip art is certainly worthy of attention
column13: despite the glaring exclusion of any significant discussion of the two giants of adventure strip art
column14: Alex Raymond and Hal Foster. But the quality of the strip art which is included speaks so loudly that the written commentary can be largely ignored in evaluating the artistic merits.  Ironically
column15: the authors' verbose analyses of modern comic book art will probably fall on more sympathetic ears
column16: despite the fact that  most of the artists chosen as representative of American comic book art would not even be considered by most comic book aficionados as top contenders for inclusion in a comic art exhibition.  But
column17: then again
column18: that is probably why these "graphic novel" and underground comic book artists were selected -- they produce the type of art that is most likely to appeal to the gimmick sensibility of contemporary art critics.  When judged by more traditional (some would say old-fashion) standards of artistic excellence
column19: such as quality of draftsmanship and composition
column20: it is hard to see how most of these artists have produced even good art
column21: let alone "fine art."  But
column22: perhaps like the child who could not see the emperor's new clothes
column23: some viewers just are not sophisticated enough to fully understand or appreciate fine contemporary comic book art.  If you fall into this category
column24: then this is the perfect book for you.  CRAIG W.  ENGLUND

column1: Nothing wrong with this version of Powers' stories
column2: but I prefer the original

column5: perhaps the most exciting short-story writer to emerge since Eudora Welty."  -- Philadelphia Inquirer.    The Doubleday Image Books imprint set about "making the world's finest Catholic literature avilable to all..."  True
column6: Mr. Powers' work is formed by his Catholicism
column7: but in subject matter
column8: he writes about baseball and jazz
column9: old people and boys
column10: boxers and more.  He has
column11: The New Yorker once observed
column12:
few rivals at creating characters with more than superficial reality. 
 As Strunk and White advise in the classic guide to writing, _The Elements of Style_, Do not overstate. When you overstate
column13: readers will be instantly on guard
column14: and everything that has preceded your overstatement as well as everything that follows it will be suspect in their minds because they have lost confidence in your judgment or your poise."  I wanted to like this book
column15: because I find Genghis Khan and his empire to be fascinating
column16: and yet the author so completely overstates the significance of the Mongols that he loses all credibility
column17: and pollutes an otherwise highly readable and interesting set of facts with so much fiction that it is often difficult to distinguish the two. For example
column18: he claims in the introduction that the Mongols had founded the first unified nations of Korea and China
column19: apparently ignorant of the fact that Korea had been unified since AD 668
column20: and that China was first unified by the Qin dynasty in 221 BC. Similarly
column21: he states on p. 237 that "[the Renaissance] was not the ancient world of Greece and Rome being reborn: It was the Mongol Empire
column22: picked up
column23: transferred
column24: and adapted by the Europeans to their own needs and culture." Although the evidence for Greek and Roman influence on the Renaissance is overwhelming
column25: the evidence for Mongol influence is flimsy at best. The more outsized the claim
column26: the less evidence the author seems to provide.   Furthermore
column27: he tries to give the Mongols credit for inspiring Renaissance art
column28: which he calls a hybrid of Eastern and Western styles; he gives the Mongols credit for disseminating Arabic and Indian mathematics (the Arabs themselves had disseminated Indian mathematics throughout the civilized world
column29: long before the Mongols); he gives the Mongols credit for introducing the compass to the West (the compass was mentioned in Alexander Neckham's De Naturis Rerum
column30: written in 1190
column31: before Genghis Khan had even ventured out of Mongolia); and he gives the Mongols credit for inventing the Silk Road
column32: which had already existed for thousands of years.   What the book desperately needs are a fact-checker and responsible editor to curb the author's literary excesses. The author clearly sympathizes with the Mongols and wants to promote their case as responsible bearers of civilization. His biases are so blinding
column33: that he frequently makes irrelevant comparisons to the worst excesses of the Catholic Inquisition to try to justify the mass slaughter of the Mongols
column34: and even tries to deny the scale of Mongol genocides altogether
column35: lamely asserting (p. 118)
column36: "It would be physically difficult to slaughter that many cows or pigs
column37: which wait passively for their turn. Overall
column38: those who were supposedly slaughtered outnumber the Mongols by ratios of up to fifty to one. The people could have merely run away
column39: and the Mongols would not have been able to stop them." The gigantic flaw in logic is that the Mongols never faced odds of 50-to-1 at any one moment
column40: but rather wiped out city after city in a process that took many years. His claim the the people could "have merely run away" is laughable
column41: given his constant reminders that the Mongol cavalry were the fastest and most efficient army of the day. He could just as easily have applied the same ludicrous argument to any other historical genocide in order to deny their scale and seriousness.  I still like the subject of Genghis Khan
column42: and Weatherford has whetted my appetite: I may eventually pick up one of the other
column43: more serious and scholarly books on the topic. However
column44: I will never again make the mistake of reading anything written by Mr. Weatherford.

column1: It appears that the thesis of this book is that logical organization and structure in the laws of physics only goes so far down
column2: that you reach a certain level where the nature of reality is intrinsically opaque and that even in principle there can be no further explanations
column3: that things just are the way they are.  Further
column4: at this level of opacity
column5: the "givens" are very messy and arbitrary: there is no elegance
column6: simplicity
column7: and beauty
column8: the heretofore goals of scientific theories. Instead
column9: at bottom the universe we live in is a Rube Goldberg concoction of surpassing inelegance.  At this point
column10: the author
column11: Leonard Susskind
column12: says there are two possibilities:  1. There is only one universe
column13: the one we live in. In that case
column14: these messy
column15: seemingly arbitrary laws and constants of the universe must be deliberately designed to allow the development of intelligent creatures like us human beings. This follows the so-called "strong" anthropic principle: our very existence proves there is an Intelligence Designer behind all of existence.  2. There are unending possibilities in the laws and constants of nature and our universe is just one possibility. There is a "megaverse" that continuously spawns "pocket universes
column16: each of which has a random set of laws and constants, and our universe is just one of these countless numbers.   How can we make a purely scientific decision between these two views? Until recently, a lot of physicists hoped that String Theory would be found to support the first scenario: there would be a single solution to the equations that would produce the particular laws and constants we find in our universe. This seemingly arbitrary and messy collection of too many constants and laws would actually flow from a tiny set of first principles that would appear to be inevitable. This would also get around the need" for an Intelligent Designer. The universe would be the way it is because it has to be that way.  But
column17: alas
column18: the most recent developments of String Theory seem to be pushing in the opposite direction: String Theory seems to allow for an unimaginably large set of possible sets of laws and constants: ten to the five-hundredth power in fact! Among all those possibilities
column19: one or more like our own universe would arise purely by chance
column20: and once again there wouldn't be anything mysterious or supernatural about our existence.  Thus
column21: Susskind triumphantly disposes of the need of a supernatural basis for existence no matter what
column22: and if this book has any focus at all this conclusion seems to be it.  The attitude that is convinced by this kind of reasoning is called scientific materialism. It is commonly used in popular science books by atheistic authors. Now there is nothing wrong with trying to explain phenomena "all the way down
column23: without bringing supernatural causes and miracles" into the picture. That's what the business of science is
column24: and we should always be suspect when the miraculous is used to fill in "gaps" that science is unable (at the moment) to fill (most often these reputed gaps are merely wishful thinking on the part of religious fundamentalists anyhow
column25: especially when it comes to "disbelief" in evolution). But to conclude that there is no transcendent ground to existence just because we have scientific explanations for something "all the way down" is overstepping the bounds of science proper into scientific materialism
column26: and that is the fatal flaw of this book and is a major reason for me downgrading it to two stars.  Just because a God may not be self-consciously involved in the selection of the most fundamental laws of nature in our pocket universe doesn't mean that it doesn't take the infinite depths of a God behind everything to provide "room" in the potentialities of existence for life as we know it to arise. The very fact that it is possible for something like the human mind to arise from the apparently "dead" material of existence speaks to a transcendent nature that is behind it all.  This is the point that everyone seems to miss who preaches like Susskind that because at bottom it is only a matter of chance that our universe has the laws that it has
column27: there is no "need" for God. The very fact that human experience is possible
column28: even with our laws at bottom the result of sheer chance among 10**500 other possibilities
column29: this very fact requires there to be an infinite Presence that some like to call God. It is God's bottomless nature that allows such highly improbable universes as ours to come into existence in the first place. God doesn't need to bring any universes into existence consciously; he does it by his very nature
column30: and most of them pop in an out of existence without God even being consciously aware of them: it's just something God does without having to think about it. But without this infinite nature
column31: none of us would ever appear in any highly improbable
column32: anthropic universe
column33: because the potential would not be there.   Maybe a conscious God is not needed to produce bacteria. Maybe a conscious God is not needed to produce 10**500 universes for every one like ours. But God is a prerequisite for universes like ours even to appear. The miracle is that there is "room" for a universe like ours to exist. God doesn't need to concern himself with the overwhelming preponderance of abortive pocket universes that pop in and out of existence. The spark of his consciousness needs only to spring alive when a universe like ours happens along by sheer chance. Then he can take an interest and start persuading consciousness when it begins to arise to flow in certain directions
column34: towards his own unlimited possibilities in depth and beauty. God then acts like a lure
column35: drawing consciousness into his own explosive depths
column36: and who knows how far evolution can then proceed
column37: once the conscious God takes hold of it.  In presenting this "theistic" view of reality
column38: I'm really doing no more than the same sort of thing that Susskind is doing
column39: and that's the flaw of this book. I'm not presenting science
column40: but Susskind is using the name of science to present an atheistic view contrary to theistic views that irritate him. All I'm saying is that his atheistic views are easily countered by alternative theistic views. In either case
column41: those views are only going to be persuasive to those with corresponding spiritual experiences of the world. As for the science that Susskind does describe in his book
column42: as has been pointed out by other reviewers
column43: it has been far better explained by other authors such as Brian Greene. I was frankly bored silly by the last half of Susskind's book
column44: whereas Brian Greene is fascinating throughout.

Bill O'Reilly is not "right wing" or Republican but rather a grandstanding populist.  John Stossel is not "right wing" or Republican but rather a libertarian.  Brock can't even give them the dignity of using an insulting term that actually describes who they are.  The left simply loses credibility and strips "right wing" of any discerable meaning when they brand everyone from George W. column1: Based on the novel The Big Arm by Clark Howard with a screenplay by Robert Roy Pool
column2: this drama directed by Ben Bolt feels like an adaptation of a large canvas novel with all the detail left in
column3: so that everything reads as subsidiary. Set in the Chicago of the 1950's
column4: Matt Dillon stars as a dice player from Indiana seeking the big time. However
column5: when you're juggling at least 4 plots it's only natural that not all of them will come together for a satisfying conclusion. The most promising one concerns Dillon's Hustler-like competition with Tommy Lee Jones as the owner of a strip club
column6: with Jones having the same spot between the eyebrows as Dillon. The problem with filming dice is that the actual game is monotonous
column7: so the best Bolt could do is create tension by delaying the next roll or the raising of financial stakes
column8: though he does provide an early montage of Dillon with David Marshall Grant on a winning spree and falling dice and money to the sounds of Shake
column9: Rattle and Roll on the soundtrack. The only other visual trick is the sparks of an overhead train on it's tracks as Dillon and Diane Lane as Jones' stripper wife kiss to Fever. The best of the screenplay is a laugh line of sarcasm and forboding given to Meg Hogarth as Dillon's mother re his dice mentor's funeral "I nearly got crushed in the crowd"
column10: and Cherry Jones as a Patsy Cline-like singer who sneaks up behind Dillon
column11: covering his eyes with a guess who? Dillon says her perfume gives her away and she replies " Aint nobody gonna give me away but my daddy". This use of eyes and the eyes of the dice are also parallel with Bruce Dern as the husband of Lee Grant
column12: Dillon's employer. Dern is a former dice champ who has been blinded
column13: but unfortunately this plot point gets no payoff. Dillon is also given two romantic partners in Lane and Suzy Amis as a mother of a child out of wedlock. The madonna/whore dichotomy is rather obvious
column14: and the symbolism worse
column15: with Amis' child scoring points for her and the way Lane is presented so unflatteringly scores points against her. Lane's fan dance doesn't help
column16: since the focus on the scen is more Dillon's twisted attraction/repulsion. The 1950's period works for Dillon's razor etched beauty
column17: the perfect locale for his photographer Bruce Weber appeal
column18: and he even gives a Method touch to the way he hits his own face with a restaurant menu. Watch for Lolita Davidovich as another of Jones' strip club entertainers

column1: This book is unapologetically about triviality. It begins with the rise of popularity of the trivial
column2: illusion and fakery
column3: in America since the time of P.T. Barnum. It is about the creators and consumers of illusion who  replaced 'survivors' in after the transition to life in the megalopolis in  America. John Berger has pointed out that zoos
column4: stuffed animals
column5: pets and  eventually Disneyworld emerged as mankind became divorced from the fight to  survive against nature
column6: where animals were essential. The book does not  explain why
column7: in its appetite for illusion and triviality (consumerism
column8: consumption of the media) America is so advanced with respect to Europe  (the decline is there
column9: if slower: the worst Hollywood films are extremely  popular among Europe's youth). Gamson informs us of Holmes' expectation  that photography would lead to the triumph of superficiality
column10: and of  Boorstin's description of the celebrity as a person who is well-known for  his well-knownness. Political campaigns are accurately described as  pre-packaged media affairs
column11: where the participants have become game-players  and the events themselves
column12: like talk-shows
column13: have become pseudo-events.  People immitating the media immitating people. The future is trivial  because trivial expectations determine the future via pre-packaged daily  behavior. Gamson does not explain why we have evolved to this state of  super-triviality
column14: and why we seem to be stuck with it. This was more or  less explained poetically by Spengler
column15: and also poetically in still fewer  words by John Berger
column16: who informs us clearly and concisely on the subjects  of Gamson's discourse: "It would ... be possible to talk of the  'homelessness' of the bourgeois with his town house
column17: his country home
column18: his  three cars
column19: his televisions
column20: his tennis court
column21: his wine cellar-it would be  just possible
column22: yet nothing about his class interests me
column23: for there is  nothing left to discover." Gamson's book is precisely about the  people
column24: and their admirors
column25: about whom there is nothing worth discovering

column1: I read this short novel because I greatly admired Shaara's Pulitzer Prize winning "Killer Angels
column2: and because I'm a baseball fan.  The novel feels more like an outline or first draft than a completed work about an aging pitcher.  It's a bit shallow and predictable in its plot.  The characters are what one expects in all too many sports novels and short stories.  The feel or atmosphere just isn't quite there.  Any baseball fan will see flaws in the book right away, flaws that distract and damage the work.  Shaara sets most of the novel in Yankee Stadium with the Hawks playing the Yankees.  Why the author chose to have one real team against a fictional team is unclear.  The Hawks apparently are from Atlanta, but an Atlanta team, Braves or Hawks, whichever, would not be playing the Yankees interleague on the next to last day of the season.  Finally, when a visiting pitcher goes out to warm up before the game, he does so in the semi-hidden bull pen down the left field line in Yankee Stadium--not on the mound on the field.  This book was published posthumously and Mr. Shaara perhaps never had a chance to polish his prose--prose that was excellent in Killer Angels."  It's unfortunate.  There are glimmers of interest in the book
column3: but not enough to recommend it to baseball fans or fans of the author's other book

I get: "In this respect [promotion] novelists are luckier than nonfiction writers. Not much is expected from them in the way of promotion.(page 87)" How much less? None? A little bit? column3: "Indian Turmeric"
column4: which is NOT the same as Turmeric the common spice.  Like many herbs

column6: so don't follow Lexa's advice to take it internally unless you are properly trained and/or medically supervised.  My suggestion to readers is to use this book for inspiration

column10: teas and the like are poisonous or carcinogenic.  Know what plants you are working with -- and how to do so safely -- from a reputable source before inhaling

column1: I received this book as a gift
column2: and found it unreadable. For example
column3: EFS says cost/benefit analysis "is a procedure by which the higher is reduced to the level of the lower and the priceless is given a price". This is meaningless rhetoric to me. It also assumes that only economics provides a guide to human behavior. Or that all economic analysis is totally rational. Schumacher questioned every assumption of "economic science" using theories from the anarchist tradition. Schumacher claimed neocolonialism is the result of politics
column4: not economic principles. But doesn't class and sectional interests drive politics? His advocacy of a search for inward spiritual space
column5: and a rejection of the real world of politics and economics
column6: makes this book part of the problem and not part of the solution.  The 'Introduction' says Gandhi wanted to use "labor-intensive manufacture and handicrafts" (p.5). Milovan Djilas said it was important for newly liberated countries to use mass production ("The New Class"). The historical record over the past centuries should tell you who was right or wrong. Liberating revolutions result in more production and other benefits for the people; else they're not liberating. Unlimited economic growth overlooks the availability of basic resources and the capacity of the environment. But there's always some natural problem that causes a correction.  This is a very verbose book whose arguments rest on unquestioned assumptions. Since it was published in 1973 Thatcher's regime destroyed Britain's coal industry to make them dependent on imported oil and gas. We've seen what happened after they divided and privatized the railroads. But who benefited from these political decisions?   Part II Chapter 3 notes that western Europe "deliberately destroyed nearly half of their coal industries". But the economy in neocolonialist countries will always suffer to benefit the imperialist ruling country. American was a net petroleum exporter until 1967
column7: and influenced Saudi Arabia and Iran (just like Great Britain did previously). You can also consider the actions of Jimmy Carter against nuclear reactors. France and Japan use nuclear power
column8: they have no oil. Saudi Arabia uses nuclear power so they can profitably sell their oil abroad. Those who criticized this book showed good judgment and wisdom. You can read this book and judge its worth for yourself.

column1: I have always wondered about Professor Chomsky's writings. He has always been described as mean-spirited and anti-American by the right. I finally got an opportunity to read his book Hegemony or Survival. I was surprised at how readable it was; I expected it to be overly verbose. I was also surprised that I actually agreed with some of what he had to say
column2: particularly about Iraq. He certainly is correct that the US led invasion of Iraq was a fantastic opportunity for Bin Ladin to stir up anti-US sentiment and attract members to his terrorist organization. I don't think you have to be a professor to see that though. Although some have charged Chomsky with being sympathetic to terrorists
column3: I failed to see this. He condemns terrorism but accuses the US of creating an atmosphere that is conducive to the growth of terrorist organizations.  He argues here that US foreign policy victimizes every country it interferes with. The US consistently brutally punishes any country whose actions are contrary to its agenda
column4: even if that country is just trying to better itself. Without a doubt
column5: the US has made some disastrous foreign policy decisions but I don't think Washington is as evil as Chomsky wants the reader to believe.   We Americans like to believe that the US is always the good guy riding in to save the day. Sadly
column6: all too often US intervention harms the very people we believe to be helping. Having said that
column7: the US is not the evil monster that Chomsky portrays it either. He asserts that the US has only one goal and that is global dominance and it is all done under the guise of fighting terrorism or fighting communism. Too often he appears to use fuzzy logic or cherry picks events so that he can apply this contention to various skirmishes the US has been involved in.   On page 9 he states "In one country
column8: Nicaragua
column9: Washington had lost control of the armed forces that had traditionally subdued the region's population" "The us-backed Somoza dictatorship was overthrown by the Sandinista rebels
column10: and the murderous national guard was dismantled. Therefore Nicaragua had to be subjected campaign of international terrorism that left the country in ruins" "The spirit of exuberance
column11: vitality
column12: and optimism that followed the overthrow of the dictatorship could not long survive as the reigning superpower intended to dash the hopes that a grim history might finally take a different course"   What Chomsky chooses to ignore is that after the Sandinistas overthrew Somoza with the full support of the US government
column13: US then made initial efforts to establish peaceful relations with the Sandinistas. Congress authorized 75 million dollars in aid and offered to send doctors
column14: nurses and teachers to help stabilize the new government. The Sandinistas got into trouble not by ousting Somoza as Chomsky wishes the reader to believe
column15: but by supporting the Marxist guerrillas in El Salvador. The US cut off aid and gave repeated warnings to stop providing support to the communist rebels. In 1981 the US even sent Thomas Enders to try to end the tension. He offered them a sweet deal
column16: the US would completely leave them alone to do as they please if they would just stay out of the conflict in El Salvador. They refused. This is was the beginning of the end for the Sandinistas.   I don't understand why Chomsky implies that Nicaragua was on the course to some utopia either. The Sandinistas promised their supporters free elections but refused once in power. They consistently denied Nicaraguans the freedoms they had promised
column17: newspapers were censored
column18: religions suppressed. Some ethnic groups were terrorized and their villages destroyed. The only reason that I can think of that Chomsky would paint such a distorted view of the Sandinistas is so that he can lead the reader to a false conclusion.  Later Chomsky implies that the US ruined the healthy economy of Nicaragua. Any economic growth that the Nicaraguans experienced was due to the US because of the said aid and the efforts of the US to have their World Bank debts forgiven.  Chomsky wants the reader to believe that US conflicts are never about communism or terrorism
column19: that its just a ruse. He's wrong
column20: nicaragua is just one example of where he got it wrong.  I also wonder about his comments concerning Cuba appealing to the UN for help. Chomsky states that Cuba didn't respond to the US with violent attacks within the US
column21: rather they followed the procedure required by international law. Chomsky appears to be implying that the noble Cubans were above the primitive barbarity of the US. Obviously they didn't attack the US because they did not have the means to launch a formidable attack. Keep in mind that after the Cuban missile crisis
column22: Che Guevara
column23: one of the most influential leaders in the Castro Regime was furious. He was angered that the Soviets were weak and pulled the missiles out and proudly announced that he would have launched them all given the opportunity.  Chomsky's claims that Cuba's economic woes are purely a product of the US embargo seem to be a bit of a stretch. Did the embargo negatively impact Cuba? Of course. So much so that their island is the now the equivalent of tropical slum despite the fact that every other country in the free world will trade with them and they get billions of dollars in aid? I fail to see how.  I am troubled at his comparison of the 911 attacks and Clinton Admins attack on the pharmaceutical company in Sudan. Why didn't Chomsky mention that it was in response to attacks on US embassies in Kenya and Tanzania? Why didn't Chomsky mention that we believed it to be a chemical weapons plant? Why didn't Chomsky mention that the US released 24 million dollars to the businessman whose factory we wrongfully attacked?  I have numerous other concerns about the authors claims but I've reached my word limit here at amazon.  Cheer

This book takes the position that increasing technological infrastructure and investing in higher information technology does not increase productivity. The argument is complete hokum from beginning to end; however
column2: it is very convincing due to the large amount of evidence presented and the prestige of the pseudoscientist promulgating it.   Most of the evidence presented exemplifies the post hoc ergo propter hoc fallacy
column3: which should be obvious to any logician or scientist reading it. However
column4: several more subtle fallacies are also present. The subtlety comes in by virtue of the author failing to define `productivity.'  First
column5: the author measures productivity using GDP. This is analogous to using the physics definition of work when you ask a man who's spent all day trying to tip over a mountain
column6: "Why are you so tired? The mountain hasn't moved
column7: therefore you haven't done any work!" GDP is a measure of output in terms of dollars. It does not measure work done
column8: just how much was sold.   Second
column9: the author uses return on assets to analyze investments in new equipment. Now
column10: I'm no expert in finance
column11: but since assets is in the denominator
column12: using ROA in the way this author does (the ROA of the firm
column13: not the investment decision) would systematically understate the positive effects of these investments. Net Present Value or Internal Rate of Return would both be much better measures.  Third
column14: and this is related to the second point
column15: the author compares firms to what they were in the past (before investing in technology) or to other
column16: dissimilar firms. The relevant comparison is between a firm's current profitability and what the current profitability would have been if not for the investment. The common form of this reasoning is: XYZ Corp. made a huge technological investment in 1986
column17: and experienced no rise in productivity (as measured by ROA). This ignores the possibility that the whole industry became more competitive
column18: and failing to invest in the technology could have led to bankruptcy.   In a related issue
column19: he completely ignores rising standards. His argument is equivalent to
column20: Finding Nemo did not make significantly more money than The Lion King. Therefore
column21: enhanced technology did not increase productivity. This is incorrect because productivity is a measure of work done over time
column22: not money made. If animators tried to make a film with the graphics quality of Finding Nemo by hand
column23: it would have taken several orders of magnitude longer
column24: if it was even possible! The fact is
column25: the animators
column26: like so many workers in society
column27: get far more done today than they used to
column28: they just don't get paid anymore to do it
column29: which is actually an argument for the value of technology.  I gave up on it shortly thereafter

column1: While I cannot say that I didn't like "Kingdom Come
column2: it certainly left me wanting, which was unfortunate since this is the grand conclusion of the Left Behind series. Overall this was by no means a poorly written book as I truly enjoy Jenkins' style of writing and his use of imagery in not just the LB series, but also the Soon" and "Jesus Chronicles" series. But I didn't care for the novel's progression and several series of events that took place. The book begins well
column3: with our usual crew about to enter the Millennial Kingdom and the theological explanations by Tsion Ben-Judah on what to expect as far as the early deaths of non-believers
column4: everyone's new eating habits
column5: the constant brightness
column6: animals of all kind living in peace with people
column7: and of course the physical presence of Jesus on his throne in Jerusalem were very helpful in setting the tone. We see Rayford
column8: Irene
column9: Tsion and co. assigned to various ministries throughout the world and Buck and Chloe have founded a millennial day care called Children of the Tribulation (COT). In addition
column10: Jesus has cleaned up the whole earth after the horrors of the tribulation and has set up his new temple in Jerusalem where he will rule forever. After establishing these initial key elements
column11: the book jumps to 93 years into the Millennial Kingdom
column12: where we learn about the formation of The Other Light (TOL)
column13: which is a Lucifer-worshipping cult whose followers hope to overthrow Christ in the final battle. After quickly reaching year 93
column14: I thought the story would keep moving quickly throughout the Millennium in order to spend a good amount of time on the final battle between Satan and Jesus. However
column15: the next 300 pages or so covered only years 93-97 in the Kingdom
column16: which I found extremely tedious. At one point
column17: we see Rayford requesting to King David that some major biblical characters come and speak at COT
column18: which he obliges. When Noah visits and tells his story
column19: I found it to be a nice filler
column20: but nothing really special. But the fact that later on
column21: Joshua and Caleb and then later David himself each come and share their stories in excruciating detail (when one can just pick up a Bible and read the same things) was pretty disappointing and way too page consuming when other storylines could have been pursued. One aspect that I truly did enjoy was that Buck & Chloe's son
column22: Kenny Williams was the unofficial main character of this book at the tender age of 97. The formation of the Millennium Force was a bit cheesy
column23: yet nostalgic to faithful LB readers who journeyed along with the original Tribulation Force. And Kenny and Ekaterina's romance was well done and makes you feel like a grandparent after having read the Buck & Chloe saga from early in the series. A big conflicting issue for me was when TOL infiltrator Qasim planted false evidence implicating Kenny as an unbeliever and a mole at COT. Kenny then loses his girlfriend and his Uncle Raymie (who has a glorified body and mind for crying out loud) initially turns on him as do several others. Kenny agonizes and feels totally alone and ostracized
column24: which I find pretty jacked up considering this is a time of global peace and tranquility. It shouldn't have been hard for Kenny to prove his loyalty to Christ
column25: especially with Jesus physically present right in his home town. Somehow I'd like to think Jesus wouldn't be some unaccessable VIP
column26: sitting in his temple all alone
column27: which is pretty much how he was portrayed in this book. Believers prayed to him
column28: but even then
column29: they didn't know if they were receiving his answers or making up their own. Why couldn't Kenny have said
column30: "You don't believe me? Let's go see Jesus and he'll tell you I belong to him!" I'd like to think that Jesus would never have a problem with his own children coming to him for counsel
column31: especially now that he was physically present with them. Also
column32: throughtout the series
column33: believers had seals of the cross spiritually placed by God on their foreheads identifying them as followers of Christ - why were they now absent?? A redeeming storyline was Abdullah's ministry to the TOL
column34: which showed a really gracious picture of how we are to love our enemies. But throughout it
column35: he seemed to keep second guessing himself
column36: wondering if he was really supposed to be there. And again I wondered
column37: why didn't he simply go and meet with Jesus and ASK him?? column40: we find Kenny exonerated

column1: In all my years of reading books this is the first time that I have felt compelled to destroy a book once I have read it to avoid inflicting the torment of its pages upon another family member or friend.  This is one of those book that at every page turn you expect the book to come alive and at the end you question why anyone would have spent so long on a piece of work in which nothing actually happens. Then you question your own sanity for persevering for so long.  I have never read another Martin Amis book but still urge everyone to read 'Lucky Jim' written by the clearly more gifted father of Martin Amis.

column1: The REA CLEP History of the US I study guide is in need of improvement and/or revision!   The format of the book and the accompanying CD-ROM is very usable...but the problem is that the information in it has little to nothing to do with the real exam that was taken yesterday.  The actual exam results were 20 points less than I scored on each of the 3 practice exams in the book.   These practice exams and explanations gave a false sense of readiness.   I wish I would have used the actual study materials from the College-Level Examination Program (CLEP).   When I called REA about the difference between the study guide's practice exams and the actual exam....they said I should write a review online?  So
column2: I am alerting people to use other study materials than this REA study guide (published in 2006).  It resulted in wasted time and money for me

column1: The liberation of Paris was a coup de grace for the Allies.  Paris did not suffer the fate of Berlin or Stalingrad
column2: to name a few cities
column3: in becoming a contested battleground.  Nor
column4: as the book pointed out
column5: did the German commander follow Hitler's orders to destroy the city's major monuments
column6: bridges
column7: and other sites.  It is interesting to note his actions in view of other German officers' claims that they were "only following orders".  However
column8: this book is written by two journalists rather than historians
column9: so it does not have the academic research nor analytical insight that a serious work might have.  Cornelius Ryan comes closer to the style of writing that might have made this a heavier book.  This is understandably difficult
column10: in some ways
column11: given the relative sparcity of combat and drama; or so this book would suggest.  Again
column12: a better writer and researcher would find more material to include.  Some material that might be considered
column13: for example
column14: are Allied intelligence estimates
column15: Axis intelligence estimates
column16: operational orders
column17: etc.  It is not clear to me
column18: for example
column19: how the German commander could fail to execute Hitler's orders in August 1944 when the Gestapo and SS were omni-present
column20: especially after the failed July plot on Hitler's life.  Moreover
column21: good research might show to what extent the Allies knew of Hitler's intentions.  The Allies had significant intelligence capabilities
column22: not the least through Ultra.  And if they knew of the plans to destroy large parts of Paris
column23: why didn't they send in commandos and special forces to disarm any explosives?  Indeed
column24: the French themselves seemed to put a higher priority on erecting road blocks rather than disarming explosives.  This is an easy
column25: enjoyable read; and one of the few on the subject in English.  However
column26: it's about time someone else updated and added value to this book

column1: Looking for a bit of sea adventure?  Fancy a run with some real life salts who face whatever the hurricane ravaged winter seas throw at them?  Well don't go looking to Redmond O'Hanlon's "Trawler".  O'Hanlon takes two potentially fascinating subjects - trawler fishing and the biology behind the creatures of the seas - and blends them into a putrid stew of nothingness.  This is a very difficult book to read. Physically difficult! Aye!  O'Hanlon's pointless
column2: manic use of exclamation and emphasis - EMPHASIS! Aye! - lends nothing to the story but then there is so little story
column3: it's really no loss.  "Trawler" dredges the bottom of literary technique and hauls up nothing but stream of consciousness drivel.  I found the book a total waste of time and will certainly never read another piece of work by O'Hanlon.  Aye!  I won't!  Never!

column1: I have read a few things by Lattimore
column2: and while he is touted as the most accurate translator of Greek literature
column3: I find him increadibly difficult to read. His sentences sometimes make no sense at all.  English is a language that depends upon syntax and the order of words in a sentence; Greek is not this way
column4: it is a language with myriad declensions and conjugations
column5: effectively allowing its poets to manipulate a sentence's word order.  Lattimore may simply be too accurate to the Greek originals
column6: because the word order--translated so precisely--simply does not fit well in the English. I recommend Fagles
column7: who is an amazing translator; and while he is accurate
column8: he also understands the limitations of translating the Greek to English. His sentences are fluid and capture the life of the translation. For Aeschylus
column9: I also recommend Philip Vellacott. Check out Fagles
column10: then check out Vellacott. But please forego the Lattimore translations
column11: unless you really want to understand just the sort of impact a bad translation can have.

column1: It's quite amazing to how much length monopolists of all kinds will go to defend their position
column2: even after they've been proven utterly wrong!  The horrible
column3: stupid and disasterous consequences of government interference in market processes should not require further demonstration
column4: but here we go: yet another idiot who tries to prove that "markets are wrong".  Kuttner doesn't get it: markets are OUTCOMES of incredibly large number of choices millions of people make. To say that some outcomes (momentary snapshots of ongoing
column5: complex processes) is not "perfect" or "desirable"
column6: he argues from HIS personal perspective. Maybe indeed HE would have liked to allocate ressources differently
column7: but it is the outcome of billions of individual decisions.  The implicite assumption by Kuttner is that some "central agency" would know better. WRONG! As history teaches
column8: any attempt at centralizing decision making FAIL
column9: precisely because of limited knowlege and the complexity of any real problem.  Let's take the example discussed elsewhere on this forum: airline deregulation. Apparently
column10: there are many "negative consequences" and somehow
column11: Kuttner doesn't like the current system very much. Well
column12: that's HIS take. I assume he always was rich enough to pay excessively high air fares
column13: contrary to the majority of people
column14: who can only afford flights since the industry has been deregulated.  Some companies fail. SO WHAT? That's part of the market process!!! Some companies provide bad seats
column15: lousy service and have a slightly higher accident risk. SO WHAT? That's the point about a market: you are allowed to choose a really cheap
column16: crappy solution. You're not FORCED to spend huge amounts of money
column17: when all you want is to get cheaply from point A to point B! If you are WILLING to pay more - up to the ridiculous price levels from before deregulation
column18: then you probably get a very high level of quality and service.  As usual
column19: Kuttner simply forgets about the fact that lousy quality is often the only way of making certain goods and services available to the not-yet-wealthy. Our grand-parents had to put up with things of incredibly shabby quality
column20: as compared to what we have now. No one served up high quality on a silver platter at low cost.  Worst of all is that a HUGE number of examples of "bad markets" actually are due to "bad regulations"
column21: but it takes brains to spot the unintended consequences of regulations
column22: if all you ever read is the declaration of intent of any law.

column1: Before you read the book
column2: look at the sources.  I only found one scientific paper out of hundreds of sources. Everything else has to be classified as opinions.  Sources for this book  include news stories and testimonies in congress.  I will point out by two examples (not from the book
column3: but from information that you are probably familiar with) why these are not good sources. I recall the news stories based on the opinions of experts that said it would take five years to put out the oil well fires started in the first Gulf War.  They were all wrong.  It took six months.  CEO's and others testified before congress about tobacco products being non-addictive.  Were they correct? No! So when we read this book
column4: we can't be sure of anything.  It is a book of opinions and ideas.  Some of them may be good
column5: but they may also be bad.  This is why we have science and the scientific method.  Even science may be corrupted at times or fail until we have a better understanding. Even if Mr. Gore had scientific papers
column6: it is unlikely that he could judge whether they really support his environmental views.  He would need a Ph.D. or at least a lot of experience in the proper field(s) to interpret scientific papers properly.  This book discusses how corporations are unfriendly to the environment. Surely some of them are.  But so is the government.  When the government plant at Fernald
column7: Ohio
column8: (near Cincinnati) was accused of poluting the soil and water with radioactive waste
column9: the government denied
column10: dragged its feet
column11: and fought in court. The government lost it case because there was obvious guilt
column12: but the government did not hestitate to fight against the very people it represents. When you or I appear to be at fault in an auto accident
column13: do we admit it and offer to pay all claims
column14: or do we take a less candid approach as our insurance company suggests?  We might even think we are not at fault. Mr. Gore has denied being at fault countless times in his political career
column15: but he can't believe that a corporation should do anything but admit guilt
column16: accept every environmental claim that is made
column17: and pay large sums of money.  Mr. Gore is an elitist.  First
column18: he believes that he is an environmental expert because he has heard a lot of opinions. He doesn't need an advanced degree in environmental science  or experience in that field.  He just knows better because he is Al Gore. Secondly
column19: he sees how he uses the environment and how you should use the environment quite differently.  When he was Vice President
column20: he flew to Kyoto
column21: Japan
column22: to symbolically (read unnecessary trip) approve the Kyoto Treaty.  He used more than 180
column23: 000 gallons of fuel in a private government plane in one day.  My wife and I can drive our cars and heat our house for our lifetimes and never use this amount of fuel.  During his Presidental campaign
column24: Mr. Gore would fly a private jet to his son's games.  I have no great objection to the former Vice President doing these things as long as he doesn't start telling me how I am abusing the environment
column25: that I should drive an electric car
column26: ...  I do have trouble believing his environmental views are anything but political.  If you like the views in the book
column27: read it and feel good.  If you don't like the views
column28: read it for some good laughs.  There are plenty of flaws.  Books like this make money
column29: but they don't make good science
column30: and they don't produce good policy.  Don't forget to recycle the book

column1: Sontag represents a certain type of "intellectual" who is - thankfully - becoming increasingly rare in the world of google and broadband. As exemplified by Descartes (I think
column2: therefore I am)
column3: this is the school of people who think that truth can be discovered solely through rumination - without doing any research
column4: without experimentation
column5: without any investigation of the world outside of your skull. It is pure subjectivity - gloriously self-referential and egotistic
column6: completely self-contained and titannically self-satisfied. What Sontag's writings are about are Sontag - not the world as it is (and which can easily be fact checked) but the world as seen through the coke bottle lens of Sontag's ego and self. Sontag would hate the comparison but she is the leftist equivalent of the medieval christian mystic - the world outside of her own mind doesn't matter and facts have no weight. This is what enabled her - in one of the most egregious public acts of heartlessness in the last one hundred years - to praise the 9/11 terrorists for bravery while the World Trade Center was still smoldering and bodies were still being dragged from the debris. This was like praising the Nazi concentration camp managers for efficiency and thoroughness. Having distanced herself from humanity and decency with her warped and unbalanced intellect
column7: the stunned response to her statements probably bewildered her completely. No matter as her crazed statements had plenty of precedents in her previous writings. She took the very cheap
column8: easy
column9: and elitist high road of condemning every wrong in the world - without ever offering any solutions and always
column10: always
column11: condemning the USA for actually trying to do something about these problems rather than just word process away safely in her study surrounded by the works of Verlaine
column12: Rimbaud
column13: and Genet.  In Photography
column14: Sontag is at the Acme of her (witch) craft. She thinks (and enough critics seemed to have agreed with her) that a well written sentence implies veracity as if the good sentence was a litmus test for truth; as if grammar and a good thesaurus conferred reliability
column15: sanity
column16: or common sense. It doesn't. She'll be forgotten. I think she would have appreciated that - joining the obscure writers that few people read
column17: enjoyed
column18: or valued. She was too elitist to have enjoyed it very much if she actually was embraced by the masses

column1: This book is an opinionated overview of some scientific literature relating to human behavior
column2: intermixed with a conservative political agenda and some light-hearted humor.  The book is divided into 4 sections: "In the Beginning" (a scientific history of the world
column3: from the Big Bang to the evolution of humans)
column4: "The Rise of Humanity" (hormones and human behavior)
column5: "The World Today" (discussion of recent social changes)
column6: and "A Look Ahead" (possible futures).  End material includes a short annotated list of books for further reading (8 books plus a list of interesting authors)
column7: and an index.  There are no footnotes
column8: endnotes
column9: or other forms of citation of source materials.  I found the best part of the book to be the second section
column10: in which Gilbert summarizes much research regarding innate human behavior relating to gender
column11: romantic pairing
column12: work
column13: and child raising.  While I found little of this information new
column14: Gilbert does an admirable job of presenting it in non-technical language for general readers.  Unfortunately
column15: his complete avoidance of citation makes it impossible to check the accuracy or reliability of his points.  He also tends to overlook facts that would not be supportive of his general thesis that women should be pregnant and raising babies while men are out gathering resources for the family.  For example
column16: after summarizing various statistics about how pregnancy and childbirth reduce risk factors for certain cancers
column17: he states "Early pregnancy
column18: multiple pregnancies
column19: and breastfeeding are simply healthy. Childbirth carries risk
column20: of course
column21: but so does crossing the street or taking an aspirin. Not giving birth seems riskier still." Phew!  I guess he's never heard of the term "maternal mortality."  One of the main claims of the book is that boys and men are being done a disservice by a politically correct agenda which seeks to make the educational and work environments unisex.  As support
column22: Gilbert calls on studies that found children learn better in gender-segregated schools
column23: but suggests that such gender-segregation should be abandoned by the college years "when the maturing sexes really do belong together." (Why stop gender segregation after high school?  The research that supports gender segregated education certainly doesn't show that the advantages of gender segregation are not also found in college-aged students as well.)  He rails against Title IX legislation
column24: which required educational institutions that provide sports programs to provide equal opportunities for men and women athletes
column25: since he feels that by nature
column26: men have stronger physical and mental needs to participate in competitive sports.  (While he supports his arguments against Title IX with examples of perhaps absurd situations in which popular men's programs have been cut so that women's sports with sparse participation could be funded
column27: he entirely overlooks the fact that before Title IX
column28: athletic women had an almost impossible battle to be able to find any playing field to compete on at many schools).  In Gilbert's view
column29: the world would be a better place if women would stick to child-raising and house-keeping
column30: and leave the workplace free for men to live out their genetically determined hunter/gatherer/impregnator behaviors.  He cites hundreds of societal ills
column31: from declining test scores to the widening gap between rich and poor
column32: implicitly suggesting that they all go back to feminism and the re-gendering of society.  In his argument that gender-linked human behaviors are innate and should determine societal structure
column33: Gilbert overlooks normal genetic variation.  While on average
column34: men are taller than women
column35: there are millions of individual women who are taller than millions of individual men.  Likewise
column36: there are no doubt millions of individual women whose competitive urges outpace those of individual men
column37: and many men whose desire to focus on child raising is stronger than the desire of many women to do the same.  In the realignment of society that has occurred particularly in the latter half of the last century
column38: legislation and societal mores have changed so that individuals are freer to follow their own specific genetically determined behaviors.  Brilliant
column39: competitive women are no longer confined to housework
column40: but are free to pursue professional careers if they wish
column41: while their husbands can stay at home with the children if that better suits their temperament.  No society is perfect
column42: and we are far from achieving a perfect match between inherent personality traits and roles in society
column43: but the proposals of this book would take us backwards
column44: not forwards in allowing people to live up to their genetic potential.

column1: I'm a Wiccan who formally practices within a traditional Gardnerian coven
column2: but practices eclectically within my private practice. I read this book because I had heard that it was recommended to my local library by a Christian; purportedly
column3: Wicca's Charm was written by an impartial writer. Immediately
column4: you realize that this isn't true. Catherine Sanders has a clearly stated agenda: that Wiccans are simply misguided and  misunderstand that what they long for is offered by Christianity.   I could write a long review debating the merits of Sanders' arguments. Instead
column5: I suggest that you consider this if deciding whether to read this book which Sanders claims to have thoroughly researched. She relies on the writings of Margot Adler
column6: Carol Christ
column7: Starhawk and Phyllis Curott (with barely a nod to Scott Cunningham and Ronald Hutton) to draw many of her conclusions. Yet
column8: missing from her notes are such writers as the Farrars
column9: Merlin Stone
column10: Raymond Buckland
column11: Isaac Bonewits
column12: Patricia Crowley
column13: and the Matthews
column14: to name just a few outstanding contributors to Neopaganism's base of knowledge.   Too often
column15: Sanders relies on the statements of young Wiccans she interviewed who come across as silly and naive. In another case
column16: she bases her thesis that women's spirituality (e.g.
column17: Goddess worship)is misguided and that Christianity fits the same spiritual needs that women are seeking via ONE speech that she heard Margot Adler give shortly after 9/11.   Sanders requests both Christians and Neopagans to read her book with an open mind. A fair request. But as you're reading
column18: closely check out her endnotes and analyze for yourself if this book was truly researched with objectivity in mind
column19: or whether Sanders limited herself to sources that would support her belief that Christianity has everything that a Wiccan desires. One needs to go no further than to consider that as Sanders attempts to persuade the reader that Christianity has always embraced the value of women that not once does she analyze the epistles of Paul.
