I often enjoy reading books written trying to read the future that are several years old. If only to see why the writer was right or wrong and where he went wrong.  Well this book was published in 1996 and is basically written around the US although other countries are mentioned in passing. The basic premises is that the new industries will employ a few people but not enough to make up the fall in the established industries. So the unemployment will go up. Furthermore we better get used to it. His partial solution is reduction in hours of employment and a greater stress on the third sector.  Looking at the US economy which most of the book is written about in the past 50 years the workforce in the US has almost tripled. Yet in the same period there is no long term trend to greater unemployment. Just look at a graph. Currently now its where it was in 1950. So obviously unemployment is not going up. So the writer got it wrong.   Looking at a graph of US unemployments percenatges
column2: its clear that the situation was a bit high at the time of writing. The writer made a typical mistake of many futurologist of extrapolating into the far future based on the past few years.  Furthermore the writer paid too much attention to the publicity departments of R&D companies. He keeps bring us all these new technologies that are going to change the world dramatically eg getting rid of farmers with chemical vats and vanilla production from genetic research. Well
column3: its been 10 years and most of these technologies are still coming. He obviously has forgotten Daniel Bell warning in what is an absolute gem of a book "Coming of Post-Industrial Society" that many futurologist look too hard at industries worth millions of dollars and generalize into industrials worth billions.   He seems to also forget that labour hours are dropping all the time. I am not sure what the situation is in the US but as the pay master in an Australian company
column4: I can see that the labour hours are  steadily dropping every year. For example old timers tell me that the standard office hours 40 years ago was 44 hours a week
column5: by the time I started working it was 40 and now at 38 hours plus now two 10 minutes breaks are included in the working hours so its more like 36 hours week. Furthermore in the past few years the number of sick days a year has gone from 5 days to 8 days a year. Two extra days a year has been introduced for compassionate leave. Long service leave (a holiday of 15 weeks) is now given at 10 years not 15 years. Furthermore the average worker now starts his employment later as he tends to study much more
column6: so early 20s is now quite standard to start working and he retires at 55.  All this works out to a rather dramatic drop in hours worked in a generation.  Finally we come to the third sector. The sector the writer hopes is going to take some of the unemployment.  This is a sector that I have had considerable contact with over the years eg I went to a private school
column7: been active in political and religious organizations
column8: been computer programmer in a private cancer research organization and have been too many private hospitals. I don't see the employment opportunities. The volunteers or people on the committees that he is referring too tend to be at most a few hours a week. Hardly an equivalent of a job. Nor is it generally like they are working. Often its more socialible. The people that work for these organizations tend to be regular workers eg the janitor in the church
column9: the nurse in a charity run hospital or teacher in a religious school does a similar job to the same people in a similar government or private institution. They tend to get paid roughly the same. Often they go from government to private to the third sector depending on who gives them a better deal. I just don't know where the writer is coming from with his arguments here. I suspect that he has little contact with these organizations.  Overall I would say that this book is best forgotten

column1: While Berlant is quite definatly a good cultural theorist
column2: the type of work she does is problematic. This book regularly tries to define a national mindset in relation to the productions of a small number of people. While one might be able to analyze any number of the texts mentioned in this book
column3: Berlant insists on saying that these texts relate to a particular way of thinking that are shared by at least a majority of our population (enough to elect republicans to the presidency). She repeatedly uses really loaded/offensive terms
column4: which can be fun if you politically agree with her (for instance patriotism=infantile citizenship
column5: heterosexuality=dead sexuality)
column6: but if you disagree even slightly with her they seem mostly like bullying. While I'm rather left leaning
column7: the core of her arguement
column8: that right leaning people vote more based on emotions rather than well thought out ideas
column9: I find to be mostly baseless (I think a misunderstanding of economics and international politics are the reason people vote republican... or immense wealth). Since most of the textual examples she uses I don't think can ever adequatly stand for the majority of the people she claims they represent
column10: and are more caricatures of poltical discourse (which of course most political discourse is) rather than actual personal poltics
column11: her work comes across as being based on a confusion of aggressiveness and refrences to Lacan with strong theorizing.  Unless you want to get into arguements with friends who really like this book
column12: I'd pass it up if I were you

column1: If you're just mixing non-gas-forming drink mixes
column2: this thing works acceptably well

column4: it's not very useful because it just doesn't form a very good seal
column5: no matter how tightly you close it. As another reviewer mentioned
column6: it's very easy to cross-thread the lid.  Thicker threads and deeper threads would probably help.  It is great for sipping though
column7: and easy enough to keep clean. But I went back to using a plastic 16-oz milk bottle that always forms a tight seal when you close it. The seal on this bottle is too flaky because it's difficult to tell if you've cross-threaded it until you start shaking it.   I'd have expected a bottle designed for shaking and mixing drinks would have paid a little more attention to the problems this has. I don't use this any more
column8: because it's too annoying to worry about the seal and the cross-threading. Don't waste your money on it.

column1: Used Norton antivirus the last 3 years. getting product in tax software promotions.  No problems until I installed 2007 6 days ago

The first rep became exasperated when his scripted suggestions did not resolve my problem after 1.25 hours and tersely told me he was sending me an email file that would solve my problems.  I had identified it was the Worm Protection causing the problem so I turned that off
column4: accessed the file and ran it.  My computer updated twice with no change - if the Worm Protection was on
column5: I wasn't going to be able to access the internet.       Worked up my patience and called that evening
column6: only to hold for 48 minutes.  Finally got another native of India who spoke English worse than the first guy. At one point
column7: we were waiting on a restart and I asked her a question about the computer being slower with the 2007 version and she responded
column8: "OK
column9: yes".  Long story short
column10: I hung up an hour later with a link for an update to the 2007 product which I was assured would solve the problem and an email address for her manager. During these two calls
column11: the software was uninstalled
column12: reinstalled
column13: and tested and I spent several hours using the online support.  I updated the product and it worked for a couple hours.  Then I was right back where I began
column14: unable to access the internet unless I turned off the Worm Protection.  I started the day with 360 days remaining on my subscription but once I updated
column15: the protection center now says my subscription is expired. When I check my Norton account online
column16: it shows I have almost a year remaining before expiration and all their tips to update the proection center have pathetically failed.  Sent an email to the management address I was given
column17: but of course
column18: haven't heard anything.  I am uninstalling this product and will never use Norton again.

column1: Tropic of Cancer by Henry Miller. Not recommended.  In his 1960 introduction to Tropic of Cancer
column2: Karl Shapiro said
column3: "I call Henry Miller the greatest living author because I think he is
column4: . . . as a spiritual example he stands among the great men of our age
column5: and . . . he [Orwell] predicts that Miller will set the pace and attitude for the novelist of the future. This has not happened yet
column6: but I agree that it must." Shapiro does not support any of these points in his essay
column7: and nothing about Tropic of Cancer supports them
column8: either.  Tropic of Cancer consists of 318 pages recounting Miller's experience as an American expatriate in Paris and expounding his personal philosophy
column9: often in ways that are rambling and painfully nonsensical. Miller's stories about his friends are tedious
column10: pointless
column11: and catty; like Miller
column12: they seem to have been talentless hacks whose belief in their own artistic abilities makes them artists and writers
column13: as though believing is being. Miller writes
column14: "A year ago
column15: six months ago
column16: I thought I was an artist. I no longer think about it
column17: I am"--which is the type of arrogant pretentiousness he mocks in virtually all of his acquaintances.  When they are not creating
column18: or talking about philosophy or creating
column19: Miller and his circle seem to spend nearly every moment picking up women (and disease). They rarely use a neutral term such as "woman" when there are so many obscene
column20: demeaning words with which to objectify the gender. The women that Miller and friends find are invariably portrayed as stupid
column21: drunken
column22: irrational
column23: loose
column24: sly
column25: deceptive
column26: and good primarily for one function
column27: which Miller turns into a squalid
column28: cold
column29: joyless act. In spite of all the vice and the "living
column30: no one seems to be having fun, and some characters, notably Fillmore, find themselves nearly trapped into the bourgeoisie life.  Miller expresses contempt for the machine, the industrial age, and money--although he schemes to keep 2,800 francs from Fillmore's mistress and revels in having so much in his pocket. Often hungry, Miller obsesses about food and relies on his friends to support him. When he describes his Indian friend Kepi as . . . a scrounger
column31: a sort of human tick who fastens himself to the hide of even the poorest compatriot
column32: he could be talking about himself as he bitterly complains about those of his friends who are stingy with money, accommodations, food, and wine.  Miller's logic about the working world is facile; he writes, If you want bread
column33: you've got to get in harness
column34: get in lockstep." On the surface
column35: this is true
column36: but it never seems to occur to him that
column37: if you want bread
column38: someone must cultivate
column39: raise
column40: and harvest the wheat and produce the other components; someone must transform these components into bread; and someone must deliver it to the shops and cafes. In other words
column41: if most people weren't in "lock step
column42: Miller could choose to starve or set himself to produce bread, joining the world in harness. He makes his choice clear, then whines about it. He may despise those who support him, whether they are friends or workers, but that is perhaps because he, a misanthrope who finds fault with everyone but himself, needs the very people he denigrates (including the grocer
column43: the baker
column44: the shoemaker
column45: the butcher
column46: etc.--all imbecilic-looking clodhoppers")
column47: a reliance which he resents. He hates the machine and the machine mind
column48: but offers no alternatives.  Seemingly incapable of sincere feeling
column49: Miller finds human emotion amusing. When a friend says
column50: "A boy can break your heart . . . He's so damned beautiful! And so cruel!" Miller writes
column51: "We had to laugh at this. It sounded preposterous. But Collins was in earnest." When an acquaintance to whom he owes money dies
column52: he writes
column53: "At any rate
column54: he was killed in an automobile accident shortly after my arrival
column55: a circumstance which left me twenty-three francs to the good."  Shapiro claims that Miller is a poet
column56: but his attempts at poetic and philosophic ramblings often make little if any sense. Speaking of buildings and statues
column57: Miller says
column58: " . . . they must be saturated with my anguish
column59: the kind of bad metaphor in which he frequently indulges. He describes artists such as himself as the inhuman ones." "I am inhuman! I say it with a mad
column60: hallucinated grin
column61: and I will keep on saying it though it rain crocodiles. Behind my words are all those grinning
column64: some dead and grinning a long time
column65: some grinning as if they had lockjaw
column66: some grinning with the grimace of a grin
column67: the foretaste and aftermath of what is always going on." Whenever these attempts at poetic philosophy appeared
column69: I found myself yearning for a return to his insipid stories about prostitutes
column72: and hunger.  Tropic of Cancer is perhaps the worst book I have ever read (and I did promise myself that I would read Tropic of Capricorn). Shapiro says
column73: "There are not many of these emancipated beings left in our world [emancipated from what? --DLS]
column75: celebrants of the soul and of the flesh and of the still-remaining promise of America." If Miller
column80: his two-dimensional view of people, and his obsession with excrement, is the greatest" of these souls
column81: may I never meet the least.  Note: If there were a 0 stars option
column82: Tropic of Cancer would have earned it

column1: I was excited to read this book
column2: as I have a degree in criminology from a British university and currently research firearms in the U.S.  I was very disappointed. While this book has interesting points about perceptions of  crime
column3: the American political process
column4: and the troubling state of criminal  justice
column5: its research methods and analytic conclusions are deeply flawed.   Windlesham critiques American crime policy and law using examples of crimes  in Britain
column6: as if Britain and the U.S. could and should be compared without  hestitation. He critiques NRA statements and policy recommendations as  misguided ideology
column7: but uses Handgun Control Inc.'s writings as if it was  scholarship.  He barely refers to any concrete criminological studies on  firearms
column8: prefering to use medical studies on guns
column9: which most sociologists  and criminologists have illustrated are often deeply methodologically  flawed.  He does not use the solid scholarship on guns in the U.S. written  by well-known criminologists
column10: even when that research would reinforce his  overall points. Lastly
column11: he glosses over research on the Second Amendment  and its supposed impediment to gun control
column12: using partisan writings and  very little work from legitimate lawyers and historians.  Overall
column13: this  book was a serious disappointment.  For much better research in a similar  vein
column14: try books by Franklin Zimring
column15: Gary Kleck
column16: or Jan Dizard et al.'s  book "Guns in America."  Though very different
column17: these works are  honest attempts to understand complicated issues. Windlesham's book is not

column1: As someone who lived (and
column2: I guess
column3: is still living) the life of a "gifted" person
column4: I'm not terribly surprised by what I found in this book.  Many of the problems held by gifted students originate not from parents but from bureaucrats--people who want to figure out how best to control their talents for profit.  There isn't much profit for the parents themselves
column5: so where's the profit going to come from?  Other than those kids marked by stock brokers and scientists for high-paying jobs
column6: what's left?  Political profit
column7: of course
column8: and this is Quart's real goal.  Quart simply oppresses her topic into non-existence unless it can produce the right kind of person that will be sure to vote the right way.  Scrabble players
column9: spelling bee kids
column10: math geniuses...they're all weird at best and dangerous at worst
column11: *especially* if they've been home-schooled or attend church.  Competitors in chess are hyper-competitive
column12: but (surprisingly?) kids participating in politically-charged poetry slams are "encouraging" and "supportive".  She weeps for school districts that support the gifted and thereby thwart the  "equal results" that certain political groups seek
column13: yet cannot find anything but disdain for programs that support the results of all students  simply (and clearly) because of the political party that happened to begin it.  Her descriptions of her subjects are caricatured so badly that one cannot have any faith in the descriptions.  And
column14: as some have noted below
column15: she has played loose and fast with those she quotes in order to make the right sort of case.  If you have the ability to ignore or refute the author's opinions through basic critical-reading skills
column16: you can get a basic idea of the sorts of issues faced by the gifted.  If not
column17: look elsewhere

 The description for this item is not accurate. I bought the freeze deied raspberries and stawberries from this same company and they are great. However, these are dehydrated which means 2 important things: - Texture: these are very hard and do not soften if left in milk or water. Don't think about adding these to cereal, only for trail mix or eating out of hand. - Saturated fat: the second ingredient is coconut oil! One 2oz. serving has 190 calories, 19 grams of fat and 16 grams of saturated fat. You're better off eating Cheetos.  These are extremely unhealthy and don't even taste that great. There is (unsurprisingly) and oily aftertaste. Buyer beware. Stick to purely freeze dried fruits - nothing is added and they are healthy

column4: estimated by Forbes to be worth US$1.74bil (RM6.6bil)

column7: competitive spirit

column9: passion
column10: gumption and more. These tests have included an advertising campaign for a card that allocates private jet service by the hour
column11: an AIDS benefit auction
column12: art exhibition
column13: running a lemonade stand and selling bottled drinking water.    Although Trump appears only at the end of each episode to eliminate one person from the losing team - and briefly at the start - he really is the star of the show which is an induction into his world. Choosing his apprentice by shrewdly assessing their strengths and weaknesses
column14: with the help of assistants George and Carolyn

column19: the ideal candidate will be familiar with all or most of these 10 Trump-approved methods:   Think Big. Show the Competition No Mercy. Defend Yourself Aggressively. Remember
column20: Consensus Is Overrated. Identify All Possible Resources
column21: and Use Them Strategically. Cut Your Losses. Get Face-to-Face With Key Decision-Makers. Step Up - Take Intelligent Chances
column22: and Then Take Responsibility. Advance the Most Profitable Deal. Negotiate Tough.    Employers look for people who dare go after a riskier but more potentially rewarding path
column23: who will pull through more often than not. These are what Trump calls Big Thinkers. The apprentice will have to be this and much
column24: much more.   The apprentice will have to be able to Show the Competition No Mercy. He does this by identifying and neutralising competition - both outside and inside. He recognises there will be team-mates who are not above stealing his ideas or credit for his work
column25: or sabotaging his ambitions.   If things take a turn for the worse and they sometimes do
column26: the apprentice will Defend Himself Aggressively. It doesn't matter whether he is right or wrong
column27: what matters is that he steps up and defends himself aggressively. How he tackles false charges and inaccuracies will be perceived as a measure of his fighting spirit.   The problem with group-think is that the watered down solution that is agreeable to everyone is rarely often the best solution

column29: when in a leadership position
column30: his team cannot come to a compromise
column31: he takes what he thinks is the best idea and runs with it.   Being able to Identify All Possible Resources and Use Them Intelligently

column33: ingenious methods of attracting potential customers
column34: getting people to work for free

column41: time and energy.   To win over a position or a business

column43: and make his case with passion and style. Non verbal communication counts and face time will give him the chance to feel out his contact's distinct way of interacting with the world. More importantly
column44: he will get to bond with that person.   Failure comes with the territory but the apprentice knows how to Step Up - Take Intelligent Chances

column46: have manageable downsides
column47: take advantage of his demonstrated strengths and resources and neutralises his competition.   In any business situation

column1: Homer Kelly is an engineer who has written a book about the golf swing that is supposedly "The computer age approach to golfing perfection". But it could equally well be written by Homer Simpson
column2: because it is almost impossible to understand. This book reminds me of the holy bible: it is so vaguely written that it opens up to a host of different interpretations
column3: and no two readers will come away with identical perceptions. This may work for the bible
column4: but for a work that promotes the truth about the golf swing it simply won't do.  For incongruous reasons
column5: Homer doesn't use ordinary scientific terms when describing golf. He doesn't use ordinary golf terms either
column6: so this makes his ideas very hard to follow.   There are several other reasons for this: 1) No logical flow. He begins in mid-scenario and describes clubhead-ball interaction and mixes hand action and other body parts into the plot without hesitation.  2) He prescribes
column7: that you should read the book in a most strange order: Chapter 1
column8: 1st part of chapter 12
column9: 1st part of chapter 14
column10: chapter 8
column11: chapter 9
column12: 1st part of chapter 7
column13: 1st part of chapter 10
column14: 1st part of chapter 11
column15: 2nd part of chapter 12 etc. If he wants people to read the book like this
column16: why didn't he write it like that? It is not that he didn't have the time as he allegedly spent 28 years writing it
column17: and he has re-written some of the chapters since the first publication!  3) The terms used are neither scientific nor golf related. They are home-made and quite illogical. And they are never explained when first introduced.   The reason I can say with confidence
column18: that it is not a scientific book
column19: are manifold: 1) The notationes used are not scientific. 2) No cause and effect explained
column20: only description of static positions (geometries). 3) You can't make predictions or even calculations with his theories. 4) No documentation what so ever are presented.   I believe that this fellow used to be a pretty good golfer
column21: handicap 1 or thereabouts
column22: and that he has evolved some major observations into this comprehensive - but very far from conclusive
column23: volume.  One of the major "findings" in The Golfing Machine is
column24: that there are two principally different ways of golfing: swinging versus hitting. But strangely enough
column25: they show identical golf swings even though the dynamics (and body parts) used to propel the club are different. But how can different dynamics result in identical swings? If the applied forces in two swings are different
column26: then the two swings will have different dynamics and will look different. And conversely
column27: if two swings look the same
column28: then the forces that produced the swings has to be identical. This is pure Newtonian physics. Anything else doesn't make sense.  Homer also states that you can move either of your wrists in 6 different directions. You can cock them
column29: bend them
column30: roll them
column31: arch them
column32: turn them etc. But what good is this notation when he doesn't tell which movements are preferable? It doesn't bring clarity
column33: only confusion.   Homer also states that the best way to swing a golf club is with a flat left wrist. And that may very well be true (especially if he bothered to define "best")
column34: but how did he arrive at that conclusion
column35: and how can the reader trust that he is right? Has he grabbed the idea from thin air
column36: is it a result of a logical train of thoughts
column37: real life observations or maybe calculations on mathematical models? No clues are given
column38: no references warrants his findings.  I sincerely believe
column39: that I would go stark raving mad if I had to read this book for a sustained period of time. It is that frustrating! He picks the golf swing apart into 1000 pieces
column40: but he never puts it back together. It feels like having a puzzle of 1000 pieces from 1000 different puzzles.  For all I know
column41: Homer could be a misunderstood genius or a raving lunatic - it is very hard to make a clear decision based on the contents of the book
column42: because it is so difficult and frustrating to read and understand. My assumption leans towards the latter - but I could be wrong

column1: A. S. Byatt's work can be excellent. Her short stories are really marvelous
column2: and "Possession" was a wonder - full of life and characters and plot. In the series that is capped by this novel
column3: I continue to find "The Virgin in the Garden" an outstanding work and "Still Life" quite remarkable. However
column4: "A Whistling Woman" is too large
column5: it covers too many topics
column6: too much history and too much science (done without any spirit) and too many stories. The period explored by the novel certainly encompassed all these things
column7: but why did the novel try to do the same. Should not the novelist sift through and bring forth something that crystallizes the period
column8: rather than load the reader with details and leave us wondering at the end why we plowed through such a "big" book only to find a clueless
column9: pregnant Frederica. The work loses focus
column10: flattens characters and in the end finishes rather lamely - dead characters either we hardly knew or from whom we expected more; live characters who have disappeared into clichs
column11: and romances that even the author seems reluctant to accept. I have to admit
column12: the energy of the 60s does seem to have ended in pregnant 70s girls in Laura Ashley dresses
column13: but I do think that Byatt should have left this novel to sit for awhile
column14: and come back to it after a little reflection
column15: crafting a finer piece
column16: which her readers deserve. Let's hope now that Byatt has the series behind her
column17: she will be freed to write a more wonderful work

column1: This book contains some useful historical information and some insights into the mass psychology of booms
column2: bubbles
column3: and busts.  Prechter should have left it at that.  Instead
column4: he offers up predictions.  Big mistake.  This guy bases his forecasts on Fibonacci numbers and so-called Elliott "wave counts."   He labels all market patterns so that they fit the preordained Elliott Wave 5-up
column5: 3-down pattern.  If you see more or fewer waves than he does in any given market move
column6: you just don't understand that there can only be 5 waves to the top of a bull market.  He's imposing his theory on the market
column7: but surprisingly enough
column8: the market doesn't care.  It does whatever it wants
column9: in however many waves it wants
column10: and Bob has been very frustrated at the market's aberrant behavior lately.  He got lucky early in his career
column11: but it seems he's been fairly consistently getting the market wrong since missing the '87 crash.    Any superstitution can "seem" to work if you only look at its happenstance apparent accuracies and disregard its abundant failures.  Keep looking for certain numbers of waves and Fibonacci ratios and you'll find what you're looking for.  Pick any set of numbers or patterns or wave counts
column12: and you'll find those too.  The market doesn't care about any of those things
column13: though.  It's nothing more than an aggregation of billlions of individual choices
column14: which are influenced by an infinite number of factors none of us can ever understand fully.  University studies of various investing methods have found that Elliott Wave
column15: like most
column16: is no better than random stock selection.   If Prechter had chosen the random method
column17: he and his followers would at least have a good chance of keeping pace with the market.  Unfortunately
column18: he has been getting everything from the Dow
column19: to oil (he thought it was going to $10)
column20: to gold (he didn't think it could break $400)
column21: to deflation (the "deflation" scare ended shortly after this book came out) WRONG in the past couple of years.  He apparently STILL believes that the Dow will go to 400 (not 4
column22: 000 but FOUR HUNDRED) because his charts tell him it should (they've been telling him that since about 1990
column23: actually).  Prechter doesn't understand demographics or economics or markets or the monetary system
column24: all of which render "Dow 400" among the goofiest of forecasting absurdities -- unless you believe a giant asteroid will hit and wipe out two thirds of the population (I don't think Prechter is counting on that).  Our debt-heavy economy may have a significant crisis soon
column25: perhaps by the end of the decade.  It will most likely be spurred on by inflation and rising interest rates.  But it's not happening now and it's not happening in the way this author has been prematurely forecasting for over a decade.  This book came out near the bottom of the 2000-2002 stock bear market
column26: just in time for a reader to short stocks as they began a new bull market.  How typical.  While promoting the book
column27: Prechter said it was "definite" that stocks would "crash" in 2003.  He said that 2003 would be "the best year yet" for bears (short sellers).  Late into 2003
column28: when it was clear that the market had proven him wrong
column29: Prechter declared on a radio show that by the end of 2004
column30: the Dow would "certainly" fall below 5
column31: 000.  Wrong again!  Since his Fibonacci turn dates and Elliott wave counts fail to portend the future
column32: maybe next he'll tell us he's found the secret code to the stock market from the text count of Nostradamus' writings.  Bob Prechter couldn't call the market if it was listed in the Yellow Pages.  This guy couldn't time the market if you gave him a stopwatch.  He's throwing out guesses and misleading people by describing them as "definite" and "certain."  He's either a liar or a true believer in his own irrational superstitions.  In either case
column33: he's not credible.  Here's all you really need to know: Buy dividend stocks.  Buy short-term bonds.  Buy gold.  Hang on to them.  Do that and you'll do better than you will trying to follow the prognostications of market gurus.  Plus
column34: you'll have a lot more time to devote to family
column35: fun
column36: and productive activities

column1: The movie Like It Is
column2: directed by Paul Oremland
column3: has to deal with a boxer/fighter Craig (Steve Bell) as a guy who is trying to crawl out from the fighting life he is in. Craig meets Matt (Ian Rose) who is a band manager/record producer who takes a romantic interest in Craig and the two head off to London. It is in London that trouble begins to unravel the relationshi as Matt's boss tries to split the two up. The movie wraps up with Matt trying to get Craig back before their relationship is doomed. Both Steve Bell and Ian Rose do a decent job of acting in spite of the terrible script that is so disjointed by terrible editting and poor scene transition. There really is nothing new in this film: drugs run rampart
column4: pretty boys litter the set
column5: and sleazy gritty characters are plentiful. In addition
column6: the fight scenes make you wince with how fake it come across. The lack of character development doesn't fully connect the viewer and the drama happening to the characters in the story
column7: thus by the time half the movie is done you really don't care if Craig and Matt get together or not. The only glimmer of promise in this movie was the techno soundtrack which was fairly funky and enjoyable. Finally
column8: when the movie comes to an abrupt end
column9: Like It Is seems more like a recipe on what a movie shouldn't be

column1: I have noticed that some people have really hated this movie and called it really bad.  I don't think that this is the case.  A really bad movie can still be entertaining because you end up laughing at the movie.  With that in mind
column2: I don't think that Must Love Dogs is a bad movie.  I think it is just mediocre.  There are some bright spots to the movie: my favorite being when Lane's father reads from W.B. Yeats.  The problem is that through most of the rest of the movie
column3: I sat on my couch wondering what the weather was like outside
column4: what I should get my mother for Christmas
column5: and what I should make for supper.  Rarely
column6: if ever
column7: did my attention focus on the movie.  The biggest reason is that I didn't care about the characters.  Given that the leading parts are played by extremely good actors
column8: I have to assume that the movie fell apart in a different place: the direction
column9: the editing
column10: the script
column11: or a combination of all three.  I tend to believe that it is the later.  There are some scenes that are cut off before they can really resonate emotionally.  Other scenes are drug out so long that if you cared about them to begin with
column12: you have totally forgotten why you cared by the time you get to the end.  Ultimately
column13: this had the potential to be an entertaining and enjoyable movie; however
column14: too many things were botched.  If you are a really big Cusack or Lane fan or extremely bored
column15: you might want to pick this up at your local rental store
column16: but I definately would not recommend buying it.  It just isn't a movie that needs to be in anyone's collection

column1: There isn't anything in this book that you won't find in Warren Buffett's annual letters to the shareholders of Berkshire Hathaway (available for free at the Berkshire Hathaway website).  If you've not read those letters then I suggest you get right to it - they clearly lay out Mr Buffett's approach to investing and are written in a very easy to read
column2: humorous and homely style.  This book pulls many of the highlights from those letters together in one place and lays out some major tenets and themes that could be said to make an investment "Buffett like".    If you're not familiar with Warren Buffett and have not read his letters to the shareholders of Berkshire Hathaway - then you will likely find this to be a good introduction to Buffett.  Anybody else should probably steer clear as there isn't anything new here.

column1: TA is a highly sophisticated topic which cannot be covered thoroughly with a 316 page book. That's for sure. In fact
column2: the author had been honest not to over promise with the humble title of his book. The scope of discussion is limited to chart patterns
column3: trendlines
column4: channels
column5: moving averages
column6: Fibonnaci numbers
column7: MACD
column8: Stochastics
column9: RSI and a few others. As the author had emphasized his objective to make his book only an introduction to TA
column10: I am not going to comment on the variety of TA tools covered. However
column11: I still want to criticize on some of the weaknesses:  1) Number of real life examples/price charts are few.  2) The choice of parameters for MACD and Stochastics had not been discussed  3) False breakouts are so frequent in the author's graphs samples (that's a fact of life
column12: I admit). However
column13: the author made little attempt to teach readers how to avoid such traps with the use of multiple TA tools.  4) The relative weak Q&A sections that questions are focused on readers' understanding of the definition of jargons instead of the usage of TA tools.   Though the price is affordable
column14: I am hesitant to recommend it to any aspiring trader/investor who are serious to get an elementary but quality course on TA. It's not the cost of the book that matters
column15: but the cost of time and potential trading loss for reading it.

column1: In the Long Ago Far Away
column2: I remember reading some of the Anita Blake series
column3: but being no fan of mysteries or detectives I let the series fall by the wayside.  If a writer is truly great
column4: then I can stay rivited even if the subject isn't one of my favorites.  I adore Faeries
column5: to the point of practicing a post-modern version of Faerie Faith with no rules and no boundaries (and hence no obsessive traditionalism).  Ms. Hamilton now has fairies with no rules and no boundaries.  None.  Zip.  Nada.  Yet somehow
column6: this is the inverse of liberating.  Oh
column7: I am not surprised.  I have something of a fetish for well-written negative reviews
column8: and reading some of the erudite
column9: articulate attacks on Ms. Hamilton's writing have been illuminating.  I am fully aware of the direction taken by Anita Blake and I knew to expect it with Meredith Gentry.  So essentially
column10: mixed blood fairy girl (1/2 Unseelie
column11: 1/4 Seelie Brownie
column12: 1/4 mortal - or some approximation of that mess) without the immortality gene runs away to escape torture at the hands of the Queen of the Unseelie Court
column13: her Aunt Andais.  She becomes a private investigator in Los Angeles.  Auntie sends a few of her bodyguards to retrieve the wayward Princess Meredith and bring her back to the Court
column14: where the Queen will make Merry an Offer She Can't Refuse.  Part and parcel with this offer comes the requirement to have sex with the Queen's Guards until she conceives
column15: because a child will guarantee Merry the Throne.  Merry's competing with her cousin
column16: Cel
column17: who is under the same orders to produce a child.  And that's about it.  From some of the reviews here
column18: I expected a lot more sex.  There are a few near misses and a few actual sex scenes
column19: but they're nothing special.  The kink quotient is quite mild
column20: comparatively speaking.  Even the scene that involves tentacles peters out to nothing.  It seems that
column21: if the character is unattractive or undersirable in any way
column22: Meredith will be spared sex with this fiend at the last minute
column23: in the most contrived way possible.  Merry
column24: apparently
column25: doesn't take any for the team.  The most diffecult thing about reading Laurell Hamilton is the way she writes.  Her vocabulary seems very limited and the writing is quite repetitious.  Whenever someone bites/something stabs Meredith
column26: the pain is described as "sharp and immediate."    "Burning and instantaneous" "Terrible and abrupt" "Stinging and urgent"  I'm not even trying.  Along with this limited vocabulary
column27: Ms. Hamilton writes very much in passive voice.  Is
column28: was
column29: were
column30: has
column31: had
column32: be
column33: been
column34: etc.  Dialogue is also stilted and awkward
column35: with normal diction sometimes ignored to give a character an opportunity to say something "witty."  Characterization isn't a strong suit either.  Meredith is a little dull
column36: but most heroines are.  Her sex partners all have nearly identical personalities
column37: and I wish there had been some variety in the way Ms. Hamilton chose to describe them
column38: rather than a run-down of features and attributes.  So why did I read it?  If I knew all this in advance
column39: why did I even drop a dime on it?    I enjoy erotica
column40: and
column41: as previously mentioned
column42: I'm a faerie fan.  I expected the writing to be terrible
column43: but bearable enough for a few moments of shallow enjoyment.  Then I expected to come here
column44: slap down a single star
column45: and go on my merry way.  If at all possible
column46: I am even more offended by the fact the most of Ms. Hamilton's ideas were good
column47: but she blew it by not following through
column48: or by failing to explore character emotion
column49: or by making the plot secondary to the sex.  To have ideas that are actually interesting and then to drop the ball is even worse than having no good ideas at all (Anne Rice's "Beauty" series
column50: *cough*cough).  But I can't give Ms. Hamilton one star
column51: because the ideas were there
column52: shining just below the surface.  The idea of fairies as celebrities in the mortal world . . . the concept of a fairie exodus to the United States . . . old gods becoming fairies . . . etc
column53: etc . . .  So the book gets two stars
column54: and it could have garnered more if Ms. Hamilton had her priorities straight.  1. Ms. Hamilton
column55: you are a grown woman.  Mention the business parts of the male chracters by name please.  Obscuring gential terms with "him" and "himself" makes you look sqeamish and unsure of yourself.  If you want to write something with a little heat and intensity
column56: clarify the act
column57: please.  2. Thesaurus.  3. If you want all the sex
column58: make the non-sexual parts longer so that they represent a plot.  4. Why is everyone so rampantly heterosexual
column59: and horrified at the idea of homosexuality?  These are fairies
column60: not humans.  Why would they possess our prejudices?  5. Let Meredith sleep with unattractive characters now and again.  Refusing to do so makes her seem like an elitist snob.  Enough complaining.   Look at the reviews and see if this is a mess you want to wade into.  I've started the second book
column61: but after the first "sharp and immediate" there
column62: I've set it aside until my annoyance ends.  If you want a modern fairy tale
column64: but it's far more satisfying than Merry Gentry's world.

column1: I have had this camera since Jan '05 and have so far taken approximately 10
column2: 000 shots while on trips and at weddings.   Don't expect much from it and you will be happy. As an entry level DSLR it does what it's supposed to do in ideal conditions. I find it's strength is in taking people photographs in bright light
column3: provided that they are not moving.    Cons:  In landscape photography this camera is lacking - both due to inadequate megapixels and it's inability to capture the natural blues and greens very well.  Battery dies FAST. The battery I got with it hardly lasts a whole day of shooting
column4: especially when shooting in RAW mode. I have yet to fill up a 1Gig card when shooting in RAW mode(Approx 150 shots) before the battery dies. Surprisingly when shooting jpegs
column5: I get more shots per charge(Over 300) but hardly enough to last a day. I cannot tell you the number of times the battery has died on me while I was out on a hike. So I always carry a backup film camera (my trusty Elan 7).  The viewfinder is very dim. When I look through my Elan 7 and then through the 300D
column6: it is painfully obvious how dark the image is through the 300D's viewfinder. In indoor situations with low light this becomes a handicap
column7: especially when having to resort to manual focus.   Autofocus in low light for the 300d is terrible. When shooting indoors
column8: the autofocus hunts and ends up focusing on something behind your intended subject. I have lots of beautiful photos of walls and sconces in the background in sharp focus while the people standing in front in the middle of the frame are an out of focus blur. This is despite having a 420Ex Flash on my camera that uses an infrared beam to assist with the focus.  The 420EX flash is supposed to "talk" to the camera and adjust the power in order to ensure the subjects are not over or under exposed. However
column9: with the 300d
column10: this is a crap shoot at best and many of my indoor shots are over/under exposed.   After about five months
column11: the shutter button started sticking. I would click it and then it would remain depressed. The shutter button would only pop back up after I jiggled it a little.  Another annoying thing about the camera is that the settings are displayed on the rear of the camera and not on the top beside the shutter button. And since there is only one thumbwheel
column12: it is not easy to change aperature and shutter speed. For example
column13: if you use the thumbwheel to change the aperature
column14: then to change the shutter speed you would have to press another button while at the same time turning the thumbwheel. When you take thousands of shots over the life of the camera
column15: this is a real annoyance.  So would I recommend this camera: If you are a casual point and shoot person
column16: it's an affordable entry into DSLRs that produces decent photos. But if you plan on shooting a lot indoors or want to take landscape photographs that can actually convey the colors accurately
column17: look elsewhere

The editor of this volume of collected essays
column2: U Maki
column3: made the mistake of republishing an error filled paper of J.Runde that originally appeared as an invited paper in The Monist(1995).Runde corrected several of his errors regarding Frank Knight
column4: but none of his errors regarding John Maynard Keynes.Runde's essay is then used
column5: implicitly and/or explicitly
column6: by the other essay authors whenever issues about Keynes and probability
column7: decision making
column8: rationality
column9: expectations
column10: etc.
column11: arises as an issue in their essays.Runde's major error is that he bases his entire discussion of Keynes's approach to the quantification and measurement of probabilities  on chapters 3  and 4 of Keynes's A Treatise on Probability(1921;TP).This is precisely the same error made by Frank P. Ramsey
column13: in two error filled reviews  of Keynes's book that Bertrand Russell correctly described as having the least value of any paper written by Ramsey during his brief lifetime(1903-1930).In chapter 3 of the TP
column15: Keynes warns the reader that his approach to the measurement and quantification of estimating probabilities would not be completed until after Part II of the TP had been finished.In chapter 15(pp.160-163) and chapter 17(p.186-194)of his TP
column16: Keynes makes it crystal clear that by the terms "nonnumerical" and "nonmeasurable" he means not by a single numeral(number)but by TWO numerals.Keynes is the founder of the interval approach to probability.This is directly contrary to Runde's claim that Keynes's theory is strictly a qualitative (comparative)approach involving the use of ordinal rankings
column17: combined with some very special cases of numerical measurement involving frequencies and applications of  Keynes's principle of indifference.This would make Keynes's theory inoperative in the real world of actual decision making.Fortunately
column18: Ramsey and Runde are wrong.For Keynes
column19: it is the intervals themselves
column20: if they overlap in any way
column21: which are incomparable
column22: nonrankable
column23: and incommensurable.A simple example is to take the two probability interval estimates [.3
column25: .6].These two probabilities can't be ranked or compared.They are "nonnumerical" probabilities.Runde wastes the reader's time by presenting diagrams purporting to represent intervals without the use of any numbers. This conception has absolutely nothing to do with the approach to probability estimation presented in 1921 by Keynes in his TP.We can now summarise Keynes's approach. All probabilities are either point estimates
column26: involving single numbers
column27: or they are interval estimates
column28: involving two numbers.These latter proabilities can be called nonadditive
column29: imprecise or indeterminate probabilities
column30: as long as the Bayesian interpretation of imprecise is not imputed to Keynes.In chapter 26 of the TP
column31: Keynes incorporated his interval estimate approach into a method for technically dealing with expectations and decision theory.Keynes presented his conventional coefficient of risk and weight
column32: c.The goal of the decision maker is to maximize cA
column33: as opposed to pA
column34: expected value or pU(A)
column35: expected utility.c=p(1/(1+q)[2w/(1+w)].Both c and w
column36: which measures the completeness of the potential and actual amount of relevant evidence upon which the decision maker will base his calculation of an estimated probability
column37: are normalized on the unit interval [0
column38: 1].Naturally
column39: one will obtain a lower bound and an upper bound when using the c coefficient formula.This would then lead to a "nonnumerical" weighted value and/or "nonnumerical" mathematical expectation or expected value.All of this
column40: however
column41: is omitted in both Ramsey and Runde.The lesson to be learned is that papers should be carefully examined for errors by editors before they are accepted for publication.The only possible reason for purchasing this book would be if a potential reader wanted to compare the original 1995  Runde article with Runde's 2001 contribution in this volume and see if any learning from experience has occurred.My own opinion is that the reader would be better off just reading chapters 15 and 17 of the TP

column1: One reviewer of this book said that this book was a "recipe for appeasement" and that were the world to recommend genocide

column3: that this book would imply that this ought to be America's policy!  Well
column4: is that reviewer right about this book?  After reading the book
column5: I think the reviewer is right.    The author makes the point that opponents of the United States try to delegitimize us.  He's right; they do.  But the response to this ought to be to do what is best
column6: not to appease our enemies.  Appeasement generally makes matters worse for everyone.  I think if we have the ability to support truth
column7: justice
column8: human rights
column9: peace
column10: and prosperity
column11: we ought to do so
column12: even if it may sometimes mean battling thugs and tyrants.  The portion of this book that I'm best able to judge is about Israel.  I'm a Pagan and a Zionist.  And the author does a bad job of describing America's informal alliance with Israel.  He somewhat exaggerates the strength of the Israeli lobby here
column13: and in addition
column14: he makes it appear somewhat sinister
column15: as if it were causing America to support policies that are against our own interests.  In fact
column16: it is very difficult for small nations to convince us to act against our interests.  It is far easier for small nations to agree to do what we say (in an attempt to become or remain our allies) or for small nations to benefit from getting our support when America's enemies attack them.  Yes
column17: the Israeli lobby has done well
column18: but the main reason for this is that it has an excellent product to sell!  Israel is a nation which is being attacked by some reactionary and racist thugs and tyrants.  The nation most slandered by the United Nations and the international community is Israel.  No wonder plenty of decent people find it easy to support it.  The Israeli lobby isn't needed to convince most American opponents of all this slander and aggression.  Walt does not mention any of this
column19: of course.  There is a big difference between being in favor of human rights for all and supporting all policies of the State of Israel.   Walt certainly agrees.  But he implies that American Zionists tend to support the latter
column20: not the former.  And that's not true at all.  There's plenty of opposition by Zionists to specific Israeli policies
column21: and it is an anti-Zionist untruth to say that one can't object to Israeli government policies without running afoul of the Zionist lobby.  Such excuses are often used by those who deny Israel's right to exist (presumably in order to deny human rights to Levantine Jews) and then try to say that they merely disagree with some policies of the Israeli government.  In addition
column22: Walt fails to discuss the extent to which some American Jews disagree not only with Israeli policies
column23: but even with the idea that Israeli Jews ought not be denied human rights.  Walt implies that Israel wants "to impose an unjust solution unilaterally" to its dispute with the Arabs.  That's ridiculous.  If there is peace
column24: Israel wins: it gets to stay on the map and prosper on land it is making excellent use of.   That's why Israel is willing to put up with a solution which cheats the Jews out of land they would otherwise be entitled to keep or purchase.  It is anything but unjust to the Arabs to let Israel have less than its fair share of land!  Or to allow human rights for all the people of the region!  The author also comes up with the taunt that denying Arabs "their legitimate political rights has not made Israel safer."  That's outrageous.   There is no legitimate right to dissolve a neighboring nation and get rid of the human rights of its people.  And it does not make one "safer" to agree to get rid of one's human rights
column25: quite the contrary.  He's simply blaming Israel for the aggression and slander against it.  At one point
column26: Walt even asks "why should other Arabs believe that the United States is committed to freedom when its money and power are used to deny these rights to millions" of Levantine Arabs.  Well

column30:
Cross and Sampson use their tiny intellects to rush into the cabin, guns a blazing. Of course they don't hit anyone -- both need more target practice I think. There is way too much galantry and not enough thinking going on here.  Don't get me wrong, the whole book was entertaining and fast paced. But more so as a satire of a real police thriller. If you need a good laugh, pick this one up. If you're looking for something more intelligent or serious, definitely look elsewhere.

column1: I rented the film version of "A Home at the End of the World" shortly after catching the "The Hours" on cable. I was pretty impressed with both. My guess was that "The Hours" had the kind of budget and richness to capture the book
column2: whereas "A Home..." was a small independent film that had more handicaps. I figured the book on which it was based would be a better introduction to Cunningham
column3: because it had a better shot at being stronger than the film. Well
column4: sometimes the film is better....  The film really centers on Bobby and Jonathan. The book includes all of the main characters as narrators and has an overlapping narrative structure. Because of this
column5: the book fleshes out the female characters better and we see why Jonathan's mother was cast with Cissy Spacek rather than someone who seemed Midwestern and why Jonathan's father was so remote. Bobby's character has more sides
column6: although the result is that he is less vivid than Colin Ferrell's portrayal. The three-dimensionality in the book is probably more realistic
column7: but the film version of Bobby captures better that which is important--his odd mix of emotional distance
column8: engagement
column9: adaptability and ambiability. Beyond his sexual orientation
column10: Jonathan doesn't emerge very strongly in either medium.  The book oddly does worse in setting the time and place than the film. I grew-up in the Cleveland of the 60s and 70s and made many trips to New York in the 80s. Neither place fares well in the book. Cleveland was in approaching its nadir--an unhip place beginning a long economic decline
column11: yet also a place with vibrant music scene (that attracted many future "names" for their early tours)
column12: racial tension
column13: and the residue of various European ethnic cultures and rivalries---in other words
column14: it had atmosphere and it was a good launching pad to go someplace more "hip". The book protrays a generic place that is more like the inland
column15: second or third string cities of the Midwest--places like Columbus or Fort Wayne that are big on Babbitry and bragging about their chain restaurants. New York also seems oddly unlike itself. The New York of the book's era was filled with menace--crime
column16: fear of crime
column17: grafitti-filled subways
column18: filth
column19: and a general sense of dysfunction
column20: as well as the kind of energy
column21: vitality
column22: and avant garde spirit that have always drawn people to the City. The book could have taken place in the tiny bohemian quarter of Atlanta or some other provincial backwater
column23: for all it matters. The gay world of the book's time also is lacking--it takes place at beginning of the age of AIDS and the end of libertine gay liberation. Yet
column24: talk of AIDS is muted beyond the early denial of its presence and Jonathan has to be most sexless gay man in queer lit. Popular music plays a big role in the book
column25: but Cunningham seems to have drawn a random selection from hits lists of the 70s
column26: rather than combinations of music that fit in time or that would have appealed to a common audience. Although Cunningham grew-up in this era
column27: he clearly participated rather little in the popular culture of it.  The story proceeds like the movie
column28: with the addition of Erich
column29: Jonathan's  bartender "boyfriend" (the relationship is undefined and mysterious to both of them). Toward the end of the book
column30: Erich seems to be more of a plot device than a real person. The other characters take care of him as he convalesces
column31: but with an odd lack of commitment.   Few films or books are made about menage a trois relationships and fewer films ask us to buy Collin Ferrell as a twentysomething virgin. Yet
column32: the book came off as something far less than the film. The odd semi-sexual bond between Bobby and Jonathan was believable in the film but not in the book. Cissy Spacek took a truncated script and a thankless role in the film and communicated more about the mother's story than what we get in the book
column33: despite the greater backstory. The film does better without Erich and without the coyness about Jonathan's HIV status. I wish I could have given the book as many stars as most of the other reviews
column34: but by the time I finished
column35: I just was glad that the story had ended

column1: I found the book another rehash of the same theme: customers aren't all the same
column2: so you can't just push advertising at them anymore. Okay
column3: okay
column4: we know that already.   The authors seem enamored with complex and unnecessary terminology
column5: which I found tedious. the book is full of terms like "persuasion architecture
column6: business topology
column7: modalities
column8: and personas
column9: to name a few. I guess the more jargon you can use, the more you can charge. If that is what you are looking for, then it's a great book.  Remember geometry class and all those tedious proofs you had to go through, step by step. I could intuit the answers so had little patience for proofs. That's what this book reminded me of. In all it seemed to me to be an overly complex paint-by-numbers approach. Even so, it just *approaches* the subject but never really gets there. You can identify all the modalities and develop all the personas you want, but without the creavity to turn that information into compelling marketing, it doesn't help anything except the consultants' bottom lines.   I kept expecting the real meat" of the book to come
column10: but it never did for me. Perhaps it's because I'm already knowledgeable on the subject. With such a clever title
column11: I hoped there might be some nuggets
column12: but I found none. Some good ways to explain some issues to clients
column13: but that's about it.

column23: and no real mystery to solve made this book a huge disapointment

column1: This book is not really about creative people.  Instead
column2: it's about a host of left-wing causes such as environmentalism
column3: new age consciousness and feminism.  So
column4: it's really a book about left-wing politics.  Also
column5: to talk about this phenomenon as "new" is a bit of a misnomer.  For 100 years
column6: intellectuals such as Djilas have talked about the "new class" and its excessive influence over public life.  Perhaps the current dominance of the political left over culture industries is inadequate for the authors
column7: such that they would prefer a one-party dictatorship.  However
column8: this would be hard for them to do.  If there is in fact a new development in recent years
column9: it is the rise of new media such as the internet which have (in part) broken the one-party monopoly of the left-wing media.  Incidentally
column10: at 370 pages the book is way too long and tedious.  Also
column11: the research is typically poor--e.g. the unsupported chart on p. 211 that claims convergence of social and consciousness movements over the last 40 years--whereas the same converged left-wing bunch has been lobbying for this whole panoply of issues for decades.  Another example is the facile comparison between biological evolution and the life cycle of civilizations on p. 248.

column1: I read this book years ago when it was first published.  Mr. Sick allowed himself to be taken in by a collection of Iranian liars as well as some phonies claiming to have experience in intelligence.  Some of the people Sick listened to were shown in the Iran-Contra hearings to be con artists who also took in Ollie North and Bill Casey.  These con artists are experts at saying what the listener wants to hear.  One guy claimed to have been in Special Forces and was an eyewitness to one of VP-candidate Bush's flights to meet with Iranians.  It turns out that he was not in Special Forces at all and he had been dishonorably discharged from the US Army.  In addition
column2: he could not have been an eyewitness to the event he claims to have seen because he was in jail at the time.  The phony intelligence specialists have also been proven to be liars with no experience in intelligence or anything resembling national security work.  By the time I finished this book
column3: I actually felt sorry for Sick because he had allowed himself to be taken in by these jokers.  He clearly wanted to believe that what he was being told was true.  This book does not prove anything except that even an experienced researcher can be fooled if he really wants to believe.  Subsequent investigations by a Democratically dominated Congress proved that there was no October surprise

column1: I'm currently working through this book now as it's the required text for my General Chemistry course(s).  I have to say that I've had a harder time reading (and understanding) this text than usual.  I would not begin to recommend this book for general study
column2: but let's face it
column3: the only reason you're likely to buy this book is because it's required.  So here's how to use it:  Plan to read only one or two sections (4-5 pages per Section) in a study session.  Read it
column4: work through the solved problems
column5: skip to the problems covering that topic at the back of the chapter and see how well you do.  Buy the solutions manual - if you write out all your work (and you should
column6: will particularly help if you forget how to solve something and your professor gives an open book/note exam)
column7: looking over the worked solutions will help.  Write down questions on specific problems and parts of the text/chapter you didn't understand.  Ask a tutor or the instructor.  The text is a hard read
column8: but you -can- get through it. If I can do it
column9: so can you.

Fischer's attempts to analyze the influence of regional British folkways in colonial America holds much promise. Sadly
column2: he uses
column3: however
column4: a simplistic and often contradictory interpretive methodology.     Much of his information on such vague topics as "freedom" ways is anctedotal. His maps of regional origins for colonists tend to contradict his findings. A case in point is his analysis of the so-called Cavalier society of Virginia. His map indicates a substantial Welsh component to the servant population. The Welsh
column5: like the Irish and the Scots
column6: are either ignored altogether or given cursory attention in the creation of a Tuckahoe [i.e. Virginian] identity. Admittedly
column7: the English did dominate Virginia numerically
column8: the contributions of the latter
column9: however
column10: particularly in the Northern Neck cannot be underestimated. The contribution of Northern English
column11: the primary creators of Fischer's fourth folkway
column12: to the Chesapeake population is also an issue that raises problems for Fischer's analysis as does the contribution of West Countrymen to New England.        In his analysis of backcountry folkways he relies heavily on McWhiney's "Cracker Culture
column13: a particularly problematic book, and McDonald and McWhiney's Celtic theory of Southern culture and the so-called Highland zone theory of British history. Fischer ignores the contribution of low country white immigrants from Virginia and Pennsylvania Quakers to the the formation of Appalachian culture, not to mention the Germans. The Germans, in particular, may have contributed to the pastoral agricultural traditions of the Southern Appalachians. Finally, the role of African Americans in the formation of Southern society is never adequately explored.      Also, some of the information he employs in presenting his case about the so-called North Britons in the Backcountry is drawn from William Byrd's History of the Dividing Line. The individuals encountered by Byrd were infact drawn from Culture Number 2. Because Byrd's expedition through the Southside of Virginia pre-dated the later arrival of Scots-Irish and other PA settlers in places like Lunenberg or Mecklenberg county.      As a native of the Shenandoah Valley, and a product of cultures number 2 and 4, I personally found this premise fascinating. The English, because of their numbers and historical position in American culture, tend to be ignored as an ethnic group. So in this regard, Fischer's premise is sound, in the exploration of the ethno-cultural contributions of English folk cultures to American regionalism. Fischer's introductory descriptions of the environments encountered by the colonists is another example of promise not kept, when he downplays the role of creolization and adaptation to the new environment. But the broad generalizations Fischer employs detracts from the final product.      I was pleasantly surprised by Fischer's second book Bound Away." For individuals interested in the process
column14: in particular
column15: by which Englishmen became Virginians I would recommend: 1. Alan Kulikoff's article "The Colonial Chesapeake: Seedbed of Antebellum Southern Culture?'"Journal of Southern History
column17: 513-40.  2. Alan Kulikoff's "Tobacco and Slaves" (1986). 3. Terry Jordon-Bychkov
column18: "The Upland South: The Making of an American Folk Region and Landscape." I have problems with Jordan-Bychkov's Finnish contribution theory and the number of Upper Souther "mestizos" that the author posits. But the author maintains the traditional 3-part theory of John C. Campbell about Appalachian origins
column19: namely: "Scots-Irish
column20: Virginian/Carolinian [i.e. lowland whites] and Swiss-German.  4.Elizabeth A. Perkins and John Dabney Shane, Border Life: Experience and Memory in the Revolutionary Ohio Valley" A fascinating account of one of the first frontiers where individuals from the different "regions
column21: in particular cultures number 2 and 4 came together.  On the positive side I would recommend his analysis of child-rearing techniques. In particular his analysis of the so-called will bending" as practised in Virginia. According to Fischer Virginians raised their sons to be both independent
column22: assertive males
column23: yet at the same time kept them economically and emotionally bound to their fathers. In this world daughters were taught to be submissive. Yet
column24: as Fischer shows
column25: Virginian daughters did not always conform to this social paradigm and with the sons this created an emotional paradox that had strong social implications. In this one example it is possible to see the way in which Fischer weaves together Anthropological and Historical methodology seamlessly.  In general the book is very readable and Fischer's arguments
column26: whether you agree with them or not
column27: are not hard to discern.

column1: First of all
column2: consider the question that Lewis is trying to ask. What went wrong with the 'Middle East' and their 'failure' to modernize? And now think about how big this book is
column3: about 150 pages. The 'Middle East' is a huge area extending from Morocco to Iran and he attempts to explain their 'failure' to modernize by reviewing the last years of the Ottoman Empire. That is just plain lazy work on the part of a historian who is supposed to be revered in his field.   Another issue is that he constantly refers to the 'Middle East' as 'Islam' as though Islam is homogenous or even centered in the Ottoman Empire. Granted the Sultan of the Ottoman Empire was also the Caliph but the Twelver Shi'is don't consider him to be legitimate anyway. To consider Islam to have some kind of collective thought process when encountering the 'West' is reprehensible. Consider now the fact that the majority of Muslims don't even live in the Middle East or the Ottoman Empire. How can Lewis truthfully use the term 'Islam' in his book to refer to the entity that 'went wrong' when the area he's speaking about doesn't even constitute the majority of Muslims in the world!?   This book is a quick read for people who aren't in the field to think that they're informed about what is going on in the scary area known as the 'Middle East'. The worst part is that the only people who would know that this is full of holes and lacking greatly in background and professionalism are the people who wouldn't normally read it anyway. This is a dangerous book because the name Bernard Lewis is synonymous with Expert in Middle East affairs. This was a lazy
column4: half hearted attempt to cash in on people's ignorance and only perpetuates the wrong ideas in people's minds. Bad Lewis
column5: very very bad. Any 'liberal historian' who suggests this book should be beaten with this book
column6: unfortunately for us the book is very thin so it will take a while to bring him down with it.  If you want better sources
column7: look to John Esposito
column8: Albert Hourani and Nikki Keddie. All of them have published widely and lack the obvious political biases of Bernard Lewis. Check them out.

column1: I bought this movie because I love to see an old tale tespun and retold. If it is done well there is nothing better to read or watch. This movie is not a retelling of "Beauty and the Beast" as its title and premise would indicate. I own several versions of "Beauty and the Beast" on DVD and in print. And after reading the reviews here I was really looking forward to adding this movie to my collection and I was excited to have the chance to watch this movie. I thought it was going to be great! BUT IT IS THE WORST MOVIE I HAVE EVER PURCHASED. I was prepared for the horses and I was prepared for the nudity and the eroticism. I was not prepared for the filmmaker's mangling of "Beauty and the Beast".  That is what the blurb on the box suggests. But instead of getting the Beauty and the Beast message of the redeeming power of love
column2: you get a half-hearted sermon against bestiality. I didn't know that was such a problem in this world. I mean I have never had the urge and I don't know of anyone who has. There have been no reports on the news about people sexually assaulting livestock that I have heard. I am sure I would have heard something if such was the case. There is no excuse for what Borowczyk has done here. The movie starts out slow
column3: I can forgive that
column4: I have an attention span (too many people don't.) The story starts to pick up momentum and promise when the beast appears. Then the story heads for the cliff and unhesitatingly dives off! I saw the kernel of a good movie here. WHAT HAPPENED? Do yourself a favor. Skip this one

Sir Leycester Coltman was Head of the Foreign Office's Latin America Department
column2: then Ambassador to Cuba (1991-94)
column3: then to Colombia (1994-98). But as this mean-minded book shows
column4: this hardly qualified him to write `the real' biography of Fidel Castro.   This book gives the Foreign Office view
column5: brimming with anti-trade union
column6: anti-national and anti-communist sneers. For example
column7: he casts doubts on Fidel's brother's parentage
column8: citing as evidence Raul's `slanted oriental eyes'
column9: but even the book's photos disprove this.   Coltman patronisingly assumes that Britain can give lessons in democracy to Cuba
column10: but how many of us voted Mandelson an EU Commissioner? Coltman smugly assumes that capitalism means progress
column11: but capitalism
column12: a mode of production
column13: does not make technological innovations or scientific advances: the working class makes them all. He cannot describe US imperialism and the illegal US blockade without putting the offending words in inverted commas.  He claims that the Macmillan government's decision to sell the Cuban dictator Batista warplanes and tanks was `commercial rather than political'
column14: because Britain's economic situation was `desperate'.  When Macmillan refused to sell Hawker Hunter fighters to Castro to defend Cuba against imminent US aggression
column15: the situation was presumably not so desperate. Kennedy's illegal assault on Cuba showed that Bush's practice of unilateral
column16: aggressive war is nothing new.  Cuba's eight million people have sustained independence and sovereignty
column17: repelling all efforts to interfere in their internal affairs. So Fidel rightly opposed the Sandinistas' 1989 decision to bow to US-EU demands to hold multi-party elections in Nicaragua: the Sandinistas even let the US government fund the opposition.   He warned
column18: "Some people think they can save socialism by making concessions. They fail to take account of the voracious mentality of imperialism and of the reactionary forces. If you give them part of a fingernail
column19: they will want part of your finger; if you give them a piece
column20: they will want the whole finger; if you give them the finger
column21: they will ask for the forearm; if you give them the forearm
column22: they will ask for the arm; and when you give them the arm
column23: they will chop off your head."

column1: I cannot justify simply giving this album such a poor review without a history lesson
column2: at least as I see it from my perspective
column3: especially given that I have traditionally enjoyed VNV Nation's music among my favorites.  VNV Nation used to have this elusive
column4: captivating quality that set their music apart from cut-and-copy EBM.  I really don't know how to describe it; I think I once called it "conceptual continuity" when talking with a friend.  VNV's older albums
column5: like "Advance and Follow" and "Praise the Fallen
column6: were alive with creativity, originality and potency, easily making them the forerunners in quality EBM in the mid-to-late 1990s.  I daresay that VNV's first three albums were better than Front 242's Up Evil" and "Off
column7: making them basically the new heirs to 242's old position, which was only solidified when 242's last album was a mishmash of experimentation and hard trance (although it was undeniably brilliant, it was a definite genre shift).  Fast forward to Futureperfect."  This was an album of higher highs and lower lows than any of VNV Nation's previous releases -- the bright spots were practically blinding
column8: especially on tracks like "Electronaut."  Simultaneously
column9: there were songs that were just outright bad -- "Liebestod" and "Holding On" were respectively out of place and of poor quality in general.  Some of the other songs
column10: like "Epicentre
column11: were toss-ups.  The tour supporting the release of their Live DVD Pastperfect" was astounding.  After seeing them live and watching the DVD afterwards
column12: I had high hopes for the next release
column13: "Matter + Form."  Those hopes were dashed by the album's complete lack of focus
column14: increasing amounts of formulaic music ("Entropy" could be on the soundtrack of any generic sci-fi shooter and not feel out of place in the least)

column16: and when I got the album itself I was immensely disappointed -- apart from maybe 3 or 4 good songs

column18: not from any respectable electronic act.  However

column10: state

column14: but our opinions on capitalism surely must deserve
column15: at the least

column18: the conclusions are
column19: in typical academic fashion
column20: sadly naive.  An example is their belief that property taxes are somehow less onerous than income taxes.  This is a position in opposition to the authors' defense of property rights.  Indeed

column22: based solely on business property

column24: lawyers
