column1: This is an important document for those who will someday write a serious non-polemical history of the McIntyre / IHM conflict. As such it deserves more than one star.  Antia Caspary (Mother Humiliata) lead the IHM nuns during their confrontation with Los Angeles Cardinal McIntire over nuns wearing religious garb
column2: living in community
column3: and their terms of service in the diocesan schools of Los Angeles. This conflict lead to the sisters presenting demands unacceptable to the bishop and his request that they leave the schools of his diocese.  Caspary's book gives her version of the conflict -- as is the role of a memoir.  The world it reveals gives one pause
column4: it is a Manichean dystopia of pure evil and pure good.  McIntyre and the "male hierarchy" are corrupt wicked men with no redeeming qualities. The sisters who sided with Caspary are without any stain
column5: the only real Christians
column6: flawed only by perhaps occasional fearfulness in following her lead.  Sadly
column7: there are glaring omissions that leave the reader misinformed or uninformed: there is nothing about the role of the famous Maslow-Rogers sensitivity sessions that played such a large role in polarizing the congregation and fostering the self-assertive and uncompromising tone that characterized (as is clear in the book) the nuns confrontations with the bishop. Missing too are the 50 nuns that reestablished the IHMs in spite of the powerful influence of group think. Missing again is anything kind of context
column8: such as what actually happened to other sisters' congregations that adopted the IHM model (polarization and then extinction mostly).  To read this memoir is to step back into the late 1960s
column9: when every Catholic nun and priest was absolutely certain that they know exactly what Vatican II meant (because they had read Xavier Rynne
column10: if not the council documents) and so was empowered to tell everyone else what to do.  Her apologia reveals remarkable similarity of attitude between poor old-fashioned Irish pastor McIntyre and the "up-to-date sister" Anita.  Both were intolerant of those who disagreed and dismissive of other's views. Both were self-righteous (Anita
column11: as is obvious from this book
column12: and McIntyre
column13: if we can trust her characture of him) and incapable of self-criticism. And it seems one of them still is: even though McIntyre's successor has apologized to the Caspary's Immaculate Heart Commuity (see p. 200) for his mishandling of the confrontation
column14: Anita has no apologies for anyone.  She has always been right and always will be.  "It is better to rule in Hell than to serve in Heaven" --Milto

I disagree with others who thought it was difficult to adjust the item around the harness straps and that it was cheaply made.  I installed the sack and made the adjustment one-time.  The material allows weather and some liquids to just roll right off the fabric.      I would consider this a must for any first-time moms (as I was) on their registry.  The price definitely a lot higher than I would like to see it
column2: but still a must if you can afford to make the purchase.

column1: The Junie B. Jones series represents thoughtful storytelling replete with the sorts of syntactic and semantic errors that all thoughtful parents try to stamp out of their children's discourse conventions. For example
column2: my multilingual daughter
column3: a second grader in an international school in Japan
column4: incessantly mixes Korean
column5: Japanese and English grammars and meanings
column6: not to mention reproducing the very colloquial forms of casual spoken English I'm always encouraging her to readjust in agreement with more standardized forms.  The typical difficulties that young native speakers of English have in moving
column7: say
column8: from the comparative to the superlative or in adjusting tense forms in regular and irregular verbs are codified throughout this series. Those who might object to this critique would also have to defend why errors such as those referenced here occur not only in the dialogues among the characters
column9: but also in the expository portions of the stories. The author makes no effort to encourage her young readers to see the differences between colloquial forms and the more widely accepted standardized forms.  Thanks to Ms. Park's efforts
column10: young children honing their language skills now have an opportunity to model the varieties that society generally deplores. Though her stories are delightfully cute
column11: her methods do not further the kinds of knowledge that the larger society will come to expect from informed citizens. If her editor hasn't yet been dismissed
column12: I would encourage Ms. Park to reflect a bit more on her approach to educational texts.

column1: This has to be the most boring book I have ever read. Well
column2: I haven't quite finished it yet as it's taking forever to push my way through it. And I'm sure that more boring books exist
column3: I just haven't read them.    I wanted to learn about KKR and LBOs - particularly as a division of KKR recently bought one of the vendors supplying my own employer. I was hoping for the big picture of what took place as well as some entertaining anecdotes. But this book consists largely of page after page of uninteresting minutiae of conversations between the various parties involved. There really is no need for such detail and a little bit of editing could have halved the size of the book without losing any essential information. And a bit of theoretical discussion would have been far more valuable than some of the biographical material. It felt a bit like watching someone else's home video. It probably means a lot to the people involved
column4: especially as they'll get the in jokes and quirks of the participants
column5: but it's painfully boring for strangers forced to watch it out of politeness.  I'm sure that much of the conversation is fiction anyway. People don't reliably remember this level of detail of converstaions over a period of years. What are remembered are broad brushstrokes - and this is what the author should have written.  There are occasional moments of entertainment - like Ted Forstmann obsessing about the evils of junk bonds. But most of the characters seem quite flat and uninteresting.   The fact is: I wanted some of this information in this book. As it provided some of this
column6: albeit with a lot of suffering on my part
column7: I'll give it two stars.  Update: Well I did finish this book eventually. My final opinion is much the same

column1: While Dr. Grandin's poignant unraveling of the mysteries of autism deserves the accolades it has received
column2: her perspectives on animals are deeply tainted by her research into "humane" slaughter techniques
column3: which ultimately have an economic rather than a purely scientific rationale. After all
column4: the meat industry cares not one iota about whether animals are treated humanely or not
column5: only whether they can be "disassembled" as quickly and efficiently as possible. Thus
column6: while Grandin's work may indeed make the treatment of farm animals more humane when they reach their brutal demise
column7: it nevertheless facilitates the expansion of an industry that is anything but humane
column8: bringing ever greater numbers of animals under the sway of its remorseless logic of bloodthirsty death. History does not judge the petty functionaries of the Final Solution
column9: the ones who devised more efficient means of killing human beings
column10: to be heroes; nor should history judge Temple Grandin to be a savior of animals. If her concern for animals goes as deep as she claims it does
column11: she should turn the wealth she garners from the meat industry against its practices
column12: donating all of her meat industry earnings to animal rights causes. Ultimately that is the only way she can begin to free herself of the moral stain of responsibility for the brutal death of innocent creatures

column1: Despite liking a couple of his movies
column2: I've never been a fan of Preston Sturges
column3: and a second viewing of Unfaithfully Yours did nothing to change that. With rare exceptions like Frasier or Comme une Image
column4: most supposedly `sophisticated' comedies are usually either too clever by half or not half as clever as they think they are: this definitely falls into the latter category. It may be slightly more articulate
column5: but it still comes down to pratfalls and clichés clumsily dispensed (not to mention an incredibly one-dimensional role for Linda Darnell as the wife whose sole reason for existence seems to be to worship her husband). Unfortunately it soon becomes apparent that despite his confidence in the early part of the film
column6: Rex Harrison is entirely wrong for the part: aside from being so incredibly unsympathetic that he simply alienates you for most of the film
column7: he has absolutely no facility for physical comedy
column8: which renders what could and should have been a great comic setpiece where he accidentally trashes his hotel room far more thoroughly than any rock star ever could even dream of rather tedious and protracted. (Alfred Newman's surprisingly crudely over the top slide-whistle and horn 'comic' underscoring all but stones the scene to death
column9: a surprising lapse of judgment from a great composer in a film revolving around classical music.) In the hands of an actor with a modicum of physical comedy timing it could have been gold
column10: but instead it's almost reduced to a technical exercise.  But the same could be said for much of the film. The idea of having the execution and resolution of Harrison's fantasies dictated by the pace of the music he conducts (Rossini for murder
column11: Wagner for mournful forgiveness
column12: Tchaikovsky for suicide) is inspired
column13: but it results in scenes that feel forced
column14: as if at the mercy of a galley slave master's drumbeat. That the scenes themselves are so predictable doesn't help
column15: as goodwill and admiration gradually gives way to boredom in the second half.  There are
column16: however
column17: two saving graces. One is the scene in private detective Edgar Kennedy's office
column18: where Harrison is furious to discover that the man he has come to castigate is a knowledgeable fan with his own tale of loss. The scene is crudely performed and reads better than it plays
column19: but there's heart and humanity there that's lacking in too much of the rest of the film. But the film's genuine standout moment is the orchestra rehearsal
column20: one of the best pieces of filmed musical performance in the movies
column21: not only showing how the music is constructed but showing the life
column22: character and human soul behind it. The loss of those qualities in the rest of the movie is all the more keenly felt in an increasingly arid and overplayed technical exercise.

column1: This is one of those rare treats in the literary world that grab your attention
column2: keep you enthralled
column3: and refuse to let you stop reading.  I read this book and literally did not sleep one night because I was too busy trying to finish the book.  But what makes this book so rare is not because of how good it is
column4: but it's because how good everything is until the very end.  That's right
column5: the incredible cop-out of an ending made me mad enough to hate the entire novel.  This is "deus ex machina" in its finest form.  This is unexcusable in my opinion.  I just don't get it.  I just don't understand how one can (seemingly) work so hard on a work of fiction only to screw everyone in the final pages.  I gave it two stars (as opposed to one) for fooling everyone into reading through this book.  This is by far and away my most dissappointing reading ever

column1: This has to be the most boring book I have ever read. Well
column2: I haven't quite finished it yet as it's taking forever to push my way through it. And I'm sure that more boring books exist
column3: I just haven't read them.    I wanted to learn about KKR and LBOs - particularly as a division of KKR recently bought one of the vendors supplying my own employer. I was hoping for the big picture of what took place as well as some entertaining anecdotes. But this book consists largely of page after page of uninteresting minutiae of conversations between the various parties involved. There really is no need for such detail and a little bit of editing could have halved the size of the book without losing any essential information. And a bit of theoretical discussion would have been far more valuable than some of the biographical material. It felt a bit like watching someone else's home video. It probably means a lot to the people involved
column4: especially as they'll get the in jokes and quirks of the participants
column5: but it's painfully boring for strangers forced to watch it out of politeness.  I'm sure that much of the conversation is fiction anyway. People don't reliably remember this level of detail of converstaions over a period of years. What are remembered are broad brushstrokes - and this is what the author should have written.  There are occasional moments of entertainment - like Ted Forstmann obsessing about the evils of junk bonds. But most of the characters seem quite flat and uninteresting.   The fact is: I wanted some of this information in this book. As it provided some of this
column6: albeit with a lot of suffering on my part
column7: I'll give it two stars.  Update: Well I did finish this book eventually. My final opinion is much the same

column1: Claiming to have recovered what the church has lost since the days of Augustine
column2: Gregory Boyd proposes an alternate view to spiritual warfare that looks at our struggles through lenses that deny the sovereignty of God.  Readers should be alarmed when a modern theologian writes off nearly 1500 years of orthodox thinking to formulate his new ideas.  Rejecting the traditional view that God is unchanging through time and that God knows the future (see page 49)
column3: Boyd's book offers little hope when we find ourselves in the battles.  For example
column4: in speaking of Job he talks about how God was "surprised" at what occurred (page 147).  Despite claims of having a high view of Scripture
column5: Boyd's treatment of the text shows otherwise.  He speaks of Isaiah "reworking the cultural stories" to create his biblical accounts (159).  Boyd goes on to claim that much of the Old Testament conceptions of Satan are merely the reworking of pagan myths.  If all Scripture is really God breathed (see 2 Timothy 3:16)
column6: I personally struggle to see how such words are adaptations of pagan myths.    In light of the dismissal of orthodox understandings on spiritual warfare
column7: God
column8: and the Bible
column9: what does a reader take away from God at War?  The reader can only come away with a sense that there is a theological dualism where the opposing forces of God and Satan are battling for an undecided outcome (a view that is in clear contrast to the decisive victory of God seen in Revelation).  As a result
column10: the book presents little more than the idea behind the Star Wars movies - You have the force and dark side competing without a clear sense of who will ultimately win and without a god being in control of all things.  Such a conclusion is a natural outcome of Boyd's belief.  If you are not familiar with Boyd
column11: he is a prominent open-theist
column12: an individual who believes that God does not know the future.    Not all is bad in this book.  Boyd does make a strong case for the necessity of prayer.  He also recognizes the reality of spiritual warfare and the demonic
column13: something many evangelical Christians ignore.  However
column14: such truths are overshadowed by the misconstrued notions as God as not knowing the future
column15: parts of Scripture resulting from pagan myths
column16: and a theology of warfare that more resembles a Hollywood movie than the God of the Bible.  In light of these problems it is hard to recommend God at War to you.  As an alternative
column17: let me suggest Chuck Lawless' books Spiritual Warfare (from Lifeway Publishers) and Discipled Warriors (from Kregal Publications).  Both recognize the reality of warfare but do so with biblical support and in a way that glorifies God and helps us live for His glory

column1: I should start by saying I am a big Clive Cussler fan and have read all his books.  The only ones I have not enjoyed are the two Oregon Files ones. I reached the point of not caring anyway and just kept reading to get to the end.  The whole thing reads like a Mission Impossible TV episode but nowhere near as good or exciting.  The scenes in the UK were very sloppy; there are no such things as pound notes and the beefeaters actually guard the Tower of London not Buckingham Palace.  I can only hope that it is Craig Dirgo that is the problem and that when the next Oregon Files book comes out written by Jack DuBrul (who I am a great fan of in his own right) that things will improve

column1: I was very disappointed in this book because I felt like the title itself is very misleading. The title of the book is called "FREE MONEY From the Federal Governement for SMALL BUSINESSES AND ENTREPRENEURS" By  Laurie Blum. The book description clearly states that there are hundreds of  millions of dollars available FREE!  to small business and entrepreneurs
column2: when in fact the only thing that I found in this book pertaining to small  businesses were LOANS and ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS
column3: and the last time I checked  LOANS are not free. This book description needs to be more clear as to what  kinds of grants are available and the title "FREE MONEY" should  not be used when this book is filled with mostly loan options. From reading  the book description I was under the impression that this was a book filled  with nothing but grant information!  I was very disappointed and  unsatisfied with this book. If I'm wrong or misunderstood this book please  fill free to correct me and direct me to the pages where the business  grants are supposed to be located

column1: One of the fun aspects of reading serial mystery series is that there are actually two things that you follow as the reader. The first is the murder mystery that is the point of the story and that you try to match wits with the detective and try to identify the perpetrator - i.e. the "whodunit" aspect. The second is that you get involved with the repetitive characters and follow their lives and developments.  The Joe Grey mysteries are no different in this respect in that early on in the series we learned about Joe's and Dulcie's remarkable abilities and we see them exercise these in every volume as they solve the various crimes that are committed in and around Molena Point.  In Cat to the Dogs
column2: we have essentially only half of a book. Oh
column3: I do not mean that you only read 100 pages instead of 200! No
column4: what I mean is that you only get to read the soap opera aspects and there is no mystery!  The book starts with the murder and the reader knows that Joe Grey knows within the first five pages that there was a murder and that it was committed by a man. By the end of the first chapter you already know who the murdere was although his full name is not revealed until later on in the book.   The author tries to compensate for this by throwing in one more murder and two attempted murders as well as several other crimes
column5: but all the mystery of "whodunit" is completely and utterly missing.  So
column6: if you want to know more about Clyde
column7: Charlie
column8: Wilma
column9: Max Harper and the rest of the gang; if you want to read the volume that introduces Kit to the mix
column10: then this is one you want to read. If
column11: on the other hand
column12: you do not have the background on the base characters and their locations
column13: and do not care to read more about these remarkable critters
column14: then you can safely leave this one behind.

column1: I purchased my version of El Hazard from a zShop for 19 bucks and I am SO glad that I did. That said
column2: the first series is worth watching for two main reasons: overt lesbianism and Jinnai. The former is self-explanatory while the latter (Jinnai) is without a doubt the best character in the series (despite the fact that he is the antagonist). You can't say that any of the characters are very deep or well developed
column3: but throughout the first series Jennai is by far the most satisfyingly fleshed-out character
column4: as well as the most ammusing and true to his nature. This superiority is all the more appearant when he is contrasted with story's main character who is shallowly developed and in no way engaging. And this is what makes the second series (all four dismal episodes) so tragic: they nerfed Jinnai. He could never have been called a genius in the first series
column5: but he was decidedly intelligent
column6: cool
column7: pragmatic
column8: supremely self-confident and an effective leader (even though he was also manic and delusional). In El Hazard II
column9: as if in response to the world recoiling at the sight of a humorous though competent villain
column10: they have turned Jinnai into a slapstick-idiot persuing his increasingly nebulous ambition with foolish abandon. I suggest purchasing El Hazard through...alternate means
column11: ... watching the first series and discarding the second. Let's face it: even lesbian humor gets old when the writing sucks and the characters are empty

column1: Leslie Downer is a cultural tourist who set out to "play geisha"-- as seen in her cheezy author's photographs
column2: being servile to a Japanese gentleman-- an insult to a profession of exquisite grace and artistry that requires YEARS of intensive training!  Both the author's information and her perspective on it are highly suspect!  She has a remarkable degree of thinly veiled disrespect for the culture she sets out to study
column3: continually complaining about the rudeness of the Japanese when she's the person who approaches them rudely in the first place
column4: with a condescending view of geisha!  She also goes to great length to try to convince the reader of her expertise
column5: and how little scholarship has been done on the subject-- and cites well-respected works by others in her bibliography
column6: ones that far surpass her understanding of the subject.  Case in point: Jodi Cobb's photo-journalistic opus GEISHA. It intimately captures the world and mood of a realm Downer tries to describe without ever realy experiencing-- and without the arrogant self-insert

column1: I originally read this book for a class in college
column2: but was unable to  finish it due to deadlines.  With more time on my hands
column3: I picked up the  book recently and attempted to read through it.  I found the book had a  great deal of history
column4: including names
column5: dates
column6: and facts that are difficult  to find elsewhere.  However
column7: the book was very difficult to read due to the  style.  It was very long and monotonous and I found myself getting very  bored with it at times.  Lewis should have written with a style that  engaged the reader more since many of the interesting facts were lost in  the endlessly long discussions about each black writer.  Also
column8: the book  included many of the writers in the Harlem Rennaissance
column9: but it barely  talked about Harlem at all.  Many of the writers during the Harlem  Rennaissance did not even live in Harlem.  It seemed to be more of a  history about African Americans in the literary world at that time.  I  picked up the book because I wanted to read about Harlem -- not the Harlem  Rennaissance.  I wanted to read about the everyday residents of Harlem.   Overall
column10: the book had some interesting facts
column11: but it is a very boring read  and very difficult to sift through.  If you ever got bored reading your  history textbooks
column12: I would not recommend this book since it is written in  the same style

column1: I have spent a lot of time with the Renovare Spiritual Formation Bible over the past two months.  I am disappointed. I bought the Bible primarily because of my appreciation of Richard Foster's previous works
column2: especially The Celebration of Discipline. I had never spent much time with a NRSV translation before
column3: and this translation is my main disappointment with the Renovare Bible.  The National Council of Churches' energetic attempt to completely remove gender-related words and language in the NRSV has given this translation a strong "politically correct"
column4: rather than "inspirationally correct"
column5: tenor. I have had to conclude that the NRSV translation is basically dishonest with respect to the original inspirations of the Greek and Hebrew.     So
column6: I found myself using my favorite translation
column7: the ESV
column8: with the Renovare's Spiritual Discipline Index and Suggested Ways to Use (the Renovare Bible) for Spiritual Formation.  That works
column9: but I would just as soon have the Index
column10: Suggested Ways
column11: along with the generally good Introduction and With-God sections
column12: as stand-alone material. The online downloadable guide (at Renovare's website)
column13: "Studies in the With-God Life. Exploring the Renovare Spiritual Formation Bible" by Jan Johnston is also useful - you can still pursue the subject of spiritual formation by substituting another translation and eliminating the NRSV.   As a previous reviewer pointed out
column14: there is a distinct flavor of ecumenism and pantheism in many of the introductions and profiles done by the 51 contributors.

column8: but as this books goes along
column9: it seems obvious that SK was losing interest
column10: either because he found the two lead characters too limiting for whatever reason
column11: and wanted to 'explore' the supporting characters more; or simply because this book came out fairly early in King's career
column12: when he was known to partake of certain 'substances' which he later swore off! Worth reading only if you really want to read every SK novel. Otherwise
column13: just be glad that nearly every book he wrote after this one(with the exception of the two mentioned above) surpasses 'Firestarter'

Let me start by saying that I may need to quit listening to the opinions of some of my co-workers in regards to movies to watch
column2: at least when it comes to the horror genre. Numerous people where I work told me that this movie
column3: "The Descent" was absolutely one of the best horror movies ever to be made.  In their defense
column4: my co-workers weren't the only people with this opinion
column5: many critics and other moviegoers said the same thing.  Well
column6: apparently the hype that was built up for me regarding this movie was more than the film could live up to
column7: because I was sorely disappointed
column8: but more on that later
column9: for now I will give you my plot summary for last year's supposed horror spectacular
column10: "The Descent"  "The Descent" begins with a young woman on vacation with her family and friends
column11: when her husband and her daughter suffer a tragic accident. One year later at the prodding of those same friends
column12: she accompanies them on a spelunking adventure
column13: the problem is none of her friends have ever been to this cave
column14: in fact it's a newly discovered cave that no one has explored as yet.  So as they attempt to explore the unexplored these brave young women become trapped in the cave.  Making matters worse
column15: this cave is not like any ordinary cave
column16: for this one is inhabited by bloodthirsty mutant creatures who have just found their next meal.  At the beginning of watching this movie I was really interested in the developing story
column17: and the shocking opener really caught my attention
column18: giving me a sense that this movie is going to be different than most horror movies by actually giving you the unexpected.  However
column19: once the story gets to the part where the girls are inside the cave
column20: which is actually where the majority of the film takes place
column21: things begin to go awry for the picture.  At first
column22: the filmmakers were doing a good job of using the claustrophobic atmosphere
column23: giving the audience a sense of entrapment and anxiety which served to heighten the suspense regarding the possibility of impending doom.  Then the filmmakers introduce a fact that I felt completely derailed the movie
column24: this is a cave that no one has been in
column25: and these girls are hardly professional.  So
column26: who in their right mind would put all of their friends lives in possible jeopardy just to be the first to explore a newly discovered cave.  It's absolutely stupid
column27: especially when placed viewed in the context of the character's interaction and companionship with each other
column28: none of these girls would do this to each other. After this occurs the mutants show up
column29: a plot point that I was hoping would help put the movie back in the right direction; however
column30: this is where the movie begins to unwind even faster
column31: because it's now just one gory scene after another
column32: and the movie is nothing more than your average monster movie.  A decision I somewhat agreed with
column33: yet still didn't agree with was the decision to keep the mutants origins unknown.  On the one hand this served to add to the mystery of why they are attacking these girls
column34: you just assume they're cannibalistic
column35: but on the other it would have been nice to know how they got there.  Even though "The Descent" was hyped as being one of the best horror movies of recent time
column36: by both my friends and many critics and moviegoers
column37: to me it was merely another average addition to a genre that is already full of mediocrity.  "The Descent" is unrated and contains violence and language

column1: As a graduate student specializing in religion I found this book wanting. If you're looking for a "soft" approach to finding spirituality in popular culture

column1: Let me start by explaining the title of my review: being an Indian (settled in India
column2: not outside) I am incessantly perplexed by the plethora or completely rubbish books from India which the West just can't seem to get enough of. Books which say nothing about India
column3: and are not about it. Just books set in India
column4: which throw in some curry and some local language
column5: and somehow thus make people fall all over themselves in an attempt to praise the book. My gut revolts against such partisanship
column6: and this is one of those books which is a perfect example of this rubbish trend
column7: and hence is going to get such deserving treatment at my hands.  But let me start by going back a bit in time and giving credit where it's due: after reading his first two books
column8: I came to the very early conclusion that Vikram Chandra was the narrator's Narrator
column9: a storyteller of uncommon brilliance
column10: a weaver of magic tales. On the flip side
column11: like most other Chandra fans
column12: I too was frustrated by his ability to end every one of his stories in the worst all of all possible ways; but I loved his craft nonetheless. I had almost convinced myself that with his next book
column13: I'd stop about 10% before the end of the book
column14: and with Sacred Games
column15: that promise turned out to be very easy to fulfill - I managed to put the book down without dying of guilt about halfway through itself.  Sacred Games is a book about nothing: there are no characters who feel real
column16: it is not about the protagonists' environment
column17: it doesn't rotate around or shed new light on any events
column18: and it doesn't deal with any objects of fascination. Nothing. Nil. Zilch. Nada. A lot of people have talked about this as another of the
column19: if not the definitive Bombay book
column20: but having lived there myself
column21: I can vouch for the fact that this book doesn't even begin to capture an iota of the character or the essence of Bombay. (If you really want to read about the city
column22: read "Shantaram" - now that's a book!) In fact
column23: I think one of the lowest points of the book is how it fails to create any context - the events of this book could almost have happened anywhere
column24: at almost any point in time. (And no
column25: that does not make it timeless - just outright insipid.) Simple mechanisms like linkages to some real-life events would have given the reader something to hold on to - but no
column26: Mr. Chandra refuses to give any straws to the drowning. Reviewers have gone ga-ga over it's portrayal of the Bombay Mafia
column27: but there is nothing said here which is even remotely new
column28: and there isn't the slightest different twist to it. Dons
column29: corrupt policemen
column30: actors
column31: dancing girls
column32: slums
column33: and smuggling - everything has been told
column34: and told much better.   A stunningly stupid highlight of this book is the copious usage of local language without any glossary to help the readers understand what the terms mean. I have almost been a local there
column35: and though I understood most of the local or slang language
column36: there were terms which bewildered even me. I understand that Mr. Chandra believes that this deliberate omission of explanations draws you into the story
column37: but when there are 10 or more such words per page
column38: it will leave a lot of readers more irritated than intrigued.  Overall
column39: I would strongly recommend avoiding this book. The Indians because there is nothing here that you don't know or can't read about in a better written book
column40: and the rest because this is not about India -it's just a forced nowhere story. Save your money and your time. Go buy or read something else.

column1: While a potentially interesting topic
column2: the authors bored me.  The consistantly repeat themselves.  I don't know how many times I was told we know the furture because our authors have studied the past! column1: Reading Dark Harbor is like watching a mediocre TV show that you can't be bothered to turn off. I listened to Dark Harbor as an audio book
column2: so I don't feel too badly about wasting my time on it because I `read it' while I was doing other things that had to be done anyway
column3: like driving.   If you are looking for something that feels fresh and new - Dark Harbor is not for you. This novel is about as innovative as an episode of Murder She Wrote. To illustrate: Stone Barrington and his cronies quickly deduce that an apparent suicide must have been a murder because the gun was found in the victim's wrong hand. (I think I actually saw that one on Murder She Wrote) Woods either can't be bothered to come up with a new idea or he simply doesn't care.   It is clear early on who is responsible for the murders in Dark Harbor. This isn't because the clues come together in any logical way
column4: but rather because of the predictable nature of the novel. You can just tell. This doesn't mean that the solution makes sense. In fact
column5: there are huge inconsistencies in the plot that make the ending feel forced.   It is as if Woods couldn't be bothered to think all of his plot lines through. Woods is compelled to include his regular characters in the novel even though they have little to do (except of course
column6: to have sex with Stone). Holly barely says a word on her first trip to the island. On her second trip she has an obligatory romp with Stone and then gets kidnapped for the remainder of the novel.   Why was she kidnapped? I don't think anyone - including Woods - can answer that question in any plausible way. My theory is that Woods needed to work Holly into the plot and decided that putting her in peril would allow him to fill a few pages. It also allowed him to include Holly's dad (another regular character) in her search. Wood's motive seems obvious. The kidnapper's motive however isn't - her kidnapping makes no sense. But clearly this was something Woods didn't think was worth worrying about.   The best I can say about this novel is that it is a quick easy read (of course
column7: in my case it was read to me). It may not be worth the time and trouble to actually read (and certainly not to buy) - but as an audio book from the library (with a limited selection of audio books to choose from) it helped me pass the time in traffic.

column1: I ordered this book through a bookclub and returned it.  It was terrible!  Tanya Holland is a beautiful Black woman

The price is outrageous for the handful of recipes that were chosen for this cookbook.  I collect african american/soul food cookbooks among others.  If you are really into soul food cookbooks and what they really represent

column5: "The New Ebony Cookbook" by Charlotte Lyons or "The Family Dinner Quilt Cookbook" by The National Council of Negro Women.  If you are interested in diverse
column6: cultural flavors
column7: I would recommend Vertamae Grosvenor's cookbooks or "Iron Pots and Wooden Spoons" by Jessica B. Harris.  I have collected over 50 african american soul food cookbooks. I just wish that she would publish an african american cookbook that the average African American can relate to.  One that would be useful to families in their everyday cooking.

column1: I bought this book looking for something that would tell me things I didn't know about Disney (I've been to WDW countless times and love everything Disney).  And while there were things I didn't know presented in the book
column2: they weren't things that I found terribly interesting.  What you get on each page of this book is a brief statement of fact...like #48's "A former test car from Test Track can be seen in the ride's gift shop at the exit" or #89's "Africa is represented by the fictional village of Harambe."  After this you get a paragraph (i.e. not alot) on the statement.  For #89
column3: you're told about the real village in Kenya that Harambe is based on.  There is then a 'furthermore' section which may/may not be related to the info on the page.  For example #89's furthermore section is on technology that can't be displayed and the authors talk about a 'makeshift insulator' which is really a Coca-Cola bottle.  This is supposed to be 'a nod to both the inventiveness of African towns and the longtime sponsorhip of Disney parks by the Coco-cola company.'  If that isn't a stretch I don't know what is.  As another reviewer said
column4: there's little meat to this book and perhaps that's what didn't hold my interest.  The one paragraph of info really did not give alot of info and the furthermore sections were hit or miss about pertaining directly to what was on the page.  I read through the book once and put it away as I don't think it's a good reference

column1: This is anything but a "historical inquiry" into the New Testament accounts of the resurrection of Jesus Christ. It is at best "historical speculation
column2: and Lï¿½demann's conclusions are little more than assertions based on his arbitrary, atomistic textual critical methodology and anti-supernatural presuppositions.  To Lï¿½demann, development from one gospel to the next is evidence of distortion. This is apparent in his discussion of the tradition of Joseph of Arimethea. Lï¿½demann is quite troubled that each of the gospels portrays Joseph in increasingly glowing terms. Although one could interpret this development as simply the progressive inclusion of more information, Lï¿½demann arbitrarily declares these accounts suspect as a result.   Lï¿½demann also dismisses any positive reconstruction of the ending of the gospel of Mark, yet insists on a negative reconstruction of the resurrection chapters in John's gospel. He admits that Mark's gospel ends with a preposition in the Greek, yet insists that we must consider the text as it has come to us without speculating on a lost ending. Since he holds to Markan priority, he argues that the earliest tradition, therefore, records no resurrection appearances.   Yet Lï¿½demann is certain that we must not accept the received text of John chapter 20. He asserts that verse 11 does not chronologically connect with verses 1-10 and, therefore, declares verses 14-18 the imaginative insertion of the author, exhibiting a surprising bias against the nature of ancient biography and its often characteristically non-chronological nature. Furthermore, he insists that verses 19-23 contradict verses 24-28, since verses 19-23 do not mention that any of the disciples were missing when Jesus appeared to them, yet 24-28 declare that Thomas was missing. But verses 19-23 make no mention of the number of disciples present when Jesus appears. So how does the information in the succeeding passage constitute a contradiction? This is additional information, not contradictory information. Nonetheless, Lï¿½demann declares these passages unhistorical. Such arbitrary textual vivisection is characteristic of Lï¿½demann's method, and his arbitrary acceptance of Mark and rejection of John further reveal his bias.  Another example of Lï¿½demann's historical" method appears in his discussion of the Sabbath Day meeting between the Jewish leaders and Pilate recorded in Matthew 27: 62-66. He considers the account of this meeting between "strict followers of the Jewish law" and the gentile Pilate as "incredible" and therefore historically "nil." Lï¿½demann does not tell us just which Sabbath law the Jewish leaders were breaking as a result of this meeting. Furthermore
column3: the Sadducee's among this group had already proven themselves to be purely politically motivated. As for the Pharisee's among them
column4: they had already been party to the arrest and condemnation of an innocent man by means of a bribe to an inside informer and an illegal trial in the middle of the night. At what point had these lawless co-conspirators suddenly become pristine law-abiders? Apparently
column5: Lï¿½demann can easily accept that the New Testament writers had personal agendas in fabricating imaginative resurrection stories
column6: but cannot fathom sinister chicanery among the Jewish leaders.   Finally
column7: we come to Lï¿½demann's explanation of the resurrection appearances themselves. Leaning on the theories of modern depth psychology
column8: Lï¿½demann psychoanalyzes the apostle Paul in order to explain his reported encounter with Christ on the road to Damascus. According to Lï¿½demann
column9: Paul had a "Christ complex" emerging from his conflict between the alleged harshness of the Jewish law and the attractiveness of Christ's message of grace. This conflict supposedly came to a head when Paul had a purely subjective "vision" of Christ that resolved this conflict and changed his life. Furthermore
column10: Lï¿½demann asserts that this "vision" represents the pattern of all the other recorded appearances of Jesus
column11: although these appearances allegedly were more the result of the disciples' wishful thinking and the need to resolve their "guilt-complex" that resulted from deserting their master.    In response
column12: we must first ask why
column13: prior to Paul's conversion
column14: there is no evidence in the text that he was unhappy with his life. He describes himself as one progressing in his Judaism and zealous for the Law. It appears that Paul was a quite well-adjusted
column15: anti-Christian bigot. Secondly
column16: we must ask what "wishes" the earlier disciples had that would have motivated such a "vision." There was no anticipation among them that their deceased Master would appear again
column17: nor was there any place in their theology for a dead Messiah. Finally
column18: Lï¿½demann fails to tell us how the experience of subjective visions translated into the disciples' unanimous proclamation that Jesus had risen bodily from the dead. There is no precedent in the Old Testament or Second Temple Jewish literature for such an interpretation of visions. Furthermore
column19: Second Temple Judaism would seem to preclude such an understanding of visions
column20: even if objective. "Resurrection" was understood by first century believing Jews to mean a physical event in space and time. So even if we grant that Paul saw a heavenly Christ
column21: we are not compelled to believe that this was the experience of all the other disciples
column22: nor are we compelled to believe that the Christ Paul saw was not embodied.*    In the end
column23: Lï¿½demann's theory is based on historical and psychological speculation that find no support in the text. His is just another attempt to come up with a naturalistic explanation of the resurrection at any cost
column24: since
column25: to Lï¿½demann
column26: a supernatural explanation
column27: even if it remains the best explanation
column28: is simply a priori unacceptable.  * For an exanded treatment of some of the thoughts in this paragraph
column29: I recommend the book Jesus Resurrection
column30: Fact or Figment: A Debate Between William Lane Craig and Gerd Lï¿½demann
column31: ed. Paul Copan and Ronald K. Tacelli (Downers Grove
column32: IL: Intervarsity Press

This means that White mixes everything up
column6: chronology

Scholastic ossification of the ideas of the Catholic Church is a great topic

column1: I have been a huge fan of the Anna Pigeon mysteries.  The hard truth about Hard Truth is skip it.  It is a very unpleasant experience.  The graphic representation of child abuse and cruelty in this book still makes me ill.    What I've loved about the Anna Pigeon series is that I felt like I got a good sense of the national park where the story took place with an appreciation for the natural beauty of the area.  I doubt Anna spent more than a night in Rocky Mountain National Park.  Not only does she completely miss the unique character of the park but the park has no necessary link to the story.  The whole thing could have taken place in urban Chicago.  I have been picking up Nevada Barr books as fast as I could find them.  This book
column2: however
column3: was truely repulsive.  I'll be much more cautious about investing a part of my life in her next book

column1: I ordered this book after reading the rave reviews and the who's who of public school using this format.  Nowhere is it advertised or even mentioned that this is a Christian book
column2: espousing Christian dogma and assumptions.  I'm surprised this is acceptable for use by Government funded public schools.  Furthermore
column3: there is a lot of non-scientific rhetoric in the book that eschews logical debate and exposition.  I'm very disappointed and consider this to be false advertising.   Some of the parenting tips are common sense that I didn't think needed to be reiterated.  A person already interested enough in buying a book would already have the basics down.  I was looking for more than that.  The advertising led me to believe that the book would be about language manipulation
column4: how to speak more effectively with children to ease the learning process. There is false logic in some of the parental mistakes.  An example is always attributing "hovering parents" to ego issues
column5: that a parent "needs to be needed".  Some hovering parents are survivors of abuse and can't see the lines between normal risks and when a child is in real danger.  False assumptions leads to false conclusions.   I gave this  2 stars with the thought that someone who is so out of the loop and a danger to their child may read this book-at least could adopt some common sense.  But it isn't helping my family.

column1: Half way through I'm wondering if I want to finish this turkey.  And that's disappointing.  I really did like Stepsister.  I also believe Wicked is a stand alone work of art!  I recommend it to anyone I meet.  I love Mr. Maguire's twists on classic fairy tales.  I hope he's not being forced by the "powers that be" (publishing companies) to crank them out quicker than he is comfortable doing.  I'm sure it took a long time for him to create Wicked and fill in all those gaps and answer all those questions!  No stone was left unturned.  Perhaps he even had some of the questions already answered in his mind for "confessions'" Cinderella and Stepsister?  It just doesn't seem that Mirror Mirror is as well put together and researched as the others.  Therefore
column2: it seems a little disjointed --- lacking in flow.  It also seemed like an awful lot of writing just for the sake of meeting a minimum word count.  I do hope Mr. Maguire has more time (or whatever else he needs ) in order to produce another Wicked.  Perhaps we
column3: as readers
column4: should also coinsider Wicked as a singualar work of art by this artist and not compare everything he writes against that benchmark?  Just an idea

column1: Loftus is a witness for the defense for parents accused of abuse by adult children.  There is well established research which defines two types of memory.  Trauma memory is quite different than the memory that Loftus discusses here.  Dismissing repression as invalid
column2: Loftus overlooks concrete evidence of dissociation
column3: repression and later remembrance of traumatic abuse. An abused child can't deal with the trauma and they cope by shutting down (dissociating) and then forgetting (repression). This is survival for children. As adults in safe environments
column4: those children are faced with what their subconscious always has remembered. These repressed memories are not always exact and precise
column5: but they are corroborated in some cases. As an abused child
column6: I know about repression. Its a coping device. We repress by drinking and drugging. People have developed post-traumatic stress disorder from abuse they don't "remember" the specifics of.  Loftus has her slant and she's entitled to it. There are always opposite sides of any fence

column5: I feel they are miscast. It has none of the outstanding production values (script
column6: casting
column7: set and costume design
column8: cinemetography and soundtrack to name but a few) of it's predecessor. The entire cast of the '74 version is superb
column9: but I must single out Sam Waterston
column10: who is such a fine actor. After seeing him in the role of Nick Carraway
column11: I can't imagine anyone else playing that role
column12: as is the case with the rest of the cast and their respective roles
column13: even the minor ones.  One scene I did want to specifically mention in the later version
column14: mostly because it really sums up the contrast of the two films
column15: was the scene where Myrtle is hit by Gatsby's car. I found it to be completely tastless and graphic. We then see her laid out in all her misshapen grotesqueness. Whereas the other film was able to recreate the scene perfectly in my mind's eye through hearing witnesses and Gatsby later relating the incident to Nick. We only see her covered with a blanket
column16: as in the book.  I would only recommend watching this if you want to see the difference between great and mediocre film making. Seeing this made me long for the other version
column17: which I promptly ordered. I would have given this new version "no stars" if they had that rating as I didn't find it entertaining
column18: but a dreadful bore. If you're looking to purchase this
column19: I would strongly recommend buying the 1974 version instead. And at $5.97 it is well worth the money

column1: So much of 'Eternity Road' is ridiculous and contrived (beginning with the premise!) that it becomes annoying. Once I start reading a book
column2: I like to finish it. In this case
column3: I had a hard time not chucking the book at the wall or throwing it in the garbage with disgust. It may still end up in the trash. I suppose if it were recycled
column4: it wouldn't be able to poison the environment. There has only been one other author that has been able to evoke such a negative response on my part
column5: no matter how poorly written the material.   Starting with the concept of the novel
column6: why would a group of scholars rate a work of fiction so highly? When the world has been largely destroyed
column7: information on how to rebuild or some explanation of what happened should be far more important. The novel also doesn't adequately explain how the people of the world learn about Mark Twain's stories or why they would be so impressed by it compared with anything by any other author. I should mention that I received this book as a gift. I have not read 'A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court'. There is at least one point in 'Eternity Road' that makes an allusion to Mark Twain's book that I could not understand.   Every time a character died (you didn't think they'd all survive
column8: did you?)
column9: I was left with mixed emotions. Yeah! One less imbecile! On the other hand
column10: the absurdity of how they get killed off is frustrating. For instance
column11: one character dies in an explosion. Apparently
column12: it's normal for methane gas to build up in random rooms even though there is no source. Only certain rooms have ventilation systems for AC and heating. It seems
column13: in the future
column14: there are no building codes to handle these kind of issues. There is no believability in the situation that McDevitt creates.   Compare this with Harry Harrison who writes in one series about an individual who'd just learned how to use Arabic numerals to aim a trebuchet. The character's forces miss on the first attack. The enemy artillery also misses. It's a race to see which side can reload and aim for the second attack. After some hasty computations
column15: the good guys fire again and destroy the enemy's trebuchet. How could their aim improve so much when they can't include factors such as drag
column16: adjustments for having a different piece of ammunition and such? Harrison explains it as 'the errors canceled out'. I've never been around a trebuchet
column17: only seen them on TV or read about them in books. But
column18: that sounds like a good reason to me! The credibility is high and I don't get distracted and start thinking too hard about how likely that is to happen. On the other hand
column19: most every one should have some experience with rooms that were too cold or too hot because there was no airflow.   This continues in other ways as well. McDevitt is trying to combine the world that we know now with a future world that exists only in his imagination. To show how the world has changed
column20: he creates new words to describe items that we would readily recognize. The way that he goes about this simply doesn't work. For instance
column21: highways are still called highways. Cars are called hojjies. McDevitt gives no meaningful description of the hojjies
column22: so there's no way to tell if they are like the cars of today or if they were hovercraft or used some other form of locomotion. Likewise
column23: one character plays a 'walloon'. The only description of a walloon that we ever get is that it's a stringed instrument. What color is it? How many strings? How is it played? We can only guess. If the character instead played a banjo
column24: an image of it would be conjured in our heads without the need for a description. This lack of attention to details is irritating.   At some point
column25: I read 'A Talent for War'
column26: also by Jack McDevitt. From what I remember
column27: that was a fine enough novel. I can't say that all of McDevitt's material is trash. However
column28: I'd recommend picking up almost any other book than this one.

column12: Marlon Wayans
column13: Jennifer Connelly and Ellen Burstyn all do drugs
column14: and this really messes up their lives. I hate to give it all away like that

column17: and since that is all there is to this movie it absolutely fails to have any sort of effect.  Maybe if Aronofsky had put more time in to characterization it would've worked

column19: we've got  Jared Leto as a stupid chunkhead who has inane conversations with his equally chunkheaded girlfriend Jennifer Connelly
column20: who wants to be a fashion designer
column21: or something.  Beyond this we've got Jared's mother
column22: Ellen Burstyn
column23: who is a weird old woman and Marlon Wayans as Leto's friend who deals drugs with him at times and appears headed towards the big leagues.  I particularly love how there's no real attempt to make Wayans into a person.  He's got one flashback about how he wanted to make his mom proud and that's it.  The doubly sad fact is that he's the most likable of the three.  He at least displays a little life.  Connelly and Leto apparently just wandered here from a Bergman film and are so dull and slow that it's a wonder that the smack doesn't cause them to cease to exist entirely.  (Well

column25: I think

column27: I actually *like* the Bergman films I've seen
column28: so that's not really a fair comparison.)  They love each other
column29: apparently

column31: Burstyn is mostly just creepy though her performance does take a turn for the hilarious as she goes off the deep end.  Perhaps it wouldn't have been funny if I cared about her
column32: but we've been over that...    And I want you people to know that I'm not utterly heartless when it comes to movies.  I can care about the characters
column33: but none of these people did anything for me
column34: so the movie's dead in the water.  For good counter examples watch "Trainspotting"
column35: which has drug-addict characters with enough humor and life to be likable and interesting and "Bubba Ho-Tep"
column36: a film which displays the plight of the lonely elderly 50 times better than this film despite being a silly horror-comedy with a mummy in a cowboy outfit in it.  On the other hand

column38: so watching them will do nothing to stroke your ego.  Still

column40: derivative over-direction.  The trouble is

column42: but they're hopelessly driven in to the ground
column43: as we see fast-motion a thousand times
column44: quick-cut montages a million times and plenty of wonky camera-attached-to-the-actor junk
column45: and they are
column46: again
column47: impossible not to notice cause the plot sure ain't drawing me in.  I imagine that the overdone
column48: repeating visual style is meant as a representation of the endless cycle found in drug use
column49: but that doesn't make it any more pleasant or entertaining to watch.  The score suffers from the same problem as they use the same handful of themes over and over.   Truth be told
column50: I thought this movie was pretty okay for about the first half
column51: but then it really started to grate on me.  It became evident that no
column52: Aronofsky wasn't going to introduce any new visual tricks and no
column53: these characters weren't going to get any more interesting.  I looked at the timer continuously for about the last 40 minutes of the film
column54: and was so uninvolved that the supposedly horrifying conclusion where all the characters really get it bad was utterly ineffective.  It was kind of uplifting
column55: really:  Now that these tedious characters have finally hit rock bottom I can go do something else.  Now that's a good ending.  Grade: D+   PS This is 500 reviews.  I doubt if I will write 500 more

column1: I purchased this book because it was assigned as a part of a literature curriculum for 7th Grade. I am very glad that I read this book before allowing my 12 year old son to read it. This book is about gang violence (although it is initially sugar coated as being fairly harmless pranks assigned to frightened students by one of the gang leaders.)  The book is also about angry
column2: jaded
column3: hateful teachers and administrators in a religious school and how they allow the gang to function in order to serve their own purposes.   The ending has the one student who stood up against the gang being beaten up quite severely for his disobedience (while the administrator of the school looks on from a nearby hill.)   Before he is taken away in the ambulance
column4: the student tries to tell his one and only friend to just do what the gang and the faculty want him to do.   The message here is do not buck the system
column5: no matter how corrupt the system is. Within the first few pages the book refers to masturbation.  (Another re-curring topic.)  I knew that it was questionable whether or not I would allow my son to read this book.  I read the entire book myself hoping that there would be a redeming message in the end that would justify the rest of the book.  There isn't.   This is the first book that I have ever thrown away rather than passing on to someone else. Save your money.  I don't care how many awards this book received.  It is pure trash

column1: The English-Speaking world has badly needed a wide-ranging history of Christianity that focuses on the lives of ordinary Christians. Unfortunately
column2: this need still goes unmet.  The contributors to the first two volumes of this series (the only ones I've looked at so far) often have mastered an impressive amount of factual material about earliest Christianity
column3: mined from a variety of literary and non-literary sources. Unfortunately
column4: they interpret this mass of data through the distorting lens of a couple of highly questionable theories - theories which they accept without examination
column5: or even question. The result is that little of what they say about the topic is reliable or useful.  The older of these unquestioned theories is the famous 'Bauer Hypothesis'
column6: developed by the German historian Walter Bauer way back in the early 19th century.  Bauer argued that originally there were a multiplicity of competing "Christianities" - no one more correct or authentic than any other - and that it wasn't until after several centuries of struggle that what we know as "orthodox Christianity" finally triumphed
column7: and then attempted to destroy all trace of its vanquished rivals.  This theory has become almost unquestioned "orthodoxy" (forgive the pun) in most academic circles
column8: but few scholars have bothered to make a serious examination of its assumptions to see if they fits the facts.  Some scholars have
column9: however
column10: and one of them is the current Archbishop of Canterbury
column11: Rowan Williams
column12: who wrote an essay called "Does It Make Sense to Speak of pre-Nicene Orthodoxy" as his contribution to 'The Making of Orthodoxy: Essays in Honor of Henry Chadwick'. He seriously undermines Bauer's assumptions and makes a convincing case for a profound and intentional unity in faith and practice in earliest Christianity. I recommend you check it out.  The second theory governing this series is much more recent
column13: but no more scrutinized. This is "Foucauldianism" - developed by late 20th century French deconstructionists
column14: particularly Michel Foucault. It was Foucault's belief that all discourse (religious
column15: political
column16: philosophic
column17: whatever) has one purpose - to help one person/group to exercise power and control over another.  Applying this attitude to Christianity
column18: for example
column19: has obvious results.  One will look at any theological statement about the Trinity
column20: Christ
column21: salvation or ascetical practice and wonder
column22: "Who is trying to control and manipulate whom by teaching this."  For most of the contributing scholars
column23: this plays out in perceived issues of class and gender. The Church fathers
column24: who have been revered for centuries as teachers of Christian truth
column25: are now seen as 'The Elite' who created "discourses" to maintain their power and exercise "discipline" on the masses. The masses
column26: for their part
column27: may have pretended to go along
column28: but (these historians assure us) they were always creating "subversive interpretations" of the Elite's discourses
column29: in an effort to undermine power structures and liberate themselves. As you can tell
column30: this sort of rhetoric gets awefully tiresome after a while.  It is obvious to me that it will be impossible to make a fair or useful evaluation of orthodox Christian faith and life when all the evidence is selected and distorted so as to fit agendas such as these. I'm still waiting for that good social history of early Christianity.

column1: This book is sponsored by the American Council for Cultural Policy and is an excellent illustration that this organization is completely devoid of ethics. The various articles in the volume detail how the 'innocent' art and antiquities dealer and collector could and should be protected by U.S. law
column2: all the while defaming the rights and plight of Native Americans
column3: victims of Nazi appropriations
column4: and countries suffering from massive art market-driven looting
column5: to name only a few. Property laws figure heavily in these debates
column6: but naturally the question of how stolen or looted art and antiquities become the 'property' of collectors and dealers is answered in such ways as to show the dealers and collectors as the true victims of both the thefts and the judicial systems. Although the book is claimed as a balanced discussion of the many complex issues surrounding the ownership of cultural property
column7: it is clearly in the corner of the wealthy dealers and collectors (and their lawyers).

column1: My Tv started to have sound problems and I sent off an email to Olevia. No response. Then tried calling support - had to leave a message.  Days later after no response I called and transferred to sales - helpful guy and wanted all the details but again he could not help and would have tech support call me back - NO LUCK with call back  3 weeks go by and now I am getting rather ticked at the no response. column1: I believe Ayn Rand's writings are very destructive. And this isn't because of her highly un-original philosophy. No

This egoism is  supposedly derived from "reason". In the real world however there  is no reason for people not to find fulfillment and meaning from helping  others and caring for their family and friends. The accusation that  "altruism"
column3: i.e. decency and goodness
column4: leads to tyranny is  nothing but products of a very paranoid mind. The craziest thing about this  though is the fact that Ayn Rand has been raised to a saint-like status by  her followers. No disagreement with her writings is ever accepted and if  you disagree you are an evil communist/collectivist. To be a true  individualist you must agree with everything she has ever written. Isn't  this collectivism in a true sense? No
column5: says her followers
column6: those views are  derived by reason and must therefore be share by all intelligent human  beings. Pretty scary!! Note that Objectivism
column7: like Marxism
column8: Freudianism and  Jungianism
column9: is a closed system of thought in the sense that any critisism  of the system is automatically seen as a symptom of unreason. This is what  makes Objectivism a religion rather than a philosophy or scientific method.  And this is also the reason for the fanatical behavior of her disciples

column6: pregnancy
column7: and childbirth
column8: and to suggest so would make his books utterly self-congratulatory other than proven techniques that work across the board. I hope the parents of his patients don't feel that they have to conform to his beliefs in terms of how they choose to raise their children. It is good to take what is useful to you as a parent from various sources such as this book; but I refuse to see Dr. Sears as an authority on my child's development and on my role as a parent just because he has written dozens of books that are regurgitations of each other. column9: you must learn to think for yourself as well as seek out information from other sources

column1: I was first angry after reading Mr. Flynn's book but now all I feel is pity for him and those that gave it a glowing review.  The thing is they just DON'T get it.  They don't get Christmas.  At it's core Christmas may be a Christian holiday celebrating the birth of Jesus.  But at its deeper core...if one actually takes the time and effort to search it out
column2: one finds the true origins of our Christmas holiday.  The origins in the pagan Roman Winter solstice celebration of Saturnalia.  A celebration that including feasting
column3: gift-giving
column4: and much revelry.  In other words
column5: a celebration on unlike the way most Americans celebrate it.  Christmas can be a quiet day of religious reflection if you want
column6: or a season of fun...a season of enjoying Frosty and Rudolph and the Grinch on TV
column7: of wathcing decorating shows (without a hint of relgious symbolism) on HGTV or DIY
column8: it can be jumping in the car and drving around the neighborhood at hight looking at houses decked out in lights.  Having parties with friends you haven't seen in a long time
column9: baking sugar cookies and Gingerbread houses.  All without the religious trappings that Mr. Flynn seems to fear.  No one expects EVERYONE to celebrate Christmas.  And so what are we to do?  Cancel Christmas because 18% of the U.S. is not ?Christian?  Heck
column10: my Arab neighbors put up Christmas lights.  Almost every ethnic group has some kind of celebration of light and music.  Does seeing Rudolph and Santa Claus on TV really impose our religious beliefs on people?  No.  Mr. Flynn is a stinker of the highest degree...he's a party pooper.  He's one who can't live with the belief that the majority rules.  Whether you celebrate Christmas as a day...or a season that starts when the Halloween decorations come down
column11: Christmas is the one time of the year when people seem a little nicer...when people who don't give to charity all year reach in the their pocket for a dollar and give it to the Salvation Army.  These are dark times we live in filled with war and threats..and for a few weeks out of the year Christmas helps us put aside those worries.  People who feel threatened by Christmas' commercialism or relgion just don't get it and never will.  What a shame...what a pity..

column1: I loved the earlier Nevada Barr mysteries
column2: with their depiction of national parks and natural dangers.  I wasn't as happy with some of her latest efforts
column3: but still hadn't given up on her.  Now I'm not so sure.  This latest novel started off well enough although the idea of two severely traumatized girls should have been a clue as to what would follow. The idea that they were from a polygamous Mormon sect was a red herring.  Perhaps it was Barr's attempt to show us how these girls were abused even before they met evil incarnate. The scenes where Anna realizes who the real villian is and her interaction with him and the poor tortured third traumatized girl went on for over 60 pages. Each scene was more disturbing the one before it. I found myself skimming the pages and still am not sure how she resolved all the loose ends. But I have absolutely no desire to re-read the end of the book and find out.  I wish I could say that I would read another Nevada Barr novel because I so thoroughly enjoyed the first ones. But after reading this disturbing
column4: somewhat convoluted story
column5: I would think twice.  If I did pick up another Anna Pigeon novel
column6: I'd make sure I had something else to read if the story took another dark turn. I would certainly not stick with it to the end.

One of the more glaring deficiencies here was the treatment of German philosophy; I don't know that there is a notable scholar who has more misunderstood Nietzsche than Bloom.  He should stick to translating French and leave interpretation up to more worthy critics.

column1: After reading this book I came up with a better title for it: "Web sites for dummies".  But then again
column2: should web dummies really read this book ?  The content of this book is made of a series of advices about organizing your web space. Most good advices in this book are already available (for free) on the W3 markup validator (validator.w3.org) or on some other W3 Consortium page (w3.org).  Other advices are just worthless
column3: like this little jewel: "[...] sound effects can be used as an extra dimension in the user interface [...] the progress of a file download could be indicated by the sound of water pouring into a glass".  Surely that will clarify it all! Should a flushing sound be played as well ?  I don't see how such a sound could actually give information about the progress of a download.  People really serious about designing user interfaces should try one of Jef Raskin's books
column4: like "The Humane Interface" (ISBN: 0201379376) which introduces quantification techniques of a user's pain when manipulating an interface

column1: I've been a fan of Heinlein's SF for just about as long as I've been an SF fan at all (somewhere around thirty-five years). But when I read this collection some twenty-odd years ago
column2: it nearly turned me off to the old man altogether.  The fiction is pretty good (although even that isn't Heinlein's best). But to describe the nonfiction accurately
column3: I'd have to use words that Amazon will remove from the review anyway.  For the most part
column4: the pieces collected here represent a side of Heinlein I strongly dislike. Though I respect _Starship Troopers_
column5: it's never going to be my favorite Heinlein novel no matter how many times we quibble over the precise definition of "fascism" -- and I'm not going to have much respect for the nonfiction in this collection.  And mind you
column6: it's not because I disagree with Heinlein's opinions; it's because he gave bad arguments for them and called other people nasty names when they differed. Some of the stuff collected here is tendentious to the point of being propagandistic. (At least in his fiction
column7: he was able to create characters with points of view that differed from his and get into their heads well enough to present them sympathetically -- in short
column8: to grok them. Not here
column9: boy.)  Heinlein (who bought into the Korzybski/General Semantics fad pretty early on) spent a lot of years dismissing philosophers as tailchasers who derive their premises from their conclusions. But his own attempt at philosophy
column10: as represented here in e.g. "The Pragmatics of Patriotism"
column11: is very nearly the worst writing on ethical philosophy I've ever seen.  Then
column12: too
column13: people who knew Heinlein report that despite his overall gentlemanly demeanor
column14: he could be pretty churlish toward people who disagreed with him. Well
column15: he's certainly unpleasant here; anybody who doesn't agree with him on the need for massive nuclear buildup is dismissed as a poltroon or a custard-head. Even in the unlikely event that I thought he were _right_
column16: I wouldn't find this a very helpful approach.  Perhaps more surprisingly
column17: his popular writings on _science_ aren't very good. Asimov's reputation as the "great explainer" is in no danger here.  This volume is second only to _Grumbles from the Grave_ in cementing Heinlein's posthumous reputation as a rather mean-spirited fellow whose fictional characters were generally much better company than he was. When I want Heinleinian company
column18: I'll stick to D.B. Davis
column19: Manuel Garcia O'Kelly Davis
column20: and (maybe) Lazarus Long.  And when I want to read some humane nonfiction by an SF master
column21: I'll still turn to Asimov. I credit Heinlein with three magisterial novels
column22: several imperfect-but-great ones
column23: and a good number of brilliant short stories. But the stuff in this book should have stayed in his drawer

column1: I used to really enjoy Mary Higgins Clark's books
column2: but I get the feeling that the more successful she becomes
column3: the more she's just phoning it in. This story was irritating on several levels
column4: not the least of which was the author's trademark formulaicism that's becoming almost comical (the protagonist is beautiful and wealthy
column5: ludicrous coincidences pile up until everyone but the reader believes she's guilty
column6: etc.) I saw the ending coming a mile away
column7: which you will too if you've read more than two of her books. And MHC's subtle bourgeoisie attitude is a bit offensive (when a villain is relaxing at home
column8: you know he's a bad guy because his chair is made of "imitation leather
column9: while the innocent main character has lovely European antiques distributed throughout her home.) Finally, MHC's characters are supposed to be young and modern-day, but not one of them speaks like today's young adults. This author's total inability to capture authentic language or everyday slang makes my suspension of disbelief even more difficult. More than one character uses the word quarrel
column10: more than one time each. How many native New Jerseyites in the year 2006 would ever just casually drop that word instead of argue" or "fight"? Because of this tendency to inadvertently use language that was probably commonplace when MHC herself was young
column11: conversations between the characters sound stilted and almost amusing.   Overall
column12: I can't say I recommend this book even as a beach read. If you're looking for a fast
column13: fluffy but satisfying mystery
