column1: My mother got me books every Christmas when I was growing up to encourage me to read more. She got me this novel 1 year because of the title (I'm the baby of our family) but I just didn't get it? The story was just odd but to each its own.
This book focuses on Amanda Starkey
column2: a young nurse who has suffered a breakdown and was sent home by her boss so she could get her act together. Amanda returns to her family home in Wisconsin to live with her sister
column3: Mattie
column4: and Mattie's daughter
column5: Ruth. Mattie's husband
column6: Carl
column7: is off fighting in France during WWI.  The sisters are very close
column8: and so Mattie is of course thrilled to have her sister back in her life on a daily basis again. They begin to embark on a new aspect of their life together
column9: while Mattie anxiously waits for her husband's return from the war.  Then
column10: one winter night
column11: tragedy strikes
column12: and Mattie ends up drowning in the nearby lake. Her young daughter
column13: Ruth
column14: almost ends up drowning as well
column15: but is rescued in the nick of time.   Not long after Mattie's death
column16: Carl returns from the war
column17: wounded. He is eager to see his wife
column18: not realizing that she has died.   Amanda
column19: who has never liked Carl
column20: hopes that he will decide to leave again almost as soon as he'd returned home. She figures him for the sort to not want to raise a child alone
column21: and each day waits for him to leave
column22: thereby making her Ruth's sole caretaker. Yet much to her annoyance
column23: he manages to get his bearings again and remains a fixture in both hers and Ruth's life.  At the same time
column24: Amanda struggles with inner demons
column25: both because of what happened to her sister
column26: and because of what happened in her life prior to returning home
column27: which you eventually learn about. She is then sent to a sanatorium and Carl is left to care for his daughter on his own. However
column28: he founders
column29: and ends up relying on a second cousin (Hilda) for her grudging help.   This new upheaval causes Ruth to regress a great deal
column30: and she stops talking and acts out by breaking things in the house and being impossible to toilet train and deal with overall. In a funny turn of events
column31: Ruth manages to embarrass Hilda enough so that she leaves. Carl
column32: in an act of desperation
column33: takes Ruth with him on one of his many visits to see Amanda
column34: in the hope that it will spark a desire in her to get well once and for all. It works
column35: and a year after having been committed
column36: Amanda returns home.  The rest of the story vacillates between what really happened the night Mattie drowned
column37: and what is happening in Amanda and Ruth's life afterwards. In the first part of the book
column38: Ruth ages from about 3-5. When the second part begins
column39: she is already 11. I felt that was somewhat abrupt
column40: and it took me a few pages to realize how much time had passed
column41: as there wasn't anything to indicate that this had happened.   The book continued to bounce around a lot from this point on
column42: between reminiscences of the past and what was actually happening to the characters months or years down the line. It got a little annoying at times to have to figure out where exactly the next installation was starting out. Also
column43: the book jacket said the story was told from several of the main character's points of view
column44: but the only ones you really hear from are Ruth and Amanda.   I was pretty disappointed by the end of the story. The book starts out intriguing and makes you wonder if Amanda literally went off the deep end after all and killed her sister
column45: or if it was in fact an accidental drowning. But by about halfway through
column46: the facts become clear and are easy to interpret. Still
column47: I hoped maybe I was wrong and the ending would surprise me after all. It didn't.  Carl also disappears about halfway through the book. It's due to a job he takes
column48: but it felt like he was written out of the story because the author ran out of use for him
column49: or wasn't sure what to do with him after a certain point. She spent a lot of time focusing on Carl's desire to learn about the truth of his wife's death.   As it was
column50: he only found out part of the truth
column51: and that was according to what Amanda got him to believe. Nevertheless
column52: Carl accepted it at face value and after that he accepted his wife's fate. He was then written out of the story. I didn't really like that aspect of things and didn't think it meshed with everything else that was happening. Even though he wasn't a strong character in general
column53: he's one of the characters I actually liked. Amanda wasn't that likeable at all
column54: and was a pretty cold person who was obsessed with Ruth and still obsessed with the past. Ruth was somewhat pliable and easily molded to her aunt's bidding
column55: even though she made some feeble attempts to be her own person.  I don't know if I'd read this author again. But I managed to find this book for $1.. and would say it was worth it and I'm glad I didn't pay full price for it

column1: As a long time mathematics tutor and teacher I know this book very well. I don't think the material is presented or explained in a way that is especially helpful for young people. As a tutor I have to constantly reintroduce the topic and/or try to stay ahead of the student's class. Beyond that
column2: the students are asked to do only the simplest of proofs. Additionally
column3: a new topic will be introduced and then no problems appear in the exercise portion of the section to help the student test and practice his or her understanding of the newly introduced topic (and of course
column4: those problems invariably will show up on the chapter exam and the final).   Moreover
column5: I think the book just fails the kids. It seems to omit certain standard concepts by being "accessible" and undemanding of even the most minor critical thinking skills. I believe that both of these shortcomings will leave the student unprepared for the challenging problems on standardized tests and on college entrance exams. Not to mention any sort of subsequent advanced work in high school and college.  Another thing about the Larson book is that the answers to many of the problems are so arithmetically peculiar that the student has no feeling that maybe they actually got the right answer. Good problems reassure the student that they are on the right track. Also
column6: once a new concept or definition is introduced it is never repeated.  Overall
column7: I think that the more capable students will be shortchanged and misled into thinking that they know more than they actually do and the less capable student might pass geometry but will perform poorly on college entrance exams and be unable to successfully progress in mathematics if they need to do so.

column1: I have read all of the books up until this one
column2: and this one is definitely the worst so far.  In fact
column3: it makes me wonder whether I will continue to read the series.  The book is misnamed.  The Ionian mission is only the last fourth of the book.  The first three-fourths is a very boring description of two battles that came close to happening but never did.  The Ionian mission itself is fairly confusing with all of the personal names and place names bandied about.  Jack Aubrey
column4: as in most of the other books
column5: is burdened with an extremely difficult mission.  He must decide who to support in some kind of three-way civil war.  He makes the wrong choice
column6: but then is called away to fight another party who has seized some British vessels.  Talk about deus ex machina!  There is nothing of much interest that happens in this book.  Stephen Maturin doesn't really do anything interesting in the espionage line
column7: and Professor Graham is a bore.  The final battle scene is as predictable as most of the others--Jack Aubrey wins against all odds because he is a good captain.  I recommend skipping this one if you are reading through the series.  I would bet that Patrick O'Brian did not spend very much time writing this.  In fact
column8: it seemed like bits and pieces patched together to form a "novel.

column1: This guy thinks collectors want to see his own creations of what rare prototypes are. What a complete waste of time. Collectors want to see the real thing. Most of the "rare" prototypes in this book are fakes that Santelmo forgets to tell the reader. This book would be useful if you are interested in conterfeit items
Despite buying four copies of 'Call to Action' for my development team
column2: reading it through twice and making copious notes - I can't recommend that you read it.  It's not that it's bad - it's just not that good and I have to believe there are better books out there.  'Call to Action' describes itself as 'both a step-by-step
column3: how-to manual and a treatise on the true nature of conversion'.  In my opinion
column4: it fails to deliver on either count.  There's no doubt the authors know what they're talking about but
column5: ironically
column6: in a book dedicated to the process of communication
column7: they fail to communicate either a cohesive overview or a detailed 'how-to' of the subject.  There's a facade of structure and some whizzy acronyms like 'AIDAS' and 'MAP' but very little flesh is laid on those sketchy bones.  The introduction identifies the main cause of the problem - the book started life as a collection of disparate web articles interspersed by 'top-tips' from marketers 'in the trenches'.  The articles themselves give the sense of having been shoe-horned into a structure simply for the sake of it.  The 'top-tips'
column8: more often than not
column9: are completely irrelevant to the theme of the article they're paired with.  As a reader looking for greater understanding of the subject and some concrete next-steps
column10: this discordant content yields as much confusion as clarity.  On top of this
column11: the numerous typos
column12: misquotes
column13: repeated quotes and printing errors confirm that insufficient care has been taken in the preparation of this book.  It hasn't even been professionally proof-read
column14: let alone purposefully written.  So how come I purchased four copies?  The first half of the book does contain some exciting ideas such as developing content based on the persona of the visitor and planning precise conversion scenarios from the home page to the conversion point for each type of visitor.  The second half of the book is mostly padding and pointless repetition of the ideas in the first half.  I purchased the other copies of the book after reading the first half and expecting the second half to follow in a similar vein.  All things taken into consideration
column15: the book reads like a series of adverts for the authors' consulting services rather than as a 'how-to' or a treatise on the subject.  Other authors quoted in this book are:  Roy H. Williams
column16: Jared Spool
column17: Tamara Adlin and Jim Sterne
column18: and I'll be checking out their writings in my continued search for genuine 'how-to' content.  The Eisenbergs could have made this book more effective and much simpler.  They chose not to write for their audience and
column19: to my mind
column20: that makes them guilty of the same sin they condemn online marketers of - focusing on themselves instead of on their customers.  The Eisenbergs make the point that content created for offline advertising rarely translates directly to the web.  This book is proof that the reverse is also true

column1: In the opening chapter
column2: Dr. Lovett introduces the major theme of his book; "This book has been written that you might gain an understanding of the manifestation and presence of the powerful Holy Spirit.  This will be accomplished through the study of an obscure and seemingly insignificant implement known as a rod."     Dr. Lovett interprets the Old Testament motif of "the rod" to be an archetype of the Holy Spirit of God.   Dr. Lovett's position concerning the present day work of the Holy Spirit is that it is misunderstood by modern believers and that this misunderstanding stems primarily form a misunderstanding of the rod motif of scripture.  In his opening chapter Dr. Lovett goes to assert that it is because of a lack of understanding of the very real present work of the Holy Spirit that has led to the rise of liberalism in mainstream Christianity.  He admonishes the reader to embrace the presence and work of the Holy Spirit in their lives and churches. As is the case throughout this book
column3: Dr. Lovett's style in this chapter is heavily sermonic
column4: giving little supporting documentation or evidence for his claims.  In one instance Dr. Lovett goes on a rather didactic rant concerning an unstated position taken by some unstated churches early in the annals of church history which led to the unspecified effects of the indeterminate doctrine "known as liberalism."     The author goes on
column5: in the same protracted paragraph
column6: to write
column7: "These churches have degenerated into mere social clubs and religious organizations that are empty and void of any spiritual blessings from God."     Who are the churches of whom the author speaks in such negative terms?  What evidence does he propose to support his claim that they are "devoid of any spiritual blessings from God?"    Chapter 2: In the second chapter
column8: Dr. Lovett begins to lay the theological groundwork of his "doctrine of the rod."  He points out that the rod is mentioned over 250 times in the Holy Scriptures.  He informs the reader of the early text which has been translated as "rod" in English.  The Hebrew word mettah has been translated from the Old Testament as rod
column9: staff
column10: shaft
column11: or branch.  The Greek word rhabdos can be translated as staff or staves.  The same Greek word is used for rod and signifies a piece of tree limb used as a support or a weapon.  Dr. Lovett gives this information to lay the foundation for his further declarations concerning the relationship with the biblical rod motif and the Holy Spirit.  He tells of the story found in Genesis chapter 38 when the patriarch Judah gave his staff to his daughter-in-law Tamar as a sign of his promise to return.  She was to keep the staff
column12: along with some other valuable articles
column13: as a sign that he would return to her with a lamb from the flock.    Dr. Lovett then writes
column14: "Likewise
column15: we Christians have a promise form the Lord that he will return just as He promised
column16: drawing a parallel between this story and the promise of Christ found in Ephesians 1:13-14.  In whom ye also trusted
column17: after that ye heard the word of truth
column18: the gospel of your salvation: in whom also after that ye believed
column19: ye were sealed with that Holy Spirit of promise
column20: which is the earnest (guarantee) of our inheritance until the redemption of the purchased possession
column21: unto the praise of his glory."   Dr. Lovett places particular emphasis on the similarity he perceives between the staff of Judah as a sign of his promise to his daughter-in-law Tamar and the Holy Spirit's role is the process of sanctification when He secures the believer's eternal inheritance.     As is the case with the other examples that the author uses to support his claim that there is a close relationship between the rod motif of the Old Testament and the revealed Holy Spirit of the New
column22: the connection between Old Testament passages and New Testament passages is strained to fit into the mold of the author's thesis.  The connections are not obvious and for the most part they are strained.  Chapter 3: In the third chapter
column23: the author puts forth a rather encouraging homily concerning the role of the Holy Spirit as the believer travels the journey upon which God has called them to.  He presents a litany of scriptural references with rather limited connection between them.  This chapter is likely to be encouraging to many
column24: but as is the case with the whole book
column25: it is little more than the author's personal opinions and random thoughts on this thing or that.  The author seldom even comes close to addressing the supposed thesis of his book.  	 In this chapter the author does give several interesting and intriguing illustrations in regard to the power of the Holy Spirit in the life of the believer.  Neither these stories or anything else in the passage give much indication as to the relationship between the rod motif and the power of the Holy Spirit for the journey of faith that believers find themselves traveling.  While perhaps encouraging in some sense
column26: the chapter provides limited insight into the supposed central theme of the book.  Chapter 4: In this chapter the author discusses the results
column27: as he sees them
column28: of being filled with the Holy Spirit.  He speaks of this filling as a command which believers have the ability to fulfill.  Again
column29: the author cites and quotes numerous scripture passages and then connects them with pithy statements
column30: clichés and generalizations about unnamed segments of the church.     The author makes ambiguous statements which are difficult to sort out.  "The goal of our lives is to walk continuously with the Rod of the Spirit (Holy Spirit)
column31: which literally means that we are walking with Jesus Himself."     Statements like this are found throughout this chapter
column32: and the rest of the book
column33: in ways that often seem out of context for the theme or message of the book segment in which they are found.  Chapter 5: The author opens this chapter with the assertion that there is a great spiritual truth to be found in the fact that all of the great men of God in the Bible walked with a staff.  The author returns
column34: briefly
column35: to defending his opening thesis that the staff or rod passages in the Bible all speak to a rod motif which points to the Holy Spirit.  Since the great men of the Old Testament and the disciples and apostles of the New Testament walked with a rod then that is metaphorical for believers walking with the Holy Spirit
column36: the author's rod of the spirit. 	 It is in this chapter where the author presents the connection between the staff in the Bible and a bed.  He points out that the Hebrew word translated bed into English is the same word which is translated staff or rod.  The difference of meaning is indicated to Hebrew readers by its usage in its original context.  Dr. Lovett then draws a connection between the Holy Spirit and a bed.  He does support this idea biblically by citing passages in New Testament book of Hebrews which refer to spiritual rest.    Chapter 6: In the six chapter the author quotes passages of scripture and shares stories and anecdotes which point the way that the Holy Spirit works in the heart and life of the believer to bring about victory through the all too common adversity of this life.   Dr. Lovett recounts a touching story of God's very real presence and comfort from his own life when he and his wife had a stillborn baby.    Chapter 7: In the seventh chapter the author asserts that God does not always choose the most capable people to accomplish his tasks.  Indeed
column37: it is quite the opposite.  God routinely chooses the people who are seemingly the least qualified and well trained to accomplish bring his purposes to fruition.  In the Bible there are numerous accounts of God using the unlikely to accomplish the impossible. 	 The author does an effective job of relating this biblical message through many quotes passages of scripture and the use of a relevant poem.  The chapter might be encouraging to those who doubt God's ability to use them and it could be a valuable resource for those believers who need encouragement in that area.   Chapter 8: In this chapter
column38: curiously out of context with the chapter title
column39: the author speaks of the need for believers to recognize the indwelling presence of the Holy Spirit.  The author does spend some time deviating from paragraph long rants about his displeasure concerning the current state of the church in this area or that to tell a story in keeping with the thesis of the chapter.   	 Dr. Lovett tells the story of a man who had left a job a respiratory therapist to attend Liberty University for ministry training.  Upon graduation the man spent several years in various forms of Christian Ministry only to find discouragement and discontent.  Eventually the man realizes that he has been operating out of his calling.  Upon returning to his former career and utilizing his gifts in his local church
column40: the man is deeply satisfied; having found the solution to when the rod does not seem to work.    Clearly
column41: the goal of the author is to encourage believers to be empowered by the very real and present power available to them in the Holy Spirit.  In the forward the author writes
column42: "My goal in this book is to communicate the dynamic Spirit-filled life that should characterize every Christian."       The author does provide the reader with numerous scripture citations.  The citations of biblical passages alone could be rather valuable for personal study or in preparation of group study on the subjects discussed.  Dr. Lovett is direct in his writing.  The reader is left knowing what the author believes concerning the things he writes about
column43: though not always about the message of the book.  While proof-texting is a habit highly regarded in Religious writing
column44: Dr. Lovett takes proof-texting to an extreme.  His constant citing of scriptures references actually detracts from the message of this book.  If one were to remove all of the direct scriptural quotations from the book
column45: it would likely reduce the size of the book by two-thirds!  The Bible is a valuable resource which should be treasured but with the author's excessive scripture citations
column46: there is little room left for his thesis to be expounded. 	 The author routinely diverts from his central thesis to record rants and tirades about various ecclesiastical ills - as he so perceives them to be.  The book seems to be little more than a platform for the author to preach against this thing or that.  As a reader I was left wondering what the overall point really was.  Was the focus the things holding the church back from experiencing the Holy Spirit or was it to know the presence of the Holy Spirit personally?   Many of the author's points were not well connected to previous paragraphs and statements.  It read like a collection of pithy statements and short devotional homilies.  The author makes tremendous indictments about perceived problems in the practical Pneumatology of daily reflection in the lives of believers and then does nothing to support those statements.  The book reads like a sermon spoken with no notes or preparation.  It meanders without making a central theme apparent.    The topic of the presence of the Holy Spirit in the life of believer has received great interest in recent years.  It seems that believers are interested in knowing more about the biblical doctrine of the Holy Spirit and the practical ways that he is available to them.  As with most recent books on this topic
column47: Rod of the Spirit is ambiguous - it's subject matter being slippery and hard to grasp. 	 The way the Holy Spirit works in the lives of individual believers is difficult to describe since it is
column48: by nature
column49: largely personal and experiential.  Doctrinal works which describe the more rigid biblical doctrines of the Holy Spirit's ontology and character are more precise by their very nature.  Christian living books
column50: such as Rod of the Spirit
column51: have the difficult of making the unreal real and the very personal experiences of individuals accessible in ideological terms to the masses.  In the opinion of the reviewer
column52: the contents of the book are better suited for a sermon or journal article than for a book of this nature.  The connection between the rod motif of scripture and the Holy Spirit is not well supported in the text
column53: though a homiletic connection may be drawn.     The pithy commentary nature of the writing is distracting and the author has filled the pages with so much direct quotation from Scripture that he left little room to develop a thesis.  The book is likely to have value for devotional purposes.   The author's passion and love for God is clearly evident in the pages of this book.  I value and respect the ministry of the author though I have taken a fairly critical position in regard to the contents of this book.

column1: The first time I heard about Antony and the Johnsons was from a friend of mine that told me about Rufus Wainwright and was listening to a new artist that was quite incredible.  I decided to do some investigating about this Antony at a local Barnes & Noble and what I discovered was very
column2: very dissapointing.  I find the music to be well written instrumentally and layered quite well
column3: but Antony's voice is very over the top and fake.  By fake
column4: I mean his use of vibrato
column5: which is very rapid and used in a way that comes out as forced and sheeplike (not natural).  Professional voice instructors teach that the correct way to use vibrato is at the right speed: five to six vibrations per second.  It is evident that Antony's "trained" sounding voice is not trained at all in this realm.  Another thing about this band and record that I find very horrible is the lyrics to the songs.  The artist seems confused or regretful of his own gender using a sorrowful and painful delivery of these wailings.  The lyrics hold no attraction or relation to the listening
column6: which lends the listener to a pitiful and almost annoying view of the music itself because of this.  My conclusion is that this is a terrible record and the singer needs to pursue professional voice lessons... and help

column1: "The Heart is a Lonely Hunter" is simply a compilation of character sketches loosely strung together.  If you are a student of literary characterization and the methods authors use to bring a character to life
column2: you might enjoy this book. The charcters are indeed animated.  However
column3: if you are searching for a book that combines vivid characters with any sort of plot
column4: this book is not for you.  By the time I was half-way through the book I was seriously wondering when a coherant plot would develop.  One never materialized.  This book does not adhere to the standard beginning-middle-end
column5: protagonist-antagonist-plot-resolution formula by which most novels abide.   As I was reading this book as a book club assignment
column6: I trudged through to its completion.  Now all I wish is that I could recapture the hours of life wasted on its pages.

column1: In many ways this book is just as interesting as previous books in the series. Adams humor is in tact and will have you snickering fairly often.  The main problem is that of the overall plot. It is unsatisfying and pessamistic. Not just the ending. Tricia Mcmillian or Trillan turns from being a likable and symathetic character to somone who uses people and makes them clean up her mess. It is a heartbeakingly unfit end to a series I have such fondness for. This is compounded by the fact that the late Douglas Adams wished to write a sixth book after this one but never got around to it.   At this point it is better to consider the fourth book the final guide since it has such a satisfyingly beautiful end. For those who love the works of Adams should read it anyway
column2: since it is well... a douglas adams book. Just dont be to dissapointed when you are dissapointed

column1: After having bought the first edition and read numerous other Finance & Strategy texts (in addition to having graduated with an MBA in Finance)
column2: I think it's fair to say this Grinblatt book is rather superficial in its coverage of technical matters e.g. options

column4: bankruptcy etc. Plus I still can't see what it has got to do with Corporate Strategy. Something is still missing here....  Most of the write-up are kind of basic (i.e nothing oustanding) explanation of issues
column5: concepts or techniques in Finance
column6: which you can easily find in other texts with much simpler names. The title of this book is catchy but MISLEADING. Priced at $120
column7: this is really a rip-off. I just don't understand how other commentors could give a 5-star for this "shoddy" piece of work. Reference manual for corporate boardrooms and Wall Street? Compared to classics like Copeland's "Financial Theory & Corporate Policy" or slightly less-advanced Brigham's "Intermediate Financial Management"
column8: this Grinblatt book really falls short of the standard and needs a lot of catching up to do. Hopefully
column9: the authors will take serious note of this in their upcoming edition. Unless of course
column10: they still want their book to be just another "appetizer" for business undergraduates....  In short
column11: NOT worth buying. And NEVER JUDGE A BOOK BY ITS COVER or in this case its rather appealing TITLE

column1: Before making a decision on whether or not to purchase this book
column2: I feel I should share some important information about its author
column3: one Mark Kram
column4: so that you can make an informed decision on whether this is the kind of honest man who is going to write a fair and even handed account on anything regarding boxing:  In 1976 Don King arranged the infamous US Championships Tournament for ABC television. This was a tournament involving fighters signed with Don King or his cohorts only. Bribery was used to corrupt ratings to justify the inclusion of undeserving King fighters/exclusion or far more deserving non-King fighters. The more worthwhile fighters who wanted to participate were told they would have to kickback a chunk of their purses to King
column5: whilst also leaving their current manager and signing with King. Those who refused this blackmail were left excluded. And thus a bogus tournament was created with a clutch of retired preliminary fighters and obscure journeymen
column6: dressed up as contenders with fake records and paid for rankings.  Where was Mark Kram in all of this? This `journalist' accepted gifts and gratuities from Don King and penned a puff piece article promoting the tournament for the January 1977 Sports Illustrated. Oh yes

I have to believe most of what is written in this book is highly embellished to say the least

column1: The 1991 "Our Game" is a standalone post cold war spy story by that British master
column2: John LeCarre: and he's written several memorable spy stories
column3: such as "The Spy Who Came In From The Cold
column4: and the Smiley/Karla trilogy.  This book exhibits some of his virtues as a writer: unsurpassed spycraft, strong set piece openings, and closings; plots that might keep a reader up way past bedtime, sharply drawn characters given snappy dialogue, and engrossing narrative and descriptive writing.  The book opens on Tim Cranmer, forcibly retired British cold war spy; luckily for him, he seems to have more than his share of wealthy relatives,enabling a comfortable retirement as a landed winemaker.  He has acquired a beautiful, much younger mistress whom he keeps in luxury.  And he's been able to place his oldest friend, Larry Pettifer, a friendly rival since Winchester, the elite public school(as the English call it; we call them private schools), and the elite unversity, Oxford, in a job nearby.  Mind you, Pettifer was also one of the deskbound Cranmer's spies, or joes, as Le Carre calls them; he was also a double agent, working for the Russians as well.  Yet there's nobody the cold Cranmer has ever been closer to.  Suddenly, Pettifer disappears, taking with him Cranmer's young mistress Emma. (He tells Cranmer: You stole my life
column5: I stole your girl.")  Cranmer soon discovers that Pettifer has committed himself to a new cause
column6: for which he's taken with him $37 million Russian that he wasn't entitled to.  Cranmer also soon realizes his former employers at the spy shop suspect him of complicity in the theft; and
column7: what's worse
column8: a ruthless Russsian mafia does
column9: too.  So Cranmer goes on the run
column10: to Paris and Russia
column11: remembering his helpful spycraft all the way
column12: as he looks for Pettifer and Emma
column13: while trying to avoid the parties looking for him.  At one point Cranmer muses: "He /Pettifer/ has been goading me about my indifference to the world's agonies....I have said that I never considered myself responsible for the world's ills
column14: not for causing them
column15: not for curing them.  The world was in my view a jungle overrun with savages
column16: just as it had always been.  Most of its problems were insoluble....I have said that I have always been
column17: and would continue to be
column18: prepared to make sacrifices for my neighbours
column19: compatriots
column20: and friends.  But when it came to saving barbarians from one another in countries no bigger than a letter on the map
column21: I failed to see why I should throw myself into a burning house to rescue a dog I had never cared for in the first place."  Now
column22: unfortunately
column23: readers who find that speech resonant
column24: who perhaps are even saying to themselves some variation of: "Right on
column25: brother
column26: couldn't say it better myself

column1: While I would thoroughly endorse and support Susan Clancy's belief that alien abduction is not a real phenomenom
column2: she fails to give the subject the scientific attention one would expect from a psychologist. Her research is shoddy
column3: amounting to soliciting abduction stories from crazies that answer newspaper personal ads. No interviews or research from psychologists treating people with abduction delusions was given
column4: and she failed to identify the psychological causes for such phenomenom that other authors and peer-reviewed journals have covered
column5: ignoring any psychological cause other than psychosis or sleep paralysis. A much better guide to the topic is "Abductions and Aliens: What's Really Going On? " a book written by a psycholgist who has done a literature survey
column6: and has actual case histories to evaluate. Abduction delusions are real
column7: and they need real treatment. Clancy offers no such coverage of treatment options
column8: or any real psychological or scientific research. She took her phd candidate thesis and tried to make a book out of it. I don't think we'll see a "Doctor Clancy" writing again any time soon

column1: This is a critique of federal case by scholars and attorneys NOT scientists. They come at the case from a religious viewpoint whether they all admit it or not.  James Watson who along with Francis Crick won the Nobel Prize in  1958
column2: for their DNA  work. And Watson graduated from the University of Chicago at 19 and nabbed his doctorate at 22
column3: whereas the authors of this book have NO PhD's. Watson also noted on a recent Charlie Rose Show on PBS that he only knew of one true scientist
column4: Francis Collins
column5: who believed in a God. Yet on CSPAN during the week end of August 26-27 the authors of this book say they know 600.  Whom does one believe?  A Nobel Laureate with a PhD and respect within the scientific community
column6: or authors who have neither?  The authors also make a big point of saying they disagreed with the parents/complantants in the federal case
column7: because the authors didn't see ID as a religious belief and that ID doesn't require a belief in a religious 'God'.  But they fail in my opinion
column8: by not realizing that it was indeed the intent by the Judge and many others
column9: that the filers of the case did believe that ID was a God issue and that they wanted this taught. The Judge even noted this in his decision
column10: which cannot be overlooked.  Had the authors or their Discovery Institute (discovery dot org) filed the case they probably would have found the Judge more open at least to their arguments.  Should you read the book?  Yes
column11: simply because I believe in being informed about what all sides of an issue believe or push.  Do I think the Judge made the right decision? Yes
column12: based on what the complainants put forth in their case.

column1: Starting off with the premise that this book is a review of the lives of the 200 children born of Nobel prize winning sperm donors is completely misleading to the reader.  It has been a long time since I actually felt lied to in the preamble to purchasing a book.  Readers should know that no children are born of Nobel prize winners
column2: no examination of the lives of 200 sperm donors from the bank is undertaken and no scientific information on genetics are even discussed throughout the whole book.  In fact
column3: even the data collection of the few lives the author does research seems adhoc at best. What this book is about is a look at some kids who find their true fathers through the help of the author
column4: but more so through a Canadian director researching the same topic for a movie documentary.  The author seems to ride on the coattails of this director in finding out a lot of his information.  All the while he makes enormously ridiculous comments and judgments about the supposed Nobel prize winning sperm bank and genetics.  He never once looks at the topic with an open mind
column5: that maybe
column6: just maybe extremely bright parents might be more likely to have extremely bright children. He does some good research in unraveling the Nobel sperm bank and the people behind it.  But it seems he relies on old interviews and tv show spots from the 70s and 80s
column7: a time when these topics of genetics and race and IQ were strictly taboo.   The book feels to me that it was trying to use the hype around a Nobel prize winning sperm bank to create a marketing buzz when infact this book is nothing but a review of what could be any sperm bank and any children born of it.  Quite disappointing.

column9: which is woeful. This is a complex subject in itself

column1: I bought this  book hoping that it would investigate today's financially status oriented world. In this task the book starts off quite well reviewing Nixon's visit to Russia. column2: the book
column3: particularly with its enumerated layout
column4: reads more like someone who's written a ph.D thesis and desperately wants to cover those things that  someone reviewing it would be impressed to see
column5: throwing in a few graphs for good measure. Unfortunately to the layperson it is very hard to get through. For example at the end of the section on philosophy it reads "To heed the misanthropic philosophical council we must surrender our puerile obsession with policing our own status..." Yeah
column6: right!  De Botton doesn't really seem to be writing for the reader
column7: more for himself
column8: and a very intellectual audience
column9: who probably will nod and agree with everything he says
column10: because they too are impressed they know so much too.  It's a shame that the book has turned out how it has as I think the subject would have made an entertaining read if written in a different style.  I was going to give it one star
column11: but De Botton has clearly researched his subject well whic earns it an extra star
column12: but don't expect to learn anything you don't know already

column1: Coupland's JPod is no exception to that rule. Although never blatantly publicized as a `sequel'
column2: it is hypothetically purported to be Coupland's new millennia answer to his early 1990s geek epic
column3: Microserfs.    My comparison
column4: Microserfs vs. JPod
column5: in short? Microserfs
column6: in my opinion
column7: was Coupland's zenith of writing aptitude -- fresh and original with `real' characters that many a geek could relate to. The microserfs made you want to care about what happened to them. The story actually went somewhere.   JPod? Stale as 3-week-old bread
column8: artificial as Twin Equal `sugar' packets
column9: featuring two-dimensional unbelievable characters. Gone are the refreshingly all-too-human disillusioned "microserfs" with their witty repertoires and flat foods. They are replaced with JPod'ers -- dusky
column10: gutter-mouthed and aimless
column11: with their couldn't-care-less-about-anything attitudes. The result? We could care less about them. Coupled with an implausible
column12: over-the-top
column13: and insipid plot
column14: it is a novel that evokes apathy and indfference. Coupland's frequent referrals (blatant plugs) to his other works of fiction were uncomfortable and tawdry.   Not that there weren't any redeeming qualities in the book. The reader is treated to a few remaining bits of Microserfs-esque laurels -- the memoir-like narrative
column15: the fun cubicle surveys ("if you were to sell yourself as an item on eBay...") and splash pages with binary
column16: spam
column17: and technical what-not. However
column18: it was not enough to compensate for JPod's weak plot and characters
column19: which ultimately made the novel uninteresting and difficult to finish. As much as I wanted to like it
column20: I didn't. At all.   It was mentioned by a friend and fellow Microserf-aficionado that it's "harder for authors to write like disenchanted young people when they have been rich and famous for 20 years."    I agree 101% and couldn't put it better myself.

column1: It isn't a bad book
column2: I just feel like I wasted my time reading it.  Mieville did a great job creating a strange

column4: reading Perdido Street Station was a significant investment.  It was interesting enough to hold my attention
column5: but I feel like the author made a deal with that he didn't follow through on: "You let me spend 300 pages fleshing out my world and characters
column6: and once you've let me introduce them completely
column7: I will give pay you back with a great story."  I never got paid back.    I read the last 75 pages becoming frustrated and feeling like I was cheated.  I understood the characters but did not care what they did.  The main story-thread was resolved and I never felt conflict
column8: drama or resolution.  The book didn't teach me or make me feel anything.  It was a well-imagined
column9: dull book that had enough novelty to keep me reading until the end.  Not recommended

column1: We bought all three sizes of collapsible Rubbermaid containers from Amazon.  Right off the bat I noticed that the lids were not engineered to fit the containers without the application of undue force.  Some would not seal at all. Trying to store left over pasta was an exercise in futility as the container tends to collapse upon sealing even when it is filled with food. My wife wants to through them out in the trash.  I plan to call Rubbermaid on their toll-free line to register a complaint. So much for trusting a brand name without doing enough research first
This book is unapologetically about triviality. It begins with the rise of popularity of the trivial
column2: illusion and fakery
column3: in America since the time of P.T. Barnum. It is about the creators and consumers of illusion who  replaced 'survivors' in after the transition to life in the megalopolis in  America. John Berger has pointed out that zoos
column4: stuffed animals
column5: pets and  eventually Disneyworld emerged as mankind became divorced from the fight to  survive against nature
column6: where animals were essential. The book does not  explain why
column7: in its appetite for illusion and triviality (consumerism
column8: consumption of the media) America is so advanced with respect to Europe  (the decline is there
column9: if slower: the worst Hollywood films are extremely  popular among Europe's youth). Gamson informs us of Holmes' expectation  that photography would lead to the triumph of superficiality
column10: and of  Boorstin's description of the celebrity as a person who is well-known for  his well-knownness. Political campaigns are accurately described as  pre-packaged media affairs
column11: where the participants have become game-players  and the events themselves
column12: like talk-shows
column13: have become pseudo-events.  People immitating the media immitating people. The future is trivial  because trivial expectations determine the future via pre-packaged daily  behavior. Gamson does not explain why we have evolved to this state of  super-triviality
column14: and why we seem to be stuck with it. This was more or  less explained poetically by Spengler
column15: and also poetically in still fewer  words by John Berger
column16: who informs us clearly and concisely on the subjects  of Gamson's discourse: "It would ... be possible to talk of the  'homelessness' of the bourgeois with his town house
column17: his country home
column18: his  three cars
column19: his televisions
column20: his tennis court
column21: his wine cellar-it would be  just possible
column22: yet nothing about his class interests me
column23: for there is  nothing left to discover." Gamson's book is precisely about the  people
column24: and their admirors
column25: about whom there is nothing worth discovering

column1: I have cracked heals and a bit of a callous problem.  They aren't dragon feet
column2: but they do have to be softened pretty often.  I have used the little blade scraper tool for a few years and that works well but when I saw the Artemis Heel Smoother advertised
column3: I decided I had to try it.  It's a waste of money.  The appliance is no more than a low-tech dreml.  In fact
column4: I have a Dreml type tool that was marketed as a dog nail trimmer that works better.  The Artemis appliance does NOT scrape any dried skin away..it merely sands your foot a bit..that is when you can get the darn thing to stay on the spot you put it on.  It comes with a small container of foot conditioning balm that is probably just straight cocoa butter except it has a really offensive aroma.  I would just as soon use a piece of sand paper than this thing.  Save your money.

column1: Although I myself confess I am no great fan of Heinlein's
column2: I found it hard to believe this was written by the author of "Stranger in a Strange Land" which is a masterly work. The idea behind "The Number of the  Beast" is appealing: a vast number of alternative universes
column3: endless possibilities for exploring mysteries and opportunities for a real sense of wonder. Unfortunately this is all wasted as heinlein trawls seemingly without purpose through an interminable series of unfunny jokes and mundane inanities. For example he invents a universe just like ours except with no letter J. He indulges his predeliction for creating middle aged women referred to as "Auntie" and adopts a writing  style which actually manages to parody his own already flawed and overly jaunty mannerisms. The satire is lost in a tale that is quite simply
column4: utterly lifeless. In short
column5: "The Number of the Beast" is a disaster and caused me to avoid Heinlein for years until I read "Stranger in a Strange Land." Even though I don't really like his works as a whole
column6: even I was able to recognise the extent to which he has fallen below his own standard with this trash

column1: Warning
column2: before reading this book make sure you are well schooled in the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan
column3: US involvement with Somalia
column4: the Persian Gulf War
column5: and Islam. The more you know about these subjects the more you will realize that Bergen interjects his political opinions throughout the book with side comments; by selectively adding some facts and leaving out others; and by the clever arrangements of facts.  Bergen is biased against the US and eerily; the net affect is some sort of weird admiration for OBL.  Bergen falls for some of OBL's twisted
column6: misrepresentation of the Koran. See page 99 and note the Bergen's equalization of the words infidel and idolater. He also defends OBL's rants against the US by clarifying for the reader that UN sanctions killed 500
column7: 000 Iraqi children. Of course Bergen leaves out Saddam Hussein's role in starving his own people.  Bergen's account of the murder of Abdullah Azzam (Bergen calls him OBL's mentor) follows right after discussion with former Pakistani Prime Minister so this arrangement implies that somehow they are connected. Other scholars suspect OBL of murdering Azzam. This Bergen ignores.  In his discussion of the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan he spends all his time talking from the side of the rebels. He gives no background as to events leading up to it
column8: nor the poor military practices in the Soviet army which contributed to its own defeat. The Soviet Union published an after action review
column9: The Bear Went Over the Mountain
column10: that points out individual combat leaders and mistakes they made that were grievous enough so that any band of rebels could have beaten them. Bergen only presents OBL view that he brought down a super power. He does mention the US made Stinger missile
column11: but spends more time talking about how clumsy the US was to let some of these go unaccounted for; rather than mentioning that without the Stinger the Soviets would not have pulled out.  In Chapter 4
column12: he mentions Desert Storm and out of left field adds the fact the Timothy McVeigh was one of the 500
column13: 000 US troops there. He adds that before 9-11 OK City was the worst terrorist activity in US. The subliminal message is US Army is an equivalent terrorist organization as Al-Qaeda. Later he outright says training in an Al-Qaeda camp is better that basic training in the Army.   In discussing Somalia
column14: he makes sure the reader is aware George H Bush got US involved. He leaves out background information about the UN and Boutris Boutris Ghali role in tribal conflict. He claims at "least 500" Somalis died when more respected accounts put the number at 3000. He says US "tried" to capture and never mention they did capture two bad guys. In all he makes the US look foolish and A-Qaeda's cause of serious blow against US. He doesn't mention the decision by Les Aspin to hamper the mission by denying the US its own armor-protected vehicles.   While recounting OBL's case against the US (like the reader is suppose to take this seriously) he adds his opinion that for two thousand years Christians don't follow the teachings of Jesus.  I'm not half way through the book and I'm sorry I bought it.   I was hoping for a documented history about OBL. Instead I got the CNN view of the world - OBL is a deeply religious man
column15: a great military leader
column16: a successful businessman
column17: and has a legitimate case against the US
column18: which by default is guilty.

column1: This short book is about the small Tuck family (a man
column2: his wife
column3: two young-adult sons
column4: and their horse)
column5: who inadvertently drink from a magic spring which renders them immortal.  Thereafter
column6: they do not age
column7: and seem immune to death by violence or accident.  In this state
column8: they seem to live a happy
column9: almost idyllic existence.  Nonetheless
column10: they bemoan their fate as a sort of curse
column11: which has removed them from the cycle of life.  Mrs. Tuck especially seems convinced that it would be a disaster if anyone else were to find out about the magic spring.  The exception to this sighing and moaning is the youngest son
column12: who
column13: perhaps because he has the good fortune to be stuck at 17
column14: seems reasonably satisfied with his fate.  The main events of the story take place 84 years later
column15: when a series of improbable coincidences involving the Tucks
column16: an 11-year old girl
column17: and a mysterious stranger
column18: together with some idiotic behavior by all concerned
column19: converge to force events to an contrived climax.  The author hints that these improbable convergences have some deep mystical significance.  Since this mysticism remains obscure
column20: one is inclined to instead suspect lazy plotting.  The stupidity
column21: and moral depravity
column22: of the Tucks is evident in the fact that
column23: for the last 84 years
column24: they have done virtually nothing to conceal
column25: guard
column26: protect or destroy the magic spring.  And yet when (by pure luck) they learn that the spring is about to be discovered
column27: they are willing to commit kidnapping and even murder to keep the secret from getting out.   The author strives to make the murder victim as unlikable as possible so that the killer (the Tuck mom) will retain our sympathies.  But the bottom line is that the sole motive for the murder is that the victim knew too much and could not be counted upon to keep a secret.  I cannot possibly agree that Mrs. Tuck had any right
column28: therefore
column29: to take his life.  The fact that the victim gloats about his less-than-noble intentions immediately before she shoots him
column30: does not make her act any more morally palatable.  The stream
column31: after all
column32: does not belong to the Tucks.  What right have they to play God
column33: and take lives to prevent others from sharing their high and lonely (if idyllic) destiny?  Setting aside moral questions
column34: the stupidity of the Tucks is nothing compared to the stupidity of the villain.  Why on Earth did he not drink from the stream and render himself immortal?  Why on Earth did he not do this before going all by himself to a secluded location to have a gloating
column35: taunting confrontation with four fully-grown immortals.  He is fully aware that the Tucks are determined to keep their secret
column36: he knows exactly why
column37: and he knows they are desperate or depraved enough to commit the kidnapping of a child for this purpose.  In fact
column38: why does he confront them at all?  They were completely unnecessary to his plans
column39: as he himself points out when
column40: predictably
column41: the Tucks refuse to agree to them.  Bottom line is
column42: he went merely because the author wanted to give Mrs. Tuck an opportunity to shoot him
column43: and he gloated and taunted only so the reader might say "Ha
column44: serves you right"
column45: when sweet Mrs. Tuck blows his head off with a shotgun.  One of the ironies of this story is that
column46: although the Tucks are convinced that the widespread availability of the magic water would be a disaster
column47: we are nonetheless supposed to despise the villain for his selfishness
column48: when he reveals his plan to disseminate the water only to those well-paying persons he considers most deserving.   And yet when Jesse
column49: the youngest immortal
column50: starts plotting to do something similar
column51: we are expected to retain our sympathies for him.  I suppose this is because Jesse is a hot-looking 17-year old
column52: is motivated (one supposes) by romance rather than cash
column53: and his offer is
column54: in effect
column55: being made to the young female who is the target audience of this book.    I have no need to say how this latter plot thread resolves itself.  In the end
column56: the moral of the story is ambiguous.  There is a lot of preaching about the curse of immortality
column57: and the virtue of remaining a part of the life cycle

column59: or that
column60: if we should find it

column13: population expansion
column14: & the money multiplier (the average dollar's spent 6x/year).  His "social credit/dividend" system is utopian to an extreme & p. 243: "We don't need social service workers where poverty is unknown" is absurd--$ won't buy a child's mental/emotional health anymore than happiness.  Heinlein fans (he's my favorite SF novelist) may find it historically/developmentally enlightening
column15: but as fiction
column16: it's his worst novel

column1: Towards the middle of 1988
column2: Castro
column3: who had taken personal control of the war
column4: wanted to withdraw from Angola and discussions began on how this could be accomplished without losing face. One of Castro's top generals in Angola had already tried to defect and Moscow was pressing Castro to reach a settlement. The Cuban leader adopted an aggressive stance and threw more Cuban troops into the front line in order to lend weight to his negotiating position in the peace talks. General Del Pino
column5: who also defected to the West
column6: pointed out that it was pure bluff on Castro's part and that he feared defeat was imminent.  Cuban forces
column7: integrated with SWAPO units
column8: nevertheless pressed on to within 12 kilometres of the Namibian border. Facing 11
column9: 000 Cubans and perhaps 2
column10: 000 SWAPO was a force of 500 battle-hardened men from 32 "Buffalo" Battalion
column11: the only available troops at the border until reinforcements could arrive. They held the line until tanks and artillery could be moved up. Cuban MiG-23s joined the fray and one was shot down. As the South African forces prepared to move North to engage the Cubans in what promised to be a Cuban nemesis
column12: the Cubans signed the New York peace accords and avoided disaster.  The Cubans immediately claimed victory
column13: which Bridgland points out was 'nonsense'
column14: but that:  the Cuban story was taken at face value by Castro's sympathisers in the Western press and repeated so many times that it became received truth. The Cubans were helped by the South Africans' own clumsy efforts at propaganda
column15: which amounted to saying as little as possible about the full-scale war they fought in Angola. The SADF at no stage had wanted an all-out war that would take them to Luanda as conquerors. Their objectives had been to fight a limited war in support of UNITA and prevent the Cubans from capturing UNITA's strongholds. The SADF had succeeded in this and was content to let the Cubans take the limelight. As Bridgland points out in his final summary of the war:  The War for Africa and the New York accords provided Cuba with pretexts for slipping out of a commitment that had become too hot and too expensive to handle. In 1975
column16: when the Cuban adventure in Angola began
column17: the 'scientific socialist' and 'internationalist' tide running from Moscow looked unstoppable. By 1988 it was a faded dream. Despite 13 years of Cuban support
column18: the Angolan economy was ruined. The Marxist MPLA was in utter disarray and was trying desperately to shed its 'scientific-socialist' past... Castro's dreams of a Marxist revolution spreading from Angola to encompass the whole of Southern Africa had become a poor music hall joke...  "The War for Africa" by Fred Bridgland....the most accurate account of Cuba's involvement in the Angolan conflict.

column1: Berkhof's Systmatic is of course a classic text that is a gem.  I had the old Banner Of Truth edition for years but like a dope sold it for pennies on the dollar.  This edition from Eerdmans is truly abominable.    Where do I start?  First off
column2: the font size is terrible.  So if you are over 58 the eye strain is quite significant.  Then comes the print type.  It is almost as if someone churned out copies in his garage.  The printing is extremely bad.  Sentences contain words that after a letter or two turn light and then dark and in a few instances downright smudgy.  Was the typeset dirty?  Did you run out of ink?  True
column3: this edition contains Berkhof's introductory section which is a bonus.  But what good is it if the production quality is abysmal?  How unfortunate that such a magnificient work is so insulted.   Mr. Publisher
column4: check out Shedd's Dogmatic Theology by P and R Publishers.  That is how one presents a text of significance.    If you have the Banner Of Truth edition do not trade it in lest you rue the day.

column1: If James K. Polk hadn't very unexpectedly become president of the United States in 1845
column2: nobody today would have heard of him.  The accomplishments he is remembered for -- the annexation of Texas
column3: the acquiring of Oregon Territory from Britain
column4: the War with Mexico and resultant annexation of New Mexico and California -- he was able to accomplish only BECAUSE he became president.  So why does John Seigenthaler devote less than forty of 156 pages of text to Polk's presidency in his book
column5: JAMES K. POLK?  JAMES K. POLK is one of "The American Presidents" series which are supposed to concentrate on the PRESIDENCIES of the chief executives
column6: not the whole lives of the men themselves.  Admitted
column7: exploring the biographical and historical background and the process by which particular individuals are able to win the White House over the opposition of many other contenders is essential to understanding the presidencies they spawn -- doubly so in Polk's case as America's first "dark horse" president.  But the other equally short contributions to this series are quite capable of covering such material in the first thirty or forty pages of text
column8: leaving the remaining one hundred plus to discuss the presidency itself.  Given the constraints of this series and the incredible presidency that was to be Polk's
column9: it is Seigenthaler's DUTY to do the same.  I bought this book to learn how a president
column10: whom I knew very little about
column11: was able in four short years to create
column12: for better or worse
column13: a United States that finally spread "from sea to shinning sea".  Thirty some pages is nowhere near enough text to discuss the complications that Polk had to deal with in his War with Mexico alone
column14: particularly when Polk thought he could annex California WITHOUT going to war.  Seigenthaler hardly mentions the problems that the obstinate Democrat Polk had with his two equally headstrong Whig generals
column15: Taylor and Scott
column16: or the increasingly fierce opposition he faced as the war dragged on and on.  Ditto for the Oregon Territory dispute with the British.  He devotes more text to Polk's establishing an independent Treasury and lowering the import tariffs
column17: but these achievements pale in comparison to the previous two   Seigenthaler wastes far more text telling the story of how the washed-up ex-governor from Tennessee hoping for the vice-presidential candidacy
column18: won the 1844 Democratic Party's presidential nomination instead when neither of the two top contenders could secure a majority.  Then Seigenthaler proceeds with an almost equally long description of the campaign itself -- during which Polk did NOT make public campaign promises to annex California and gain the Oregon border treaty with England
column19: but merely promised to accept the annexation of Texas and serve only one term.  The "four goals" that he had for his presidency he first confided to his secretary of the navy AFTER becoming president (check out pp. 102
column20: 3).  Imagine a book of some one hundred fifty pages about another rather obscure ex-congressman from Illinois named Abraham Lincoln that devotes less than forty to his presidency and barely mentions the Civil War.  Change the main character and you've got John Seigenthaler's JAMES K. POLK.

column1: I'd heard the buzz (both pro and con) and thought I'd take an independent read. I was dismayed with this book. James Frey has insulted anyone who has gone through a real experience with substance addiction by trivializing the truth of whatever experience he really had. One of the hardest things an addict has to grasp is the TRUTH so that he can take ownership of his actions and take the 12 steps or whatever is necessary to save his life and often the lives of loved ones tangled up in the mess with him. Lies are what enable "slips" and "enabling" and "denial" and those other catch words that describe continued misery and failure. Recovery is nearly impossible without honesty. So
column2: can we look at this man's "memoir" and expect it to offer anything of value? It's poorly constructed
column3: repetitive
column4: and narcisitic. Even if Oprah hadn't exposed him
column5: the writing takes the tone of "whoppers" like Frey's account of the drug house visit in which he "rescues" Lilly. Other reviewers and Smoking Gun have written about the fantastic episodes one by one
column6: and I can't improve on that. Suffice to say this mockery of misery and hope is no more real than a daytime soap opera.  Story lines in a soap may look like real life to one who is isolated from real life
column7: the same way A Million Little Pieces might look to someone who has not been touched by real addiction. A real addict with typical delusion could be misdirected from a true course of treatment with tragic result. I was left with the impression he thinks institutions and people who help others with substance recovery are pitifully misdirected or inept. Like a joke of some kind. I'm not laughing.

column1: Brandon Sanderson's debut deserves great praise for offering the rarest of fantasies:  a stand-alone novel.  Furthermore
column2: he eschews the classic tropes of fantastical races in favor of a modern-fantasy type medieval world fragmented by religious politics and a mysterious biological plague.  Unfortunately
column3: little else in _Elantris_ is as original or promising as the concept.  The pace is numbingly slow
column4: especially in the early chapters of Sarene discovering her way through Arelon.  Huge passages of expository dialog between her and her Tinker Bell-like floating confidant serve only to dump background information on the reader.  Clunky prose repeatedly distracts from the tale.  Sanderson's fantasy names are too similar to avoid confusion
column5: often starting with the same series of letters:  Derethi religion and Dathreki Mountains
column6: arteth priest and Arelon kingdom
column7: Fjon the priest and Fjordell the religion.    Worse still
column8: the characters are shallow modern archetypes--the tables-turned prince and his world-wise new friend
column9: the harsh militant priest
column10: and the perky young princess who changes the world.  They react most predictably to the situations they face
column11: and many of those situations seem gratuitously engineered by the author to force the outcome he wishes.  The dialog is laughably wooden
column12: lines that real people would never say.  "'Something just doesn't feel right here
column13: '" Sarene tells Ashe at one point
column14: and she's exactly right.  Sanderson's concept is wise and full of potential
column15: but his writing is not yet equal to that challenge

column3: Tom moves into a diatribe of Panentheism and peppers most of the book with this type of theology that has proven inconsistent in and of itself. If you don't know
column4: Panentheism is a way of explaining that "Everything is in God". At the surface that sounds great. But there is more to it. It also ascribes that God is so intertwined in the creation that he cannot live apart from it. Man. That is a leap...since God is the same yesterday
column5: today and tomorrow
column6: and He was so BEFORE he made the earth.  OK>..so you see. Tom moves away from a real answer to the guilt issue to explain a theology that has no foundation in truth.  If you want the guilt answer...doooo noooott buy this book. Instead
column7: buy a bible. Holman Press just came out with a great one. Read the first few verses of Romans chapter 8. Then buy a couple of great commentaries that discuss them. If you want the short answer. Hear it is. "We are not ever going to be good enough. And that is OK. God forgives all of us. Just accept that fact." Don't stop trying though. It helps others see the Good in GOD when they see it. Being good is not for going to heaven. It is to help show others that there is a good God to go to heaven to see!

column1: The book can be used as a repository of useful anecdotes. However
column2: it doesn't bring much new. If you're a beginner in the SCM field then it will definitely open your eyes to some operational challenges companies face all the time. But for the experienced professional
column3: this book is of no great value (some of the anecdotes are interesting though)... We
column4: as supply chain professionals
column5: need to upgrade our thinking and admit that our role is not to eliminate uncertainty but rather mitigate it... and that's the best we can do... as such
column6: one cannot possibly come up with a bullet proof model but rather an approach to handle risk... the key attribute to all of this thinking is how much risk we can live with? that's it... truly
column7: that's all that's needed to be told! My reaction to the example of Apple reducing its inventory and then getting a major supply disruption because of some disaster in Asia is So? What can you do? The only thing you can is to define your tolerance for risk and conduct some tradeoff analysis: what matters more? keeping low level of inventory and therefore reducing likelihood and scope of obsolescence (tangible)? or is it minimizing potential for lost sales (intangible)? That's the basic question

column27: or else each character seems to belong to a stereotype of some sort. Tolkien avoids both pitfalls while simultaneously acknowledging that
column28: yes
column29: sometimes it's reassuring to a person/character to have a stereotype to fall back upon for a sense of identity when circumstances require.   Once our fellowship finally goes into battle
column30: we get some great sequences. Among many fine performances
column31: those of Frodo and Gandalf stand out in my mind. Oh
column32: and "never toss a dwarf
column33: which I KNOW Tolkien didn't write. Anxiously awaiting part two.   THE TWO TOWERS   What's more boring than real world politics? Fictional politics! I don't believe Tolkien spent this much time on the war aspect. Well, I hope he didn't. Saruman makes a bunch of uber-Orcs and sics 'em on humanity. Fine. We don't need a cast of thousands to spend hours in mock battles. Nor do we need the lamest excuse for a love story" in cinematic history.   But once we FINALLY get past all that
column34: I believe we get back to the Tolkien vision. Here's hoping we stay there for part three.   (Two hours
column35: two paragraphs. What's wrong with this picture?)   THE RETURN OF THE KING   A balanced attack. That's what THE TWO TOWERS lacks but THE RETURN OF THE KING has. By this
column36: I mean that long sustained fight sequences are boring. That's not your "action
column37: unless your name's Jackie Chan. Give us just enough fight to let us move from plot point to plot point, then switch over to the real conflict before we get bored and leave the theater.   {No hate mail from Jackie Chan fans, please. I love SHANGHAI NOON.}   The real drama comes in the interpersonal, and in Frodo versus that @#$%^* ring. Gollum is one freaky deaky, ain't he? Liv Tyler is still unwatchable, but fortunately her screen time was minimal.   We get very close to the end of this film before Hollywood excess creeps into the war scenes. Those very cool elephants, for example, seem unstoppable. I was quite impressed with Orlando Bloom's quietly effective performances, but I'll never believe his computer simulated double took down one of those big bad muthas. Those elephants are doomsday machines, and the heroes' strongholds were Hiroshima and Nagasaki.   Meanwhile back at the ranch, perhaps we had one too many dramatic rescues that stretched credibility. Sam the Hobbit versus HOW MANY orcs? Um, lest we forget, he's only a freakin hobbit!   I don't know if it was the screenwriters who wrote themselves into a corner or perhaps Tolkien himself. But, well, somebody damn sure did. Let's floor the gas over those speedbumps and see what's on the other side.   Unlike some critics, I appreciated that this film didn't end at the climax." We needed some more time to just hang out in Middle Earth
column38: well over 9 hours after we entered the place

column41: and that includes the entire elven race. You can leave your Shire without leaving your world
column42: Tolkien. I did. I've been in China since 1999.   THE VERDICT   I appreciate Tolkien's imagination
column43: and I'm glad the film people made this. But I know it could be so much better with an editor. Yeah
column44: I'm talking about changing what Tolkien wrote if required.   (There goes another subscriber...) column2: I'm going to go against the grain here and say that Suttree really isn't all that good.  Maybe it's fine literature -- although personally I don't think so; I think literature should engage and tell a story that the reader can feel part of
column3: absorbed into with a pathos for its characters
column4: good or bad.  Here we get only snatches of that.  *At times* we feel akin to Suttree.  For example the prison segment is good; there is a sense of purpose and pace here absent from the rest of the book; but on the whole Suttree is a rambling and confusing mess.  Why struggle so much with a book?  It's not that the ideas are so incredibly complex -- sure
column5: at times it's sublime -- but it has a purposefully disconnected storyline.  The reader is meant to feel in the dark and only slowly pick up on the context and setting of the scenes.  The relationship between Suttree and Harrogate is great

column1: I think this book is largely bogus. Sure there is logic in having an efficient system to your manufacturing process and in buying the machines you actually need instead of something too big or too inflexible. But while the Japanese may have ninjas and 'Asian sexual secrets
column2: ' they haven't discovered any new principles of manufacturing that we insecure Americans didn't already know a long time ago. Despite the stylish Japanese mumbo-jumbo
column3: there isn't much in this 'lean thinking' that Henry Ford didn't already have figured out by 1914
column4: although the limitations of the technology of that day prevented him from implementing his ideas fully.  Speaking of Henry Ford
column5: among the historical inaccuracies in this book is the oft-repeated untruth that all the millions of Ford Model T cars produced over 19 years were all exactly alike. The truth is that several body styles
column6: ranging from open touring cars to 'Torpedo Roadsters' to closed sedans were produced
column7: and the entire line went through at least two major styling changes and thousands of mechanical improvements.  Some parts of this book just don't make any sense at all
column8: revealing amazingly poor writing on the part of the authors and -- given that this is the revised edition -- an astonishing lack of critical thinking on the part of eager readers. For example
column9: on page 178 it is told how Pratt & Whitney replaced a particularly inefficient turbine blade grinding machine with 'eight simple three-axis grinding machines.' But in the very next paragraph they mention 'each of the nine machines
column10: ' and then go on to say
column11: 'The number of parts in the process would fall from about 1
column12: 640 to 15 (one in each machine plus one waiting to start and one blade just completed).' Then to top it off
column13: the text is accompanied by a diagram showing a grinding process with eight grinders and two EDM machines. I can see I'm not the only one who flunked math here.  Additionally
column14: the book is full of stories of Japanese lean thinking gurus walking into American factories without advance notice and ordering that all the production machinery be uprooted and repositioned -- immediately. Supposedly
column15: this is done and things brought up to running condition again in six or eight hours
column16: with greatly improved efficiency. Where I come from
column17: we have bothersome things like OSHA rules and the National Electrical Code that prevent us from just sliding around 100 ton presses and precision-levelled CNC machine tools like so many couches and chairs.  Also telling is the example the authors themselves picked to illustrate their concept of 'flow.' One of them asked his daughters
column18: aged six and nine
column19: what would be the best way to fold
column20: address
column21: seal
column22: stamp and mail the monthly issue of their mother's newsletter. The girls naturally replied that you ought to concentrate on one task at a time
column23: and process all the newsletters up to that point before moving on to the next step. But the authors assert that this is wrong
column24: and that this type of work can be done more efficiently by carrying one workpiece through to completion before starting on the next workpiece. Aside from the cruelty of forcing his daughters to walk out to the mailbox and back 547 times
column25: I can tell you from long experience that this is 100% pure BS. Flow is great
column26: as Henry Ford used flow. But to make a blanket statement that it is better to keep one workpiece in hand and pick up ten tools
column27: than it is to keep one tool in hand and pick up ten workpieces
column28: is just plain wrong. It is the tool that requires technique and concentration and uniformity of use
column29: not the workpiece. By spotlighting this ill-chosen example
column30: the authors have revealed in their own introduction a total lack of real-world experience and a disdain for common sense that runs throughout the entire book.

column5: like every one of Godard's post-Anna Karina films
column6: is more a flawed experiment than anything else: On occasion
column7: interesting and thought-provoking
column8: but more often static and didactic to the point of alienating the viewer rather than converting them. I respect Godard's attempt to create a new cinema built on "ideas" rather than "emotion"
column9: but in my opinion
column10: he went too far in this direction. A piece of art devoid of any emotion is a hollow experience and don't we have enough of that in our crude
column11: consumerist society? And as far as experiments go
column12: much of what he was doing in "Weekend"
column13: he had already done and with vastly better results in  "Pierrot le Fou". That film was a perfect balance between Godard the political-scientist and Godard the post-modern film-maker. Plus
column14: "Pierrot le Fou" benefited by having Jean-Paul Belmondo and Anna Karina. They brought heart and humor to Godard's abstract explosion of ideas; a perfect symbiotic relationship between director and actor(s) that he never achieved again. "Weekend" starts off very promising with the sex dialogue and the long tracking shot of the traffic-jam
column15: leading to a car-crash...but then it descends into a grating mess of dated ideology and too much dead space. You really wish Belmondo and Karina would pop in and show the cast they don't have to be mere nails to Godard's hammer.

column7: with complementary qualities

column12: "A Comprehensive Introduction to Differential Geometry".
