column5: I think
column6: because it mandates that you cut flour
column7: sugar
column8: and other foods completely from your diet.   I feel that this sets a person up to fail because one ends up feeling deprived
column9: which leads to binging.  In fact there is a whole chapter in the book that talks about case studies and nearly every person mentioned has relapsed and is valiantly trying to get back to abstinence and lose the weight yet again.  I would suggest that instead of working a program that obviously isn't working
column10: they should perhaps seek another solution
column11: maybe in the form of professional counseling.  I would recommend "The Solution" by Laurel Mellin
column12: which is a comprehensive support solution with groups and pyschologists around the country practicing the methods given in the book.  I have found this method much more helpful than Overeaters Anonymous ever was.  If OA is working for you
column13: then I think that is great
column14: but if you are like me and do not find that it fits you
column15: I encourage you to look elsewhere.  The Solution is a great place to start

I normally don't put a book down without finishing it
column2: especially one in the genre of classic American literature.  However
column3: Hemingway's English translations were so irritating
column4: trite
column5: and immature that I could not get past them.  The use of "thy" and "thou" to indicate the ud. form is ridiculous in 20th century English.  Quoting the characters as asking
column6: "How do you call yourself?" instead of "What is your name?" is downright silly.  If Hemingway really wanted to convey what the characters were saying literally
column7: he should have simply quoted them in Spanish and provided a translation in parentheses or in an index.  Regardless
column8: who needs a literal translation?  How is "How do you call yourself" better than "What is your name"?  And is it really important to know who uses ud. to whom when this form doesn't even exist in modern English?  I found these "translations" so distracting from what was going on that I couldn't continue past chapter 2.  I get the impression that the hundreds of reviewers who have raved about this book over the past 65 years don't speak Spanish.

column2: I always thought the guys who complained about the CD remastering of Dylan's albums were full of themselves. However
column3: I was quite surprised that nobody sees the problems with this remastering.  I borrowed the remastered "Nashville Skyline" CD from a friend a few years ago when he found out I had never heard the album before. I listened to it a few times and promptly returned it
column4: stating that it was really disappointing. It sounded like a short
column5: poorly-recorded album of Dylan with a weird voice. When I tracked down a good turntable
column6: I picked up a bunch of Dylan vinyl to see how other albums fared in comparison to the CDs. I finally got around to "Nashville Skyline" last month
column7: and discovered that the album was pretty good. The sound quality was much better than I remembered
column8: even though my vinyl copy is pretty scratchy. Then
column9: I ordered the remastered CD last week
column10: thinking that I didn't give it a good chance the first time...............  Oh boy! What a tragedy. The remastered CD is truly as awful as I remember. I could not believe that the CD could have been worse
column11: so I did a track by track analysis. Turns out the entire CD suffers from problems not found on the vinyl. The CD has noticeable tape hiss
column12: with attenuation of the higher frequencies
column13: and a complete lack of punch. The real travesty is that some tracks sound like they have been remixed
column14: as some instruments have been relocated and brought up or down in level. A real travesty considering the vinyl mix is pretty good. The remastering problems really "cheapen" the album overall.   If you have this album on vinyl
column15: just listen to the first few acoustic guitar chords and how they have a "bite" to them on the record that is gone on the CD. It only gets worse from there. This is the only remastered Dylan CD I have been disappointed with. I regret buying the CD and will wind up making a CD copy of my record.

column1: I first ordered this guitar in another color and after about a week of checking the mail with my little boy every day
column2: I was informed that it was out of stock. I re-ordered in the bodacious blue and it came Friday. It literally came in the cardboard box that you would buy it off of the shelf in with no packing besides a plastic bag around the guitar like your newspaper would come in. There was NO PACKAGING SLIP. I took it out of the plastic and the body of the guitar was damaged around the edge. There was a little divit the size of a raisin where it looked like it had hit something pretty hard. There was literally slack in the strings
column3: so they had to be tightened. It would not stay in tune and I would tighten the strings and you could see them loosen again immediately. My little boy began to play with the out of tune guitar that sounded TERRIBLE and the next day one of the strings broke!!! This toy is a piece of junk. The sales pitch says a fully functional guitar... great value for the money.... HAHAHA! I thought this would be a great starter guitar with little investment. I would only recommend this if you are needing a prop or decoration of some kind. It certainly isn't playable! I have no slip to send it back and what I would have to pay in shipping would probably be near what I paid for the thing. Don't waste your money!

column1: Have you ever desperately wanted a book to end but hated leaving it unfinished?  That's the way Sappho's Leap was for me. I finally finished it over the weekend and am still wishing I hadn't spent good money
column2: even bad money
column3: any money on it.  Admittedly
column4: very little is known about the only ancient Greek female poet besides where she probably lived and a few snippets of her poetry. Her words are searing
column5: lovely and sometimes erotic. But Erica Jong's novel fictionalizing her life was banal and boring and droll. Sappho
column6: as her heroine is not only uninteresting
column7: but has no single aspect of her personality that makes me like her. Sure
column8: she experiences heartache and longing
column9: but Jong simply fails to give me a reason to care.  Jong just tells me
column10: flatly
column11: in first person
column12: how Sappho feels and what she thinks
column13: but doesn't make it real for me. She tries to make Sappho into a female Odysseus and can't figure out if the novel should be a fantasy or a semi-believable historical account. And all that wrapped up with a very disappointing
column14: Hollywood ending
column15: tied it off into an unequivocal piece of garbage.  I can't believe Erica Jong has actually written and published eight novels.  It honestly seems like she wrote Sappho's Leap specifically to sell to high school English departments to teach a bit of Greek history with a feminist slant.  Regardless of whatever pocket genre she was trying to exploit
column16: Sappho's Leap is utter tripe

column1: Here's the news:less than half the forces on the allied side on D Day were from the  U.S. Would you guess that from reading Ambrose's book? - nope. The vast bulk of the volume is devoted to the U.S. experience. It seems Ambrose thinks the British
column2: Canadians etc were just there to make up the numbers.  It's just not acceptable for a historian to devote the bulk of what purports to be an account of that day to one national contingent and then call it 'D Day' . To perpetrate that is petty and appallingly parochial.  Worse: it's offensive to the memories of ALL those who fought and died for democracy. The American sacrifice was real and  doesn't need this sort of thing to keep its memory green.  Robin Neillands and John Keegan have both written much better
column3: fairer accounts.  If Ambrose had called the book 'the American contribution to D-Day' no one could have complained. As it is
column4: it has no claim to our serious consideration as history.

column1: I recently purchased this book and was somewhat disappointed when I sat down to read it. The subtitle is "Games & Puzzles to Stimulate Your Creativity & Imagination". Actually
column2: there are only some  thirty such puzzles and many of them are 'old chestnuts'. However
column3: my  biggest complaint is the lack of accuracy. The very first puzzle (p. 20)  has a mistake in it. Then in 'Mental Counting' (p. 161)
column4: the author claims  that the letters O and U are not symmetrical about the vertical axis. As  for 'Three-dimesional Dots' (p. 199) the text states "Below is a  collection of random dots." Unfortunately
column5: the random dots have been  omitted. So much for "something remarkable" happening as the  author claims. And how's this for one of the three (yup
column6: only three)  lateral thinking puzzles? What common word begins with IS
column7: ends with ND
column8: and has LA in the middle? I bet that really stretched your brain
column9: didn't  it? Sorry
column10: but Mr. Wujec's editor should be fired. These glaring mistakes  and omissions have scuttled any enjoyment I may have expected from this  book. I suspect the author was motivated by the commercial success of his  previous book. He should have waited until he had something of value before  publishing this schlock

column1: Time was when the words Betty Crocker actually stood for something good in cookbooks
column2: although the books' recipes
column3: for better or for worse
column4: were always a product of their times.  The very first "Betty Crocker Picture Cook Book" was published in 1950 (still available)
column5: revolutionized how cookbooks were produced
column6: and was an enormous best-seller.  The recipes were the result of much thorough testing in the company's kitchens and in homes across America.  This was cooking from scratch with very little reliance on convenience foods in its pages.  This gradually changed as Betty and her books became more and more of a shill for General Mills' products and her name got plastered on one mix after another to the benefit of the company's bottom line
column7: but to the detriment of good cooking.    The two all-purpose cookbooks that came out in 1961 and 1969 were both loaded with recipes and wonderful tips/helps
column8: although you could see the beginnings of sacrificing quality for convenience--especially in the 1969 edition--but this was still relatively minor in proportion to the majority of the recipes.  If you have one of these books
column9: treasure and keep it; you'll never see their likes again.  The current 10th edition looks good but
column10: like the past several editions
column11: the number of recipes has been drastically reduced.  Gone are the many variations
column12: which are especially missed in baked goods.  It was wonderful having recipes of many cakes that were sized for two people or small families and having different mixing methods to choose from.  Now way too many recipes are of the "dump and stir" method instead of choosing methods that would insure the best results.  Also gone is the very friendly
column13: assuring
column14: conversationial voice of yesteryear.  Yes
column15: there are recipes covering a wider range of ingredients and styles
column16: but they are mostly stripped-down versions.    It's obvious that the folks at Betty Crocker now seem to think that no one really cooks anymore and can't be bothered with proper preparation of dishes
column17: which begs the question of why General Mills even bothers to publish these cookbooks anymore.  The "Better Homes and Gardens New Cookbook" is a better bet for those looking for an all-purpose
column18: everyday guide.  It has a better layout
column19: the recipes and ingredients are generally of a higher quality
column20: and there are more recipes and variations than Betty Crocker's had in some time.  Even better
column21: if you care at all about the quality of the food you eat and serve your family
column22: I highly recommend the cookbooks of Cooks' Illustrated/America's Test Kitchen.  Their comparable
column23: general-purpose cookbook is called "The America's Test Kitchen Family Cookbook."  The recipes are tested and reworked--dozens of times
column24: if necessary--to be the best their staff can make them and you get precise directions in preparing them.  It's a shame that Betty Crocker has abdicated her throne and good name
column25: but there's even better stuff out there now.  Go for it!

column1: This book is a self-indulgent wallow in the mire of despair.  Wolfe starts with the supposition that "our earliest ancestors. . . crawled out of the primeval slime
column2: that God is an unwitting spirit" in "remote eternity
column3: and consequently that prayer is useless and the earth is forgotten, and then whines when he is left with the natural conclusions of a godless world view: that life is accidental, without meaning and without hope.  The characters fumble around, looking for salvation in a stone
column4: a leaf
column5: an unfound door
column6: (tragically rejecting the Way, the Truth, and the Life) only to find at last that there is no point in looking for salvation at all, since There is no happy land. There is no end to hunger
column7: YOU are your world."  This book is unorthodox
column8: unwholesome
column9: and unhealthy.  Avoid it for your own good

I decided to read a book on the five-hour flight from MCO to LAX
column2: and then on the return flight of something less than five hours.  (Flying downwind eastbound
column3: of course.)  I purchased "The Aquataine Progression" by Robert Ludlum
column4: in paperback form.  (I must admit that I still can't get used to spending $7.95 for a paperback book!  But
column5: the horrors of inflation obviously continue to haunt us into the 21st century
column6: and beyond.  This promised to be worth the price inasmuch as it was touted as a "New York Times Bestseller.")  I got to Page 17 of the 658-page book before I gagged.  I managed to read only a few more pages before I set it aside disgustedly.  I quote from the book to explain why:  "Lieutenant Senior Grade Gordon Ramsey had been hit by a fluke rocket that had winged out of its trajectory over the coastline and in on Ramsey's fuselage; the explosion had filled the jet streams" - - (etc).  This almost stopped me in my tracks.  The reason for my hesitancy being the fact that there is no such grade or rank in the US Navy as "Lieutenant Senior Grade."  My inclination is to think that a noted author like Robert Ludlum (or the editor at Bantam Books) should know that while there is
column7: indeed
column8: a rank of "Lieutenant Junior Grade" in the US Navy
column9: there (conversely) is NO such rank as
column10: "Lieutenant Senior Grade."  (The ranks of "Ensign
column11: Lieutenant Junior Grade" and "Lieutenant" equate to "Second Lieutenant
column12: First Lieutenant" and "Captain" in all other branches of service except the US Coast Guard which echoes the rank structure of the Navy.  Most confusing
column13: of course
column14: is that the rank of "Captain" in the Navy is equivalent to "Colonel" in the other services. )  I swallowed my disapproval
column15: and continued to read.  But then
column16: the author goes on to tell us that the skipper of the aircraft carrier
column17: a Captain
column18: calls in our protagonist
column19: a Lieutenant Junior Grade
column20: to inform him that he is being promoted to squadron commander after "Lieutenant Senior Grade" Ramsey met his fate with the rocket as previously mentioned.  Here again
column21: I blanched.  A skipper of an aircraft carrier would hardly deal directly with a Lieutenant "Jay Gee" (JG
column22: for "Junior Grade") to inform him of such a thing.  There are
column23: of course
column24: officers of intervening rank and intervening commands and responsibilities below that of the skipper of the ship. You would have other Commanders
column25: Lieutenant Commanders
column26: and Lieutenants who would be in the chain of command between the skipper and the protagonist.  If there's one thing that's paramount in the military
column27: its delegation of authority!  It would certainly be somebody else who would inform the JG of his "promotion."  So
column28: I had to swallow hard
column29: again
column30: and go along with the absurd notion that a Lt. JG would report directly to a Captain
column31: let alone the skipper of the boat.  Then
column32: while these two are conferring
column33: a four-star general shows up unannounced via a tender to chew-out the Navy Captain.  Aw
column34: come on.  Between the four-star and the Captain are three-star generals
column35: two-star generals and one-star generals.  The chain of command would insert these people into the mix well before a four-star would come and deal directly with a four-striper
column36: let alone "chew him out."  After all
column37: one is ARMY
column38: and the other is NAVY.  The ticked-off general would vent his anger through not only his own chain of command
column39: but decidedly through the chain of command of the US Navy.  I swallowed hard
column40: again
column41: but kept reading.  Now
column42: what happens is that the general proceeds to chew-out the captain while the JG is still present in the quarters.  BIG SWALLOW this time.  NEVER in military protocol or in the constraints of military courtesy would a senior officer berate a junior officer in front of somebody who was junior to THAT officer!  It just does NOT happen - - except in B-grade movies that aren't worth the price of admission.  Not only that
column43: but we are now supposed to believe that the JG interrupts the general
column44: and tells him that he's off base for berating the captain.  I almost upchucked!  The captain dismisses the JG
column45: but he refuses to leave (yeah
column46: sure!) and continues to give the general a piece of his mind.  (Yeah sure
column47: again.)  After all
column48: he's a hot-rock fighter pilot
column49: and he's not gonna let some four-star berate the skipper that just promoted him to squadron commander
column50: right?  The general absorbs the static from the JG
column51: but "orders" the Captain to launch a strike despite the unfavorable and deteriorating weather over the target.  He calls the captain "chicken" if he doesn't order the strike
column52: and calls the JG "chicken" if he doesn't fly it.  So
column53: the JG and everybody else fly the mission rather than being labeled as "chicken" despite the previous critical decision regarding unfavorable weather (which
column54: of course
column55: is a ridiculous contention) and the JG gets shot down.  Okay
column56: this is a far as I got in the book.  It's just entirely too hollow and too outlandish in its premise to entice me to read any further.  This sophomoric rhetoric brings this book down to comic-book level.  I can't believe the blurb that says this bookspent time on the best seller list of the New York Times!  But then
column57: I guess that inasmuch as so few of the American public will spend any time in military service these days
column58: this kind of bull-loney can pass for "real world" scenarios and the author can weave such bull-loney into a "believable" plot.  It's a shame.  And
column59: so is this book!  Carl B. Jordan

column1: Why is it that when you combine great solo musicians into an all-star lineup the whole is usually less than the sum of its parts? I came to this CD with high hopes featuring as it does four veteran country singers with great reputations.  Despite not being an especially big Mel Tillis fan
column2: I can honestly say that each of the other three have written at least one tune I consider among my favourite songs ever (not just favourite country songs
column3: favourite overall: Waylon Jennings "Lukenbach
column4: Texas". Jerry Reed's "When You're Hot
column5: You're Hot"
column6: Bobby Bare's "Detroit City"). I also knew that Shel Silverstein was involved and thought that would be a good thing as he can be a clever writer.  Like one other reviewer here
column7: I'm gonna lay blame at Silverstein's feet. The singers don't sound poor here
column8: but they don't have much in the way of memorable lyrics to sing. The  overdubbed phony crowd noise becomes annoying and the repetitive nature of the subject matter (it's hard to be old) works against desiring frequent listens. One or two novelty numbers like "Cut the Mustard" and "Young Man's Job" would be plenty.  Highlights: "Rough on the Living" casts a jaundiced eye at the country music industry that talked up Johnny Cash after his death but couldn't find space on the airwaves for his new material when he was still with us (even though some of it stood alongside his finest work)
column9: I Don't Do it No More with Waylon on lead vocal is one of the better 'gettin' older' numbers here ("lovin' them ladies two at a time
column10: I don't do it no more
column11: I CAN'T do it no more...")
column12: "She'd Rather be Homeless" is a pretty witty take on one of country's "four D's" (divorce in this case...the woman chooses poverty over the yuppie life with Bobby Bare..)
column13: and "Time" is a wonderfully bittersweet look back at a life well-lived ('So it takes a bit longer to walk up a hill/What of it?/My life now is much more fulfilled/But they're tearin' down buildings that I watched them build')   Low points: Why they chose to use a cliched double entendre like "Old Dogs" as the leadoff track is beyond me. ('Old dogs don't waste his licks but he can still bury a bone'). It's easily one of the worst songs here and made me not want to keep listening to the disc. "Still Gonna Die"'s joke on health nuts wears thin. "Me and Jimmie Rodgers" would be a great piece of Americana if it ever found a hook but it just feels unfinished.   Bottom Line: While I agree that too much of the country music coming out of Nashville these days is faceless and unremarkable
column14: handing substandard material to great singers isn't a good way to make the case for putting the old-timers back on the air. A more convincing case could have been made. Let's hope the Dogs get another chance to leave the doghouse and they get more than table scraps to work with.  2 1/2 star

column1: I can see why Christian apologists like this book. It is well written
column2: with lots of sensible advice in arguing wtih skeptics
column3: and it was written from the heart.  But the idea that some minimal agreed on set of facts makes the resurrection of Jesus the best explanation of history is just - bunk. In fact
column4: it is pseudo-history
column5: the way creationism is pseudo-science. It requires one to uncritically accept the historical value of the New Testament
column6: and ignore all modern historical standards for evidence.  I have heard WIlliam Lane Craig lay out this pseudo-history in a debate
column7: and also Greg Licona. Craig is a very accomplished debater
column8: Licona less so - but neither one is persuasive. The idea that there is credible historical evidence for an empty tomb is just false
column9: and the whole argument falls to pieces after that.  I think that the point of this book is to make Christians feel better about their intellectual credentials. But the arguments do not convince anyone who knows about historical standards of evidence. And if Christian missionaries just keep repeating these arguments
column10: it will eventually make them look bad.  I would recommend any book by Robert Price
column11: especially the Incredible Shrinking Son of Man
column12: to anyone who really wants to evaluate the historical case for the Resurrection

column1: Unfortunately the author did not get the basic premise correct. Ukraine does not mean borderland. The oldest use of the word found in written text is in the 10th century chronicle of Slava o Polke Ihoria. The term Ukraine is used as meaning within the kingdom
column2: at the heart of the kingdom. The opposite of what the author writes. Borderland would mean Okraina
column3: this is the difference between in and out. She also missed that Ukraine has the oldest calendar on the planet now dating to 7039. Another significant fact.  Maybe the next book could be an new history based on  archives from Lutsk and Kyiv that the author did not read. Missing such a basic premise clouds the rest of the book

column1: I first  read J. Gilbert many years ago: many people
column2: it seems
column3: jump on the bandwagon whey they find a poet who doesn't publish often or publish a lot of poems. Mr. Gilbert has admirable feelings
column4: but he is unable to translate them into readable
column5: cogent
column6: successful poems. He is not better nor worse than many poets who are acclaimed (wrongfully
column7: for the most part) and regularly published: e.g. Jorie Graham; Louise Gluck; May Oliver; Maxine Kumin; Charles Simic
column8: Gary Snyder etc. ad infinitum
column9: ad nauseam.   The major problem respecting poetry in America today is that we have too many writers and too few readers (I know
column10: some good poets can't get published--true
column11: but far fewer poets than most people realize). Mr. Gilber subtracts time from the reading of other poets
column12: including especially the classics: Virgil
column13: Dante
column14: Donne
column15: Herbert
column16: Pope
column17: Shelley
column18: Keats
column19: Wordsworth
column20: Dickinson
column21: Yeats
column22: Pound and Eliot
column23: to name well-known poets. Among more recent poets
column24: those readers who effuse over Gilbert and many other current poets
column25: should be reading Elizabeth Bishop; Edgar Bowers; Geoffrey Hill (often difficult
column26: but absolutely the best poet of our time and certain to be studied in years to come); Basil Bunting; Charles Tomlinson (a must!!!); John Berryman (Dream Songs); J.V. Cunningham.    That said I have read volumes and volumes of poetry published in the last 25 years. Good poets are there for the reading: Betty Adcock; Dick Barnes; Dick Davis; Ellen Bryant Voigt; Gibbons Ruark; Cathy Smith Bowers; David Mason; Bin Ramke; Andrea Hollander Budy; Kathryn Stripling Byer; Fred Chappell; Kelly Cherry. Not a lot more.  The bad inevitably crowds out almost all the good
column27: particularly when many readers are still trying to emulate Sylvia Plath or Anne Sexton or the odious John Ashberry; or they just use modern lingo indiscriminately or they write about politics
column28: feminism ad infinitum
column29: ad nauseam. Or they write what they read and hear in Creative Writing classes and workshops that ubiquitously litter our land with slop and slag.   Avoid Mr. Gilbert: read good poetry (And if you can't stand to be told what to read: listen to Mahler
column30: Mozart
column31: Bach). You could also do a lot worse than read Shakespeare or Cormac McCarthy.

column1: I was unfortunately subjected to the second edition of this book during my graduate studies at DTU. In my opinion there's only one good thing to say about this book
column2: and that is that it's the only book I've seen where you get a comprehensive introduction to all of the techniques for developing and serving web-pages. Unfortunately
column3: the authors are living in a Miocrosoft Internet Explorer only world
column4: which especially is reflected in their chapters on (x)html and javascript. Problem is
column5: no version of IE is actually capable of understanding xhtml
column6: so what you are in fact taught is xhtml 1.0 served as text/html which is treated as hmtl 4.01 in all browsers. Even worse
column7: the third edition has rewritten all the examples in xhmtl 1.1 which *should*not* be served as text/html. Even worse
column8: the xhtml examples given will trigger an error in IE 6 that will get IE 6 to behave as IE 5.5 in quirks mode - inclusive the css box model error. As to the javascript examples
column9: the book isn't teaching you the w3c DOM but only the IE DOM
column10: thus all examples using eg document.all will possibly fail in some browsers. And document.write isn't allowed if you are serving your pages as application/xhmtl+xml. I'm considering this book dangerous because it doesn't teach you how to code according to the w3c standards but only according to the 'Microsoft standard

column1: Yet another historical novel into which a lot of research and work was clearly put
column2: but the result is dissatisfying largely because the author doesn't know how to write.  My single biggest objection to this book is the constant and annoying use of the author's alternative grammatical rules.  Comma splices and run-on sentences are not
column3: and never will be
column4: acceptable to me.  Occasional use can be overlooked
column5: but Shaara peppers every page with them
column6: tacking four or five or more predicates on to the same subject.  The effect is so glaringly obvious that it becomes difficult to continue reading.  The following example is made-up
column7: but it is a good imitation of how Shaara writes:  "He turned in the saddle
column8: rode toward his headquarters over the ridge
column9: refused to look back toward the man receding in the distance
column10: focused instead on the day ahead
column11: forced himself to confront the bigger problems at hand."  One often finds whole paragraphs composed of several run-on sentences in a row like this.  The result is a book that reads like a rough draft
column12: or maybe not even that;  it reads like a collection of notes preparatory to writing a rough draft.  I don't understand how authors get away with publishing such half-finished work
column13: and I don't understand why readers put up with it.  Another problem is the lack of convincing characterization.  Everyone is vaguely noble here
column14: with the exception of a few complete cads.  Washington loves his wife and longs for peace and home.  Cornwallis loves his wife and longs for peace and home.  Greene loves his wife and longs for peace and home.  I think you get the picture.  Few characters stand out on their own.  Even Lafayette is just another young officer.  The author assumes that we already carry our own perceptions about the major characters and will plug them in at the start of the book.  And Shaara's attempts at making his characters witty never work.  The result is a cast of characters that is tedious and dull.  Beyond that
column15: I'm doubtful about the author's device of switching focus among the various characters in each chapter.  It's fine when we leap across the Atlantic and jump into Franklin's mind.  But the rest of the time
column16: it doesn't work well.  I find that I sometimes have to flip back to the start of the chapter to remind myself who has the focus.  Either I'm a lazy reader (and I'm not)
column17: or the device isn't working well.  In addition
column18: this device constrains the author to keep the narrative focused almost entirely on Franklin in France
column19: and Washington
column20: Green
column21: Cornwallis and Howe in America.  That means that we get only glimmers of the happenings in Parliament and the royal court in England
column22: and the continental congress in America.  In effect
column23: this novel is really about Washington's military camp and Howe's dinner table
column24: which makes the narrative unbalanced.  Some aspects of the story are interesting.  I enjoy reading about Washington's maneuvers
column25: and the repeated frustration at coming up with an empty bag and finding that the British have eluded him.  I learned a fair amount about just where the various forces were
column26: and when.  But I wish now that I'd just bought a decent beginner's history on the war.  Most of the book
column27: as literary fiction
column28: left me cold

column1: By chance before picking this up I had just finished The Heart is a Lonely Hunter by Carson McCullers
column2: and was struck by the similarities and differences. It's a great "compare and contrast" pair
column3: as an exercise for high-schoolers.  Both are written as first-person accounts by teen-aged girls and are roughly contemporary. Heart published in 1940
column4: and Castle in 1948
column5: both about life in the 30s.   Both families are poor. In Castle though
column6: there is never any question that the girls might go off and get jobs. This is supposedly because they "don't know how to do anything". So instead they sell off their belongings and get by on scraps of bread and the odd bit of butter. How charming! They are "eccentric"
column7: which seems enough in the author's eyes to exempt them from the expectation of supporting themselves. Only Stephen the handsome young son of the late housekeeper
column8: enamored of Cassandra
column9: does work and gives the family his entire salary. But he is of the class that is expected to toil after all. Even he is rewarded in the end--able to avoid labor with an easy job similar to that of step-mum Topaz--striking poses.  Unlike the looming and grinding poverty of Heart then
column10: the poverty in the Castle never amounts to more than a lark--educated folks playing at being poor until they're rescued by romantic circumstance. Not so in America where Mick Kelly
column11: who didn't know how to do anything either
column12: went off to work at Woolworth's
column13: and to a life of little hope.  In Castle the solution comes in the form of that classic deus ex machina
column14: the inheritance. Two dashing young wealthy Americans one of whom has inherited the castle
column15: show up just in time
column16: with their chatty modern mum. They throw money around and talk too much
column17: in the cliched extravagant American style. Most of the remainder of the novel consists of Cassandra and her sister Rose swooning over one brother or the other
column18: with an eventual romantic result that assures all the characters of economic well being.   It's all so very charming
column19: bourgeois
column20: and harmless. If your life is hard don't worry--a man will show up to rescue you!  The reviews for this novel in Amazon are overwhelmingly positive. Smith was obviously talented. Her writing is elegant and a pleasure to read. I wish she had given Cassandra a little more ambition.

Please!...  Unless you know A LOT about Vodou don't read this book.  The Tao of Physics or Divine Horsemen are MUCH better alternatives

column1: Worst book I've read all year (this is being written in late November) and strong contender for worst book of the decade.  Flat
column2: leaden
column3: dull prose.  Cardboard characters with no depth.  Silly little trivial asides.  No sense whatever of plotting
column4: timing or narrative.  The author uses a true story from the pages of the Wall Street Journal as the basis for this book
column5: but does not realize that he still has an obligation to write well and make the characters come alive -- you can't hang your words on an extoskeleton; the book has to have internal structure.  The ending is farcial
column6: and the subplot conflict between father and son is a genuine embarassment to read.  Avoid at all costs.  I want my money back!

column4: for example. It could technically be interpreted to mean many things to many different people

column1: The book's objective: "An exploration of core diagrams
column2: and how they can be used effectively in business".  What the book tells you: Fourteen core diagrams
column3: what they are
column4: how to use them. They are all familiar diagrams that an average user will find it easy to understand. Most
column5: if not all
column6: of the diagrams are standard textbook presentations. I see nothing new from this book.  What the book does not tell you: Non-core diagrams. I bought this book expected to discover some fancy diagrams to use in my business presentations. The kinds that consultants are found of using to justify their horrendous fees. But none of that is present in this book.

column1: I graduated in Statistics

column8: it is written to franchisors
column9: not franchisees.  Since the marketing of the book makes it look like it's trying to appeal to everyone
column10: it took me a few chapters to figure out that it's actually written to franchisors.  Repeat: It is NOT good for franchisees.  I did complete the entire book.  I'm not one of those reviewers who calls the book boring after reading a few pages and throwing it away.  I am someone who plugged through so that I could warn everyone else

column1: Like many people have repeatedly said

column1: I read in a magazine about how "wonderful" and full of "romance" this novel was and so I checked it out for a bit of summer reading only to discover that it wasn't wonderful or romantic at all.  The narration was witty and comical
column2: but the outcome of the novel was frustrating and sad. As anyone will tell you
column3: a young man named Charles is walking along the beach one day with his fiancee when they come across a forlorn young woman staring out at the sea. The rumors say that this young woman (Sarah) had her heart broken by a French L. who then left her for the sea
column4: and that everyday she stares at the ocean in the hope that he will come back. She is dismissed as mad by the locals and works for a snobby old Catholic woman.  And yet
column5: dispite all this
column6: Charles is smitten by her.  He and the French L.'s woman cross pathes regulary by chance
column7: until Charles finally sits down with her and asks her for her story: it only confirms what everyone else is saying: she slept with the French L. and he left her heartbroken.  ::SPOILERS:: Don't buy this novel. I can tell you what happens and save you ten bucks.   What happens next is this: Sarah is fired on the mere suspicion that she is having a tryst with said Charles. Sarah fires up (for the first time showing a temper) and declares that she is NOT fired -- she quits! She then storms from the hosue and disappears from the town alltogether. The  town goes on a manhunt for her -- but
column8: of course
column9: it's Charles who finds her.  Later
column10: the two hook up in a hotel and have sex. When Charles's family and future father-in-law find out
column11: he is stripped of his inheiritance
column12: left poor and thoroughly humiliated
column13: while Sarah has disappeared yet again . . . and yet he STILL  can not forget her! He travels the world
column14: missing Sarah
column15: until one say he locates her. She's been living with an artist.  Here are the alternate endings:  Ending one: Sarah and Charles meet
column16: Charles is naturally upset
column17: but all anger is forgotten when a little girl appears. It is his daughter. He stays and holds the child. End of story.  Ending two: Sarah and Charles meet
column18: Charles is pissed off and yells at Sarah
column19: who is trying to tell him that he's a father. Charles won't listen. He storms from the house and never gets to meet his daughter. End of story.  What a great story
column20: huh? (Sarcasm)

column1: This short E.P. of mostly live performances was mainly an effort to hold fans over in-between albums.  Some live performances with Queen were included

column3: performed as a duet with Lisa Stansfield.  Michael also performs live renditions of Seal's Killer"(#69 US)
column4: which segues into the Rolling Stones' "Papa Was a Rolling Stone
column5: and a stark, stirring performance of Bob Telson's Oscar nominated Calling You" (from the BAGDAD CAFE).  Also included
column6: for somewhat inexplicable reasons
column7: is a brief snippet of Queen performing "Dear Friends" from it's SHEER HEART ATTACK album.  There are enough interesting moments to make this a fine listen for Michael's fans
column8: however
column9: none of the covers top the originals and most listeners will be able to live without it.

column1: Like many other reviewers
column2: I struggled with this book. For more than 600 pages
column3: Anna Wulf explores every thought and emotion that comes into her head and tries to make sense out of her life. This might be an interesting book for fiction writers
column4: who might understand the elaborate process Anna goes through to create characters and combine her life with her art. But for the average reader
column5: this is just too much and too long.  I am very patient with novels. Perhaps too patient
column6: because I should have put this one down sooner. I got all the way to page 500 before I realized I just couldn't go on. And it's quite depressing to invest so much time in a book and then put it down. Doris Lessing says herself that no one should force themselves to read a book they are not connecting with. I should have taken her advice sooner. But while some books you might not just be 'ready' for
column7: I don't think I will ever be ready for this one.   It's disappointing because I am a Doris Lessing fan. The Four-Gated City explores many of the same themes - an emotional breakdown can be constructive in order to build yourself back up whole and understand the world around you. Anna Wulf did have a fragmented mind
column8: as demonstrated through her keeping of four separate notebooks. She was kept together by the routines of her life
column9: such as making breakfast for her daughter. When she didn't have anything constructive to do
column10: she thought herself to death. And if you read this book
column11: you'll likely be right there with her - going crazy.

column1: I've been following the Alex Cross series from its beginning
column2: and after reading Cat & Mouse
column3: I'm wondering if Patterson has taken these characters as far as they can go... Given the fact that there are 7 or 8 more Cross books written subsequently to this one
column4: I can only hope that the series gets better.  My complains are similar to those of other reviewers:  1. I'm getting sick of the perfection of Alex Cross.  The man's a saintly father
column5: saintly grandson
column6: saintly lover
column7: saintly charity worker
column8: and saintly detective.  These traits hooked the reader and made Cross an intriguing character
column9: but he's fast becoming too one-dimensional.  2. The Cross/Sampson relationship.  As if we weren't sick enough of this already.  Every few chapters
column10: we're reminded of the man-crush Cross and Sampson have on each other.  Sampson is so perfect in Cross's eyes that it becomes tiresome to hear about it every time Sampson enters a scene.  3. The Cross/Christine Johnson relationship moves WAY too fast.  One moment Christine is still mourning the loss of her husband (who was viciously murdered 6 months prior in Jack & Jill) and freaks out over an innocent dinner date
column11: and the next she and Cross are madly in love.  No development whatsoever
column12: no line from Point A to Point B.  4. I'm not sure Patterson could have written the dialogue between Cross and his children any more unrealistically.  Aren't these 7- and 9-year-old children?  He has more intelligent conversations with his kids than he does with Sampson or Kyle Craig.  5. The entire novel is a series of pseudo-climaxes which are ultimately resolved by plot twists that seemingly arrive from left field.  The Soneji resolution was anti-climactic at best
column13: and the Mr. Smith conclusion was unfulfilling

column1: Those who expect vocals by the featured singer Bocelli will be disappointed.  He only sings one selection.  The selections are almost completely instrumental and choral
Siegel presents an interesting view of the next few decades and how to profit off them. With the book
column2: he had to do two things: prove that "Stocks For The Long Run" still works and join in on the many books about the effect of demographics on equities.  Siegel's portfolio theories are the strength of the book. Compounding dividends and the mean aversion theory of stocks have been a success. The time period Siegel uses to come up with hypothetical returns has been the best 50 years for US markets
column3: so one can only hope it continues.  Siegel's demographic models show that Harry S. Dent's Age Wave gets completely absorbed by rising middle-classes around the world and several other smaller solutions. But the numbers just don't add up and I mean that quite literally. This is one of the largest demographic problems the planet has seen in 500 years. I fully expect some sacrifice coming up. Too many people owe too much money.  In case of a worst case scenario
column4: such as those in "The Next Great Bubble Boom
column5: The Coming Generational Storm
column6: Empire of Debt
column7: and Prechtor/Folsom's daily newsletters, Siegel recommends TIPS. Read that again. TIPS during a period of deflation.  I don't know what the future will bring, but at least I know what a business professor's computer models think will happen. If you're set on reading this book, be sure to read Stocks For The Long Run" first

column1: It was difficult to assign a "star rating" for this book. It is a classic
column2: for sure. It's definately a good book. However
column3: I don't think I'd recommend it for most readers
column4: and hence the low rating.  Like all of Knuth's "Art of Programming" books
column5: this one is really starting to age. Like other reviewers
column6: I really don't like the MIX assembly examples. (MIX is a fictional computer that he invented purely for the purpose of teaching.) His rationale for using MIX is because he says that he doesn't want to just discuss topics in theory
column7: sometimes it's necessary to show how it's actually implemented. He does this in MIX. He says that he chose MIX
column8: rather than any actual existing machine language
column9: so that it wouldn't be out of date or be tied to a particular platform. Unfortuanetly
column10: there are several problems with the MIX examples:  * First
column11: it's assembly language. I used to do lots of assembly language. (I make video games.) Now I do almost none at all. In general
column12: very few programmers do assembly language programming. I understand how in many cases using a high-level language could possibly have glossed over some of the details. However
column13: still
column14: I think a language like C is sufficiently low level that he could have acheived the same results with C
column15: and it would have been much more readable and accessible to today's audience.  Also
column16: when Knuth wrote his first books
column17: C was just being born
column18: and since then
column19: it has become a lingua franca in the computer science community.  * MIX is purposely contrived to be "weird" (6-bit word size???)  * Most importantly
column20: using a fictious computer system introduces an unnecessary extra step to understanding the examples. Not only do you have to learn the material
column21: but you have to wade through learning MIX - information you won't use anywhere else. I know that any of C
column22: Java
column23: Pascal
column25: MIPS
column26: etc would have had people who didn't know that language and so it would have been an impediment to them. Unfortunatly
column27: Knuth has chosen a language that NOBODY knows and so EVERYBODY has this extra learning curve.  The books are also really heavy on the math. I think it's not unfair to say that these books are more math books than they are computer books. Knuth is famous for setting computer science on a mathematical foundation. He proves everything and RIGOROUSLY discusses the math behind every topic. For some readers
column28: this is enlightening. Now I am not shy on math (I wrote a book on 3D math myself) however I usually found the detailed proofs unnecessary. I also wish he would have expressed ideas in English more that equations. For example
column29: Knuth would never write "the elements sum to one" - instead
column30: he'd have an equation using sigma notation. Which is consise and precise and in some sense "elegent" - but it takes a lot of mental "work" to read. I think many readers will share this sentiment.  Some people include the phrase "the information is timeless."  Yeah
column31: this is true.  But the presentation style is not.  There other books with the same "timeless" information
column32: and a more up-to-date style of presentation.  I personally use Sedgewick's algorithm's book.  An interesting anecdote on how much I have been actually able to use this book - perhaps it will help you estimate if you will get enough use out of it to justify the price tag. We discovered that the rand() function in the C library on the PS2 was buried underneath several layers of funtion calls and checks for different random number modes
column33: etc
column34: and it was causing a performance problem
column35: and we needed to write a replacement. I was thrilled. Finally
column36: an opportunity to pull the Knuth off the shelf! This book is one of the the bibles on random numbers. I looked for advice on chosing A and C for the linear congruential generator. There was SOOOO much information. (The first 190 pages of the 2nd volume deal with random numbers.) It was all very facinating. Yet in the end
column37: we dug up the gcc source for rand() and just used the numbers they chose!

column1: Science is about making deductions from factual evidence. It has no means of explaining anything that is supernatural.   However
column2: religion requires the belief in supernatural forces and at least one supernatural being.   That DOES NOT mean religion is wrong
column3: it just means it is a different subject matter than science and therefore DOES NOT belong in a science classroom.   You wouldn't expect English literature
column4: music
column5: history and other such subjects to be taught in a science classroom. Neither should religious beliefs. I
column6: for one
column7: am perfectly happy to have my religious beliefs kept out of science classrooms. I don't need science to tell me there is a God. I don't need - or want - my religious beliefs to force science to be conducted in a certain way. Quite frankly
column8: anyone who feel that the honest teaching of science is a threat to their religious beliefs is someone who has great doubts about their religious beliefs!

column1: I read this book and it made me so upset to think that the author would dare to run our foremothers into the muck that she writes.  There is no such reason to make the foremothers seem like they were unhappy performing "traditionally feminine roles" or enbittered because of them.  Priorities were much different back then and it took A LOT more physical and time consuming work to run a household and make a living than it does in the 21st century.    I am afraid this book will push many females away from Judaism. This book starts with a belief that Judaism is a male chauvinistic religion
column2: and does its best to "prove" this the case.  The author misses out on many of the beautiful commentaries about our foremothers.  When she does include these stories
column3: she dissmisses them as being from another religion or as proof of bible written by humans - which both contribute to deligitamizing the stories.  So much more could have been learned and glorify our foremothers and all of the wonderous things that they performed.  I recommend you steer clear of this book! If you are looking to learn about our foremothers and what Judaism feels about women choose another book.  Please realize that there are many other lessons to be learned from the stories that she tells and there are others that are not included

column1: This is a deeply flawed book. It purports to be a description of the characteristics and attitudes that make wealthy people wealthy
column2: but it is based mostly on their self-assessments without comparison to a control group. I suspect that this heavily underplays the role of random chance in success
column3: and attributes causation where there is only correlation. Further
column4: the author displays clear biases on a number of topics
column5: which leads him to engage in ad hoc interpretation of his data
column6: sometimes to argue for conclusions that are contrary to the clear implications of the data--such as his arguments for the importance of religion in the lives of millionaires.  On pp. 33-35
column7: the author looks at success factors
column8: and compares to the role of luck on pp. 82-85
column9: which he downplays in favor of discipline. While he touches on the importance of having the right connections (and the genetic contributions to intelligence)
column10: on p. 85 he asks "what does luck have to do with graduating from medical school? What does luck have to do with successfully running a medical practice? Very little
column11: according to these physicians." But what does luck have to do with being born into a family and in a country where one has a chance to reach adulthood
column12: let alone be able to attend a medical school? Quite a bit.  Unlike its predecessor
column13: which looked at prodigious accumulators of wealth (PAWs) vs. under-accumulators of wealth (UAWs)
column14: this book focuses on millionaires (PAWs) and decamillionaires (a tiny subset of PAWs
column15: those with net worth $10M or greater). The lack of comparison to the general public serves to limit the book's value.  A misleading comparison between businessmen and stockbrokers on pp. 76ff makes the point. Stanley states that the former is an occupation more likely to have higher net worth. But this comparison is misleading because he's only looking at the millionaire-plus sample; he is excluding more of the total business owner population from his sample than stockbrokers. The average and median income and net worth for business owners are likely lower than for stockbrokers. If he made the same comparison with actors or musicians to stockbrokers
column16: for example
column17: the problem is more obvious--by excluding all those who aren't worth $1M or more up front
column18: you exclude the vast majority
column19: and pull up the average. With stockbrokers
column20: on the other hand
column21: a higher percentage of them are in the top income earners and wealthy.  On p. 110
column22: after having pages about the importance of ethics and advising "Never lie. Never tell one lie." (p. 55)
column23: he passes right over his example
column24: Mr. Warren
column25: lying about being a college graduate in order to get a job
column26: without comment
column27: and without noticing the hypocrisy.  On pp. 173-174
column28: the author wants to make the point that prayer is important for millionaires dealing with stress
column29: despite the fact that the majority of his surveyed population do not regularly pray. (He repeats this again on p. 370
column30: saying "nearly one-half of the millionaires (47 percent) engaged in prayer. ... for a significant percentage of millionaires
column31: their religious faith is a major force in their lives.")  In trying to emphasize the point (p. 174)
column32: he splits his sample into "religious millionaires" (RM) and "other millionaires" (OM)
column33: observes that 75% of RM engage in prayer while only 8% of OM do
column34: and points out that this is "a ratio of more than nine to one." This is a meaningless comparison
column35: however--RM make up only 37% of his total population of millionaires
column36: so his "more than nine to one" ratio is really nothing more than saying
column37: of those millionaires who are religious
column38: three-fourths hold religious practices which involve regular prayer (and 8% of those who do not consider themselves religious pray anyway). Since the OM population is much larger than the RM population
column39: in absolute numbers that's not a nine-to-one ratio--his numbers show that about 28% of his total sample are RM who pray
column40: while 5% of his total sample are OM who pray--closer to a six-to-one ratio.  But more importantly
column41: the author glosses over the fact that not only are the majority of millionaires not religious
column42: even a quarter of those who are don't engage in regular prayer! Given that the U.S. is one of the most religious countries in the world
column43: the fact that such a low percentage of millionaires are religious is quite interesting and worthy of further exploration as to the cause
column44: but for Stanley
column45: religion and prayer are an important foundation of the "millionaire mind
column46: and he completely misses the opportunity to find an explanation for why millionaires are so much less religious than the general population.  In a later table in the book on p. 366, he shows activities engaged in by a sample of 733 millionaires during the preceding 30 days. The table includes 52% attending religious services, 47% praying, 37% attending religious events, 22% Bible/devotional reading. These numbers don't quite match up with the RM/OM data from pp. 173-174, which seem to show even lower levels of religious activity, but these are still lower than they are for the nonmillionaire population--and weekly church attendance is notoriously over-reported in surveys. Work by Mark Chaves, C. Kirk Hardaway, and P.L. Marler in the 1990s found the actual percentage of attendance about half of what surveys show. This actually could mean that millionaires attend more often, if Stanley's survey results don't have similar over-reporting.  The author's religious bias further leads him to recommend to a student going through a divorce that she, despite not being a church attendee, search for a mate by joining a church group (p. 268) because she believed in marriage and the traditional family concept." He writes that "I believe that one is likely to find better prospects in a church setting than in singles bars. Of course
column47: there are no guarantees
column48: but people with a religious orientation are more prone to respect the principles espoused in the Good Book." But why is he just guessing on this? Hasn't he asked his population of millionaires--the ones who are 63% non-religious--how they met their mates? He did this
column49: very usefully
column50: regarding how millionaires purchase their homes (pp. 315-326)--yet isn't picking a partner even more important?      This book has some interesting data
column51: and is at its best when giving comparative results between populations (e.g.
column52: the house-purchasing characteristics of economically productive millionaires vs. non-economically productive millionaires in chapter 7). But it doesn't stand up well in comparison to The Millionaire Next Door
column53: which is a much better book

column1: Well
column2: before buying this I had never even heard of bright eyes.  Just so you know my background
column3: I generally dislike indie and Emo.  I usually listen to hardcore and Screamo.  But for some reason I became interested in this band.  (or person) Someone compared a CD of their's to A Death Cab CD.  Me being a pretty big Death Cab fan
column4: I decided to go out and buy this EP to see if I liked this band at all.  This review is the result of that listen.  The EP opens up with the slow acoustic guitar picks of "a line allows prgress"...  A few seconds into the song I am greeted with with drums and an organ.  This song sounds like a slower Cursive song.  The guy's voice sounds decent.  I guess the vocal effects he uses are for emotional purposes.  Overall this is a pretty decent song.  It reminds me of hotel california.  Next in line comes one of my favorite tracks on here:  "a perfect sonnet".  I don't know if it's the simple guitar stum or the sense that his voice is going to explode any moment.  Seriously
column5: the whole song I was thinking that everything was about to fall apart...but it didn't.  He keeps going and going.  It must be his voice that creates this mood.  This was also the point of the CD where I realized that it was a bit more than music I was listening to.  Bright eyes will make you feel moods that other music can't.  It's got a unique brand of emotion that is new to me.  It's too bad this song ends so quickly.  As I press on to: "on my way to work" I begin to get the feel for the CD.  He's almost whispering on this track.  There's an odd sounding guitar picking and a country sounding synthesizer.  Quite frankly
column6: I hate this song.  It sounds like an offkey country ballad...  Who wants that?  The next two tracks are more or less the same feel.  A new arrangement provides better quality music than the craptastic on my way to work
column7: but doesn't reach the level of A perfect sonnet.  Finally
column8: the EP is ended with the techno atmospheric: Neely o hara...  I don't know what to say.  It's meaningless.  I don't see how you can like this.  It's just pointless.  Overall this is a half and half EP.  The first two tracks are good...  But the rest of the CD falls between failing and decent.  If Bright Eyes good churn out more tracks like a perfect sonnet
column9: this band would get at least a 4 star.  Sadly thats not the case.  So I don't recommend this for anyone other than the really dedicated fans.  Perhaps the other CD's are better

column1: We purchased this machine for our small coffee shop 2 months ago as in the discription it was said to be for light commercial use. We make probably 20-30 cups of coffee a day. The machine makes great froth for cappuccinoes but if you want to have steamed milk instead of frothed it either comes out of luke warm temperature allthough the setting is on high temperature or if you put the dial almost on the line between latte and cappuccino it gives you too much foam
column2: which lattes shouldn't have. So customers complain about their lattes being either too cool or too foamy. We called the manufacturer's customer service and were rudely brushed off. For a small business like us it is hard to close for 2-3 weeks to send the machine for temperature adjustment service
column3: so we had to deal with it. Another problem came up 3-4 weeks later
column4: when the machine started shutting off by itself in the middle of steaming/frothing cycle or frother cleaning cycle. Sometimes we had to restart it up to 5 times to make 1 cup of hot chocolate
column5: just to steam milk. At the customer service we were told to reset the computer by unplugging the machine for a couple of hours
column6: which we did. It did not shut off for 1 day! The next day the problem started again...  I perform every neccessary cleaning or maintenance procedure that machine prompts and cappuccino cleaning daily
column7: so you can not say that the machine is being neglected.  We are very disappointed with this machine. For the price that you pay you would think that at least customer service would be polite
column8: understanding and helpful. Now we are looking for another machine
column9: a back up one
column10: to be able to send Impressa Z5 for service..

column1: Am I the *ONLY* person who thinks Thoreau was an arrogant snob who did nothing but whine? Maybe it's because I'm an Englishman in America but all I hear is American educational institutions praising Thoreau's "Civil Disobedience". I don't deny that he has made some points worth considering in his book but many people have made the same points without whining and railing at humanity.  I would dearly like to say I had the patience to read this book all the way through but it is perhaps the only book I've ever read that I couldn't finish. I found it hard to separate Thoreau's genuine
column2: honest observations from his juvenile complaining.   The phrase that I found mose running through my head (shortly before I deleted the book) was "o'erweening arrogance". The man's arrogance is astounding. He supposes himself so far superior to his peers in EVERY way.  I found his writing to be confused and self-serving. He could barely hold a topic for one page at a time before veering off on to another
column3: entirely unrelated one. He skips from subject to subject and often contradicts himself within the same chapter.  I got the electronic version of this book and
column4: to date
column5: it is the only book I have actually deleted. So
column6: I'd love to pepper my "critique" with quotes that I found completely offensive and juvenile but that would mean getting the book again and I *really* don't want to do that

Derrida gets 2 stars for FINALLY coming around to writing about social and political issues. The book itself is interesting
column2: but the fact of the matter is
column3: it's not good Marxism. He's remained ambiguous even since the 1968 French University protests of 1968. His only discussions of Marx revolved around his critique of Hegel
column4: and I believed he dropped Lenin's name a few times in "Positions". Still
column5: Derrida's entry into Marxism is a disappointing one. While he never claims to be a Marxist
column6: one would expect him to be aware of the basic tenents of Marxism. The problem with Derrida's book is it's fetishism of the spirit. The specter takes precedence over the material. Ultimately
column7: Derrida misses the point of historical materialism completely. History is ALWAYS present...there is no specter. In Marx's view we are always creating our own history
column8: as part of our nature as human beings. Furthermore
column9: Derrida's dialectics in the book is far from dialectical materialism. Despite what he claims to be a thorough reading of the German Ideology
column10: he falls into the same traps of the Young Hegelians Marx critiques. His dialectics posits an a priori state
column11: beyond history
column12: language
column13: and everything. Derrida claims he doesnt but this "presence non-presence" of the specter applies something beyond both the material and memory. Regardless
column14: neither of these options suit Marx.  Consciousness (das Basswussein I believe?) is the life-blood of the human being
column15: and her/his existence. It is material in and of itself. There is no to come
column16: it is always in process
column17: always becoming
column18: it is in transition. It is not a state of being as "to" implies...it IS being. Anyone who wants a refutation of Derrida need merely read the "camera obscura" passage of the German Ideology. Furthermore
column19: had Derrida read MORE early Marx
column20: and paid attention to the seminal importance of the "Grundrisse" in linking humanism to the political critique and the economic critique
column21: he might've been more clear on what dialecitcal and historical materialism entail. We see how historical materialism is a humanism. (If anyone notices a similarity to the Sartre essay "Existentialism is a Humanism"
column22: kudos...it has a purpose. I think Derrida (and even Marx himself) would've benefited from Sartre's reading of Marx. Anyone who would like a nice concise exposition of that reading that has some familiarity with Marx need only read Sartre's "Search for a Method").  Derrida's clear misreading of Marx will make the book a confusing and misleading read for anyone not already familair with Marx
column23: so I recommend read the Econ./Phil. Manuscripts
column24: Chapters 1
column29: 25 of Capital
column31: the 1st 15 pages of the Ger. Ideo.
column32: and the intro to the Grundrisse and the intro to the Contribution to the Critique of Pol. Econ. or at least SOME of the above writings by Marx. (Another complaint not related to Derrida's reading of Marx is his statement that justice is undeconstructible. Why? The quasi-universal cop out is annoying. Thats a contradiction in terms...I think Derrida needs to stop with the Heideggerian wordplay and make up his mind about foundationalism and deconstruction.) Still
column33: Derrida writes some startlingly beautiful passages about social justice (the part that talks about how "never even the histroy of the world have their been more people starved
column34: killed
column35: and disenfranchised at the hands of a government or should I say empire" or something like that. But flashy rhetoric and Derrida's impeccable
column36: yet esoteric writing style cannot save him from the fact that ultimately his own lack of theoretical grounding
column37: practicality

column9: for many years
column10: in getting the "inside view"--the  view of a culture as seen by the person within it.  While Barzini is  indisputable Italian
column11: he tries to visualize Italians as seen by foreign  visitors
column12: then explain to those of us not lucky enough to travel there
column13: why  they are as visitors see them
column14: or why they are not as foreigners may think.   This is not a successful gambit.  Cultures are based on many general  factors--like history
column15: socio-economic patterns
column16: religion
column17: family
column18: etc.---but the specific results are just that
column19: specific.  Barzini covers  many topics--the importance of spectacle and giving an illusion of  something rather than actually having that quality; the family vs. the  state; Italian modes of achieving success; the north-south split; Sicily  and the Mafia; and last
column20: the tragedy of Italy's long domination by  foreigners.  But nothing really connects.  There are only superficial
column21: scattered impressions
column22: nothing very concrete to grasp.  The reader is left  with a handful of stereotypes.  Barzini is at his best when describing the  lives and modus operandi of particular characters in Italian history.   These sections were well-written and interesting.  But his portrayal of  Italian "character" is fuzzy

column11: yada yada yada.  But that's not true
column12: is it?  So many people in this country believe that this the plot of this book is plausible and even to be encouraged - - just look at the reviews to find the believers.  Alright
column13: here are my problems with it:  First
column14: politicians are corrupt and will sell-out anyone to maintain power
column15: but that's not true if you're a conservative farm-boy elected despite your honesty from a midwestern state.  In Term Limits
column16: Vince Flynn just beats you over the head with the "power corrupts" mantra - he doesn't show it in the actions so much as just repeats it like the chorus of a bad rap song
column17: yet from the lips of the Marine Combat Veteran Congressman who is our protagonist.  You know what
column18: though?  There are people in politics on BOTH SIDES OF THE AISLE who really want to do what's right
column19: who really are trying to make a difference for the positive
column20: for this nation and the citizens.  In this book
column21: however
column22: the public is a tool to be used and treated as if they aren't smart enough to make good decisions.  Second
column23: murder is a viable answer.  This repeats another mantra that conservatives repeat often - that they do the hard fighting and living to protect this nation and its freedoms so that the liberals can live in their fantasy-land.  Come on
column24: get real.  This book touts a Special Forces Unit as being so committed to the Constitution that they are willing to murder high-level politicians and threaten the president with assassination if he doesn't balance the budget.  And
column25: they get away with it because it's really the right side to be on.  Murdering our leaders is the answer according to Vince Flynn.  Murder solves the obvious weakness that we have as a nation
column26: that being elections.  Elections apparently just get in the way.  Third
column27: the balanced budget.  For years and years - until the time this book was written - conservatives cried about the budget.  The book makes it the central theme.  Balance the budget and make us fiscally responsible.  It's important enough for a military coup supported by the protagonist of this novel.  A Coup!!!  Yet
column28: when the conservatives did take power
column29: despite Vince Flynn's prescient forecasting ability
column30: they ran the deficit into uncharted territory and didn't flinch.  Even when confronted by this atrocity of fiscal irresponsibility
column31: they claim that NOW!!!!! the deficit isn't a big deal
column32: that it's really just a function of the percentage of GDP and we ought to all forget about it.  This book starkly reveals the disconnect between conservative priorities of the 90's and the realized result nearly two presidential terms later.  It's like looking back in time to a parade of nit-wits.  Fourth
column33: the good guys don't do bad things.  The Special Ops team kills only who they want and never any innocents - just the politicians.  The bad guys leave a wake of messy slaughter and civilians whenever they use murder as a tool.  Flynn spends way too much time making this point and beating the reader over the head with it . . . killing is good when only your target dies . . . but whatever happened to that oh so famous
column34: though shalt not?  - CV Ric

column1: Suzanne Hansen must have read The Nanny Diaries and said to herself
column2: "Hey! I was a nanny for some famous and important people and I hated my job. I can write a book like that."  Only she can't
column3: and she didn't. She uses actual names and claims this is a true story but unfortunately
column4: making it real doesn't make it good. There is name-dropping (so much it becomes tedious) and sure
column5: Hansen was a nanny for an unreasonable family
column6: but that's as far as it goes. This book lacks any of the warmth
column7: the genuineness
column8: and the realism that made The Nanny Diaries so fun and touching. Hansen tells the story of her year as a nanny for the Ovitz family with no seeming rhyme or reason. The narrative lurches forward in a series of anecdotes that seem to exist completely on their own. It's simply a walk down memory lane
column9: (plagued by corny jokes) not an actual story with a point.   The characters may be based on real people
column10: but they are not real here. We never get to know any of them and consequently
column11: we don't really care about them. Hansen waves her paper dolls at us and tells us how we're SUPPOSED to feel about them
column12: but we never actually feel anything. Everyone is flat and dreadfully uninteresting; even Michael Ovitz
column13: who is supposed to by a dynamic and forceful personality
column14: is bland.  The children
column15: who we are supposed to care for and worry about
column16: are so badly written that they barely even register and make no impression.  Even if the characters were better written
column17: the protagonist is so loathsome that it's hard to sympathize or care about her. Her "hick from the sticks" routine quickly grows old and she spends the entire book whining about how underappreciated and used she feels and how mean these rich people are. She is selfish and completely self-centered - the very behavior she accuses her employers of.  She even condones employees stealing from their employers
column18: reasoning the employers deserve it because they are so wealthy.    Hansen admits all this happened some time ago and the story is dreadfully out of date. The name-dropping is a line-up of has-been celebrities no one cares about now.  We may have loved Cheers and Family Ties in the 80s
column19: but most of us don't now.  (In fact
column20: many readers are likely too young to even remember those shows!)  Added to this is the character's unfortunate crush on Tom Cruise
column21: who has recently proven that he's a lunatic.  It's hard to like a girl who's gaga over such a ridiculous person.   Too lifeless for those who want a good read and not enough dirt for those looking for some good Hollywood gossip. The whole book seems like a dated
column22: sad grab for the coattails of its more popular
column23: better written predecessor. There are really only two reasons for Hansen to write this story so long after the fact - money or revenge. Either motive makes her just as petty and vindictive as the Hollywood family she writes about

column2: when I asked her what was wrong she broke down sobbing about how the old lady dies in the end of the song.  I haven't seen her this upset about anything in a long time.  Even after I explained to her that it was just a story and not real  she still was upset for the rest of the night.  I know that death is a topic that we all need to discuss with our children
column3: but I'm not sure that this is the appropriate way to deal with it.  I have removed the craft that she made so she doesn't need to be reminded of it.  I know that there are a few children in her class who have lost grandparents this year and it just seems like maybe this book could bring up sad feelings for them as well

column1: I've always looked upon "Christian" fiction with a rather wary eye.  It has less to do with the subject matter than the lesser quality of these works; it's as if the publishers cynically assumed that merely presenting something as "Christian" would be enough to guarantee a certain level of readership
column2: no matter how poorly written the book is (this is often done with science fiction and fantasy as well).  Three (or more properly
column3: Thr3e) by Ted Dekker has done little to alter my view.  (Why did I read the book?  Because when I bought it (along with another Dekker book)
column4: I didn't realize fully what I was buying.)  Three tells the story of Kevin Parson
column5: a seminary student who suffered from a strange
column6: semi-abusive childhood.  He gets a phone call one day warning him that unless he solves a riddle within three minutes
column7: his car will explode.  Kevin doesn't solve the riddle and the car does blow up
column8: but he escapes intact.  Thus begins a cat-and-mouse game with Slater
column9: who may or may not be a serial killer named the Riddle Killer.  Slater believes that Kevin has committed a grave sin that requires confession or death.  Kevin
column10: along with his childhood friend Samantha (now a state cop) and Jennifer Peters (an FBI agent) try and hunt down Slater
column11: but Slater is apparently too clever to be caught easily.  There is not much that is truly Christian about this book other than a few religious lines (never getting very preachy) and the definitely PG-rated material:  the language is gentle enough
column12: the romance is chaste and the violence is relatively bloodless.  I'm fine with all that as long as the story's good
column13: and that's not the case here.  It's actually too bad
column14: because Dekker seems like a decent enough plotter
column15: but the story relies on a plot twist that is one of the most annoying in suspense fiction; I won't say what it is
column16: but even Dekker seems a bit uncomfortable with it
column17: as he spends a lot of time rationalizing it.  In addition
column18: to perpetrate this twist
column19: he has to actively deceive (not merely mislead) the reader
column20: which is a cheat.  In addition
column21: even though Dekker has a good sense of plot (till the end) and he is able to maintain a fast
column22: tense pace
column23: he is overall
column24: just a passable writer.  I suppose technically his work is proficient
column25: but compared to the great names in crime stories (Elmore Leonard
column26: Michael Connelly
column27: Lee Child
column28: etc.)
column29: Dekker's prose is just flat.  With a two-star rating
column30: it is not the worst book out there
column31: but it is one to avoid.
